Taste/Palate: Its sweet up front with lots of deep malty texture in a full body. Roasted grain, toasted bready notes, caramel and toffee blend with mild bitterness from the mostly hidden hops and finish a little dryer but still with some residual sugary sweetness. It has a smooth full feel with light carbonation.

Notes: Overall its a well made and very enjoyable American Porter.

Bottle 355ml at home. Pours amost pitch black with small dark tan head. Aroma is prunes, molasses, dark choc. Taste is medium to very sweet, light, dry bitterness. Medium to full body, oily, average carbonation.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Sweet, coffee, chocolate & malt aroma. Almost black colour with a good head. Sour, grassy, chocolate & malt flavour. Quite smooth but has a lingering sour aftertaste. Drinkable but not outstanding.

bottle poured in tulip.
Big beautiful brown head with lots of retention. this beer is a deep dark BLACK. Aroma of dark malts. Fabulous taste of dark chocolate coffee and toasted nuts. Smooth thick palate with a little bite. Yummy sweet coffee aftertaste

Served from a bottle on a recent trip up to San Fran. The appearance is a deep brown black with a big foamy brown head. The aromas are full with a good heavy roasted grain and a light burnt coffee note. The flavors are pretty rich with a similar heavy roast grain, malts, and some coffee notes. Very dry flavors with just a kiss of sweet. The mouth is on the fuller side and well carbonated, perhaps a touch too much. A great classic porter.

Dark black in color with a thick dark head. Chocolatey, smokey flavor with an average mouthfeel and light carbonation. This beer isnt going to knock you off your feet, but like every Anchor beer there is just something about it. A nice classic brew that youre sure to enjoy.
Dark, murky brown color with a medium tan head. Bitter chocolate taste. This could have used more malt.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2012 Pitch black body, big rocky brown head. Coffee and chocolate in the not so strong aroma. Smooth, flavour is sweet with coffee, lots of chocolate. Excellent. (7/5/8/5/18)
(MAR 5, 2012) Black body, creamy light brown head. Some coffee, chocolate, and hops in the aroma. Nice flavour with coffee, licorice and dark chocolate with a balanced bitterness. Very nice. (7/5/7/4/17)
Black body, medium light brown head. Bitter coffee and black chocolate in the aroma. Great roasted flavour with black coffee, dark chocolate. Great.

I poured a 12 oz bottle into a tall pint glass...

The beer was black, there was just a sliver of light that shines through the edge of the glass with brownish, red hues. The head was tall, filmy and tan colored. I could smell lots of roasted malt, molasses, chocolate and a dark fruity presence. Tastes roasty, there is some licorice and molasses, raisin and bitter coffee. The liquid is smooth and silky, it has low carbonation and a thick medium body. The rich flavor and full body prevents me from drinking very many at a time, its very enjoyable though.

12oz bottled August 7, 2010.  Pours dark brown with a large foamy light brown head that leaves some really clumpy rings of lacing on the glass and holds a small cap.  Aroma is dark fruits such as prunes, figs, and raisins, roasted malt, some chocolate, a bit of coffee, caramel and toffee round things out.  Very good strength.  Flavor mostly follows suit with a good dark fruit presence up front then some chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, caramel and toast.  Moderately sweet, low bitterness.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied, somewhat creamy, medium carbonation.  An excellent Porter Ive enjoyed many times in the past but never got around to reviewing.  Good stuff!

Fantastic beer. Had on tap at the San Francisco International Airport Anchor Brewing company location. The pour is pure opaque black with a thick creamy tan head. Aroma is roasty, chocolately, coffee, nutty and roasty. The taste is full bodied, thick roasty malts, chocolate abundant. A beautiful beer overall.

bottle at home 10Feb11 pours opaque black with a medium brown head.  Aroma is full on roast and bitter cocoa, smells very rich and robust.  Flavor is rich and coats my mouth with loads of burnt sugar, caramel, tootsie rolls and a nutty character that reminds me of hazelnuts.  Nice porter with lots of flavor.

Draft on tap at Sheffields (Chicago, IL). Pours a very dark blackish hue, near opaque with brownish edges that show some light brownish head. Dies to a thicker film, laces well, a bit cakey and frothy. Aromas are light cocoa and bakers chocolate, light roast and toast, toffee, creamy malts with some touches of dry soda bread.  Initial is medium bodied, perhaps a touch lighter. Blends of cocoa, sweet and bitter cocoa, touches of roast, toast, creamy body with a silky smooth finish. Light roast. Toast, lingering toasty bread. Roast and touches of coffee, light roastiness. Simple, roasty and smooth with touches of light hops, cocoa and roast. A solid quaffable Porter. Mellow and decent roast. Balanced.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle at Fireworks. 
Aroma: The nose is lightly roasted malt with a touch of caramel. 
Appearance: It pours a very dark brown with ruby highlights and a foamy tan head.  Great head retention.  
Taste: The flavor is mostly caramel with a little roasted malt and raisin.  A good bit of fruit moves forward as the brew warms.   Fruitier than I expect in a porter but well balanced and good. 
Palate: Medium bodied with average carbonation leading to a slightly dried fruit finish. 
Overall: A bit more body and raisin than I generally like in my porter, but this brew is well done and very sessionable.

12 oz flaske matsort hælde med et forholdsvis lille lyse brunt hoved. 
Aroma af let brændt malt, noter af kaffe. Smagen bære præg af brænd malt og noget tørret frugt. Cremet mundfornemmelse med let restbitterhed.
UPDATED: JUL 1, 2014 Aroma and flavor is dark malts, coffee undertones and an acidic finish.  Just like every Anchor beer, a standard for its style.

Bottle. Pours nice and dark. A white head, moderate lacing. Aromas of chocolate milk, dark chocolate and roasted notes. A bit of underlying licorice as well. Taste is lots of roasted notes at first, followed by a soft chocolate and some coffee. Body was a bit too carbonated, and the flavors were a bit weak, but still a very good porter.
UPDATED: APR 7, 2011 RR 15/3: Bottle. Black with small beige head. Roasty malt aroma with fruit - banana, licorice, coffee, sweet malty and dry taste of fruit and coffee.

Bottle pours deep brown with a khaki head.  Aroma shows notes of roasted malt, chocolate, light coffee, plum, and raisin.  Flavor shows the same with a little extra black cherry and smoke.  Overall body is moderate and soft.

Bottle. Appearance: Deep ruby and brown, almost black with a thick off white head. Aroma: Overripe apples, raisins, good amount of chocolate and a drop of coffee. Flavour: Raisins and chocolate, like a tiffin bar, quite sour too, wine like yet very sweet, quite a complex balance between its sweetness and sourness, tangy coffee finish. Very enjoyable.

The beer pours a very dark brown color with a tan head. A very nice looking porter.

The aroma is heavy on the raisins. but there is also some roasted malt and chocolate mixed in. Besides the raisins, there is some other dark fruit mixed in, including dark cherries. 

The flavor is raisins, dark fruit, grapes and roasted malt. I also get a little bit of anise and some iced tea notes. Very strange, but it all works pretty well together. I have had this beer numerous times and I never remembered it having this flavor profile. There is a little bit of charred malt/smoke at the end of the flavor when the beer warms. 

Medium to thick mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
On tap at Allstars cafe, Bratislava. Almost black color with beige head. Aroma, chocolate, red fruits, spices. Taste, chocolate, later on coffee, roasted malt. Nice bittersweet finish. Great beer.

In the glass is a deep black porter, with a high creamy head.Smells  toffee and bitter coffee. Starts complex malty, very chocolaty roasted malt and bitter, with a pleasant coffee flavor in the background. Its leaving again very chocolaty bitter taste. The further course is dominant and chocolaty coffee-like bitter malty

This one has a salty sea smell that reminds me of a balitc porter. It pours with a pretty good head of larger little bubbles. Quite dark. This has a really good flavour like in homebrew, the layers are at once thick and individual but all play well with one another. It leaves an impression of % and some chewey black malts to savor. Some hops in the end. Actually there is quite a bit of hops there. This is pretty darn good as far as a standard porter goes.

Pours black with a thick beige head. looks great.  strong roasted malt aroma. Smells amazing. lots of chocolate and other roasted malts. NIce flavour very sweet with chocolate molassas, smoke. This is a very nice beer. very complex. I love it.!

Pours jet black with big light brown head. Aromas of roasted malt, dark chocolate. Flavor is malty, coffee, chocolate, and a firm oaky woodiness. Generously hopped. Finish starts off bitter but warms into mocha and coffee  flavors. Medium to full bodied, low carbonation, stout - like.

It pours a insane dark brown with an off small off white head. Mild amount of carbonation present with some small lacing.

On the nose I am getting some roasted malt,molasses,chocolate.

The flavor has a bunch of things going on. I am getting some dry roasted malts,little amount of chocolate. There is some sweetness coming from some toffee and molasses notes. In addition to all of that it has faint coffee lurking around. Having all those different elements going you would think something would go wrong. It seems to blend well together.

It finishes with a smooth creamy ending. Even despite the burnt notes on the finish. This has to be one of the best beers I have had in a long time. So many good things to say and so little time.  Do yourself a favor and grab some ASAP. Anchor brewing always seems to please the palate.

Bottle. Dark brown big head. Massive chocolate and soft roasted, sweet also. So smooth in the mouth again chocolate and dark malt. Maybe just a subtle  alcohol feel, but this beer is delicious! One of the best porters I ve tried.
Strong roasty notes with piney hops in aroma.  Very dark brown with a resilient brown head.  Taste is a little acrid with heavy roasty notes.  Finishes fairly dry.  Medium to full bodied.
Nice creamy head and toasted taste that isnt overbearing. It had a hopiness that was surprising and overall i would have to say this is a Great Porter!

Bottle. Pours a near black colour, with a fluffy dark tan head. Strong smell of molasses, maybe a small chocolate in there. The taste has a strong taste of malt, a large amount of molasses flavor, sweet and rich, this fades to a slight chocolate and finishes with a bitter hop presence and a delicate roastiness. Thick rich mouthfeel, not too heavy.

Pours a deep dark brown with hues of red.  Aroma of roasted grain, cocoa, molasses with a touch of coffee and dried fruit.  Flavor is chocolate, vanilla, dried fruit.  Finish is slightly dry with a touch of bitterness.  Overall, a very nice beer.

Appearance:  very dark brown, with a hint of ruby when held directly against the light; light brown creamy head that persisted, leaving light lacing.  Aroma:  chocolate, caramel and vanilla coffee creamer, dusty leather, with a hint of piney hops.  Taste:  bittersweet dark chocolate, cream, a whisper of hops and green wood.  Finish:  smooth, creamy, dry and mellow, with a hint of bitter dark chocolate and dust the last flavors.  Notes:  Wonderful porter.  Flavors are mild, yet delicious.  Palate is creamy-smooth and mellow.

Pours a deep, dark chestnut brown color that appears pitch black in the glass. Completely opaque with only the slightest f mahogany edges when held to a light source. Two finger frothy, pillowy yellowish-beige head that has excellent retention, only slowly fading into a lasting cap that coats the pint with chunky lacing.

Roasted malt aroma with hints of silky chocolate, toffee, toast, oatmeal in the nose as well as some faint earthy hops. The chocolate presence is very prominent, balancing out the smokey/roastiness quite nicely.

On the fuller end of medium bodied with a lot of roasted and silky chocolate malt flavor. Surprisingly hop forward with a much stronger bitter, earthy pine profile than the aroma suggests. A bit more roasty and dry than I expected with hints of roasted coffee bean, luscious chocolate, burnt toast and oatmeal. There is a slight lactic cream presence mid-palate that adds to the complexity and balance, making this beer pretty quaffable. The maltier flavors open up as it warms but its still a bit too bitter for my liking.
Bottle. Crazy good porter. Color is deep black with a (too) thin tan head. Aromas of dark malts, chocolate primarily. Long finish. WIll definitely have this one again.

Bottle.  Pours nearly black with a thin tan head.  Aroma is chocolate, dried cherries, sweet caramel, a touch of vanilla.  Flavor follows aroma, plus a hint of coffee and smoke.  Starts sweet; ends fairly dry.  Very smooth; almost no bitterness, either from hops or roast.  Medium, somewhat creamy palate.  Definitely not as complex as some other great porters, but its also more balanced and drinkable than most.  Aroma and flavor both open up and get richer as the beer warms.
Surprising malt.  Very tasty.  Bitterness is solid and interesting.  Pretty good for style but somewhat average overall.  Solid.

A: The pour is a dark brown color with a finger of mocha colored head that recedes after a short while.

S: Nose is quite roasty with some bitter dark chocolate notes. Theres a touch of nuttiness along with licorice, toffee, and even a bit of sweetness.

T: Some bitterness up front with plenty of roasted malts, coffee, and bitter dark chocolate. Theres a touch of licorice to go with some dark molasses sort of flavors.

M: The body is medium with a moderate to high level of carbonation.

D: Pretty damn easy to drink and enjoyable porter, here. Id gladly drink this beer again.
Anchor never disappoints.  Pours oily black with a tan off white head.  Arma is roasty malts, caramel and chocolate.  Taste is sweet with a very dry finish.  SLick mouthfeel.

Fekete színű, világosbarna árnyalatú apró habbal a tetején, igazán szép látvány. Illata édeskés, cukros, pörkölt malátás és kávés. Ízében ott a keserű csokoládé, pörkölt maláta, kevés kakaó és kávé, valamint egy enyhébb gyógynövényes, medvecukros aroma. Porter létére eléggé itatja magát, köszönhetően az erősebb komlózottságnak, és nem is annyira testes. Lecsengése száraz és kesernyés, és eléggé hosszan tartó, jellegzetes utóíze van. A legjobb döntés lehet akkor, mikor megkívánjuk az általa kínált ízvilágot, de nem akarunk komolyabb italozásba kezdeni. Finom!

12 oz bottle.  Pours an almost opaque black color with a small amount of tan head.  The head dissipates quickly but there is a fair amount of lacing.  Aroma is not as strong as one would expect.  Aroma is mostly of roasted malts with some fruitiness.  Flavor is mostly malty with some hints of chocolate and coffee.  Some sweetness at the beginning.  The finish is slightly bitter as some hops character emerges.  Body is medium with minimal carbonation.  This is a good beer and is drinkable and a probable repurchase.  What sets it back is that it is a bit too simple for my tastes.  It doesnt quite have the complexity of flavor I want in an elite porter.  Its missing that extra kick.  Definitely well balanced.

A: snifter. deep rich brown, almost black color. light tan head with a medium retention level. fair lacing.

S: roasted malts. some caramel and chocolate aromas, with a light sour note as well.

T: a little sour, could be an old beer. some sweet roasted malts, mostly a chocolate flavor. I am also picking up some tobacco flavors.

M: smooth and creamy. mild carbonation. not heavy at all for a porter.

D: very drinkable. A good representation of style, but I think I need a fresher bottle next time.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2010 12 oz. bottle.

Aroma - fruity, dark malt, with a wee bit of hops in the background. Smells British.
Appearance - Black with a tiny bit of blood red in the center. Bubbly white foam head than retreats to the sides of the glass.
Taste - A lot of the fruitiness found in a British porter up front. The middle is where the dark malt sweetness comes in. Bittersweet chocolate flavors for sure. Finishes roasty with a slight sour tartness.
Palate - medium bodied with a very appropriate light carbonation.
Overall - one of my favorite porters. Definitely more a nod to the British side of the style, but with a definite American slant. Amazing porter!
Pours black with thick creamy head and foamy lacing.  Notes of coffee and chocolate with a hint of vanilla.  Sour off-taste that clings to the back of the throat spoils the experience.
Bottle. Pours brown-black with a big tan head. Flavor is chocolate/coffee with light hops and some caramel. Very drinkable. Great simple beer.

355 mL bottle from Beers of Europe.  Bit of a gusher.  Smells like a proper porter.  Bit of an uneven head, but thats probably due to the way I poured it.  Has character, and is readily drinkable.  However its not anything special, just does the simple porter thing well.  Its very smooth, and well worth a taste.

Bottle from Systembolaget. Aroma hints of roasted coffee and caramel. Appearance is black with a thick creamy foam that settles slowly. Taste is a little bit sour on the onset, then a little sweet followed by some bitterness at the end. There are notes of coffee and caramel in the taste as well. Very good beer overall, one of the best porters I have tried.
An enjoyable, if somewhat unspectacular, easy drinking porter, that went down well on its own on a winters night.
UPDATED: JAN 10, 2011 Black beer with nice brown head.Roasted malts,light dark fruits,light smoked,chocolate,coffee,dry,hops bitter.Nice balance.

12 oz. bottle at The Royale.  Batch 08M.  Pours a dark brown color with a huge tan head that leaves some lace in the glass.  Aroma of chocolate malts, earth, leafy hops, and toast.  Also a little funk in the nose.  Flavor of chocolate malts, coffee, roast, earth, and sweet bread.  Medium bodied, with soft carbonation and a smooth, chocolaty mouthfeel.  Nice, simple porter.

Notes from Wednesday, August 11 2010
12 oz. bottle from HyVee Marion

Ar: The aroma seems a bit deadened to me, but whats here is pretty nice (roasted coffee).
Ap: This is a really pretty beer.  Pours a deep black with just a hint of red shining through when held to the light.  1" cinnamon head of tightly knit bubbles lasts long enough to enjoy.
T: Of course the big roast coffee note is present, but there are some black licorice and chocolate undertones that are quite nice.
P: The creamy head adds a nice texture to this beer.  Moderately thick body.

O: This is a really good porter.  Definitely worth the $10 per sixer it retails for around here.

Bottle served in shaker- poured a dark brown color with tints of black and dark maroon, light carbonation, half finger off tan head formed which laced to an extent.  Aroma of dark toasted malt with notes of chocolate, coffee, and freshly baked rye bread- very nice.  Hits the mouth with a wide medium body, malt comes across as roasted heartily, some light brown sugar in the middle, finish is creamy, sticky, and lasting.  If you dont like this beer, get the hell out of here.

Bottle. Pours dark ruby with a foamy tan head. Aroma has notes of chocolate, coffee and licorice. Flavour  is roasted malts, licorice, chocolate and some coffee. It ends in a little bitterness. A very nice porter

Draft at Euston Tap. Pours dark brown with a thick, beige head. Brown sugar and caramel malts in the nose. Fairly sweet flavor, lots of dark malts, slight minerality, plenty more caramel and brown sugar, along with light, earthy bitters. Medium bodied with fine to average carbonation. The finish is sweet, faintly roasty, with lightly sticky hops, mild mocha. Pretty excellent overall.
Nutty, broody beer. Its a very smooth brew with a burnt carmel finish.  I find myself wishing it was a little colder right now because it has the makings of a great winter beer.

Bottle, 355 ml. Pours darkbrown, almost black colour with a thick, beige head. Aroma  of roasted malt, liquorice and even some coffee. Flavour of roasted malts and some sweetness of chocolate and hints of coffee. This one was delicious.
I love drinking this one. I put on my Mr.Plow jacket, pet Santas Little Halper, then I race downstairs to have another Anchor Porter.

Bottle @ Henriks Bergen. Pours rich black body with a soft - almost creamy head. Good lively carbonation. Nose is liquorish and some what chocolate. Tastes sweet liquorish and leathery - nice and creamy with a soft bitter and sweet ending. A good porter.

Full, lush, creamy, cream colored head.  Color is almost pitch black.  Just the faintest dark red, ruby highlights around the edges.  This brew looks outstanding.  The head is really sticking around and it leaves a copious amount of lacing.  A rich chocolate and coffee malt come to the forefront of the nose.  The smell is also evoking a roasted and smokey flavor that is very delightful.  The taste is very similar to the smell by recalling the chocolate and coffee.  Not overly sweet, but just enough sweetness for a teasing.  The smokey flavor adds appeal by appearing in a delicate way in the end.  Medium to full mouthfeel.  Chewy and very smooth.  Creamy.  The coating of the tongue and throat are very satisfying as they linger for a long while.  I really, really, really like this brew.  I havent had a tremendous amount of Porters in my life, but this one has to be at the top of my list of ones I have had thus far.  Perfect for those late Autumn/Winter days and evenings.  Easily drinkable.  This is a beer that I will have to visit every year at some point or another.  Thanks Anchor...... for brewing it.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2011 Bottle.  Has a light aroma, smells of chocolate and a hint of raisins.  Taste is pretty damn good!  Has a roasted malt taste to it, along with chocolate/caramel/coffee.  The finish is slightly bitter and sort of muted - wish it had a more robust, roasted finish to balance it out.  As it is, its a light-medium mouthfeel with maybe a little bit too much sweetness.  5.6% alcohol.

Black with red hints. Nice mocca head. Looks really nice. Hoppy aroma but also burnt malts, dark fruits like plum and wine. Theres actually quite a lot of plum and grapes in the taste. Mouthfeel is smooth and nice. Nice beer! Easy going but nice!

12 oz bottle into English pint. I cant believe I havent rated this yet; its always been one of my favorites. Pours an almost impervious black with reddish tints showing up when held up to a light. Has a nice long retaining tan head that leaves exceptional lace. Aroma is very English compared to most American porters. Smells like a bakery: freshly baked cookies and bread especially; cocoa, cinnamon. Taste is both tart and sweet with some  bitterness coming up in the finish. Tastes somewhat old. If Im reading the code right, this was brewed in September of 2009. So it is past its prime, which is a damn shame, because I remember this being a very delicious, distinctive beer. Its still good, but that old taste is definitely bringing the score down. Ill definitely rerank it as soon as a fresher bottle becomes available. Carbonation is low to medium, body is medium, texture is a little chalky. This beer deserves better, so maybe I fudged a little on the scores. I repeat: a re-rate is in order and will be done as soon as some fresh stuff comes in.

Bottle. Pitch black pour with a medium tan head. The aroma is ashy, chocolate, roasted malt and sweet tobacco. To the sweet side. Rich tobacco flavour with notes of chocolate, roasted malt, caramel and has bitter chocolate like finish. Nice.

Bottle at Cardinals Porter Symposium. Clear deep ruby with a finger thick, creamy light brown head. Light bodied and dry. the roasted notes are properly present in mouth and on the nose along with dried fruits especially prunes. Sweet, acidic and bitter. A well balanced porter.

Bottle 33cl. A dark beer with low head. Smell is malty and roasted. Aroma is a sweet caramel and roasted malt style beer, medium creamy, good roast flavor with nice chocolate and sweet notes. Some fruit hints at the finish, a goos porter a bit heavy but pleasant.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2010 Bottle.

A - Dark garnet color with a large, foamy, thick, creamy tan head. Good retention that sticks around for awhile. Leaves a nice layer of lace.

S - Sweet malt with cocoa and some anise (along with some raisin) aroma gives it a chocolaty and tart aroma. Slightly roasted malt with some caramel. Could be a little stronger, but pretty good.

T - Similar to the nose with chocolate, some anise, and some raisin come out along with the roasted, sweet, caramel malt. Some earthy and nutty flavors come out along with a touch of spiciness. Hints of coffee, but fairly faint. Very nice mix of flavors and pretty well balanced.

M - Fuller side of medium body with a good level of carbonation. Pretty smooth and creamy. Just gets a touch of a drying feel at the end.

D - Very easy to drink porter with a nice mix of flavors that is well balanced. Keeps me wanting to drink more.

Notes: A very nice porter with mixes of cocoa, anise, raisin, nutty, earthy, and caramel malt flavors. Sweet, tart, spicy, and roasted tones all come in and out. Might not be world class, but a great beer for a good price. Recommend picking one up.

Pours a dark brown color with an off-white soapy head.  Has an aroma of caramel and bread with hints of roast.  Sweet roasty taste with nice chocolate notes on the finish.  Notes of caramel throughout.  Excellent.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2011 Nagyon kedvemre való sör ez annak ellenére, hogy fekete. Kellemes, nem tolakodó illat ami kávé, föld, hamu, és csoki harmonikus keverékeként tudnám definiálni.
Az ízek szintén hasonlóak és kiegyensúlyozottak. Meg fogom szeretni a nedüt! Szép középbarna hab, fekete szín. Még-még belőle.
Tudnak a yenkik.
26th April 2006  Warning! Early amateur rating! Sharp start - noticeably banana! Finishes smoky, bitter and dry. Gets better with peserverence. Bitter chocolate and coffee. Still getting better...

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2011 Bottle. Black with a large light brown head. Aroma: wine gums, blackcurrants, chocolate. Taste: Sweet licorice, wine gums, berries, just a bit of milk chocolate, rather sweet, slightly acidic. Full and creamy mouthfeel, pretty stouty in character.

Bottle. Pours an opaque dark brown with a fine-grained cappucino head. Smells somewhat dry and austere for a porter; spice and roast is about it. Palate is rich and roasty, but the dryness remains; espresso and rye notes predominate. Mouthfeel is clean, crisp, and elegant. Good.

Bottle. Dark brown pour with a rich tan head that dissipates slowly. Aroma is sweet malt and brown sugar with some cinnimon too. Taste is smooth and sweet malt with spices and some melow hops and dried fruit as well. Palate is chaulky fizzy and dry. Very well put together porter!

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2015 A personal favorite beer. Im ashamed to admit I havent had a sip of it in at least a year, probably more like 2 years, and it could be closer to 3 years!

10/15/10: Not anymore, drinking some tonight!

9/9/2015: And again!!

motor oil color with disappearing creamy head, aroma of raisin, caramel, bread with minimal carbonation; nice mouthfeel, sweet taste, could use a little more alcohol and hops but very enjoyable indeed
Bottle: Pours almost black, with a pillow of tan to brown head. Roasted malt aroma, with some chocolate on the finish.  A nice porter.
Dark frothy head that looks like a ice cream float and lasted a while. Nice cascade. Nutty aroma. I notice a bitter malty flavor. This is a really good beer.

(bottle)  The Keg_Juggler pick of the week.  I think this would be a good sample of the style, except I just finished a superior example in Long Trails Imperial Porter.  This porter is milky, well roasted and rich.  Malt forward in style and slightly watery.  Very nice, but I must hold back from the cumulative accolades received.
Bottle @ home. Deep black pour, medium lightly brown head. Aroma is strong roasted malt. Flavour is light dry bitterness, hint of sweetness, hint of smoke. Nice but a bit boring.

Dark colour with a low brown foam. 

On the nose there is some milkchocolate, bread and overall a nice chocolate malt flavour.

This beer is really well balanced, perfect between sweetnes and bitternes. Good brewing!
There is almost a breadflavour to it, with topnotes of the floral kind.

12 oz bottle. Pours dark as expected. Thin tan head. Aroma of dark, dried stone fruit. Bit of chocolate. Malty sweetness. Caramel. Taste is a fruity malt up front, giving way to the caramel. No real roast. Bit of twang. Good, viscous mouthfeel. I know this one is a classic, but not for me. Not what Im looking for out of ny porters.

Bottle from Systembolaget. Opaque dark brown beer, beige head. Roasted malts, coffee and dark chocolate on the nose. Taste is quite dry with slight bitterness, roasted malts and chocolaty end. Nice porter indeed!

Sample at Fête bière et saveur Chambly.
Appearance : Pitch black with a medium creamy head.

Aroma : Roasted malt with butterscotch and a bit of caramel. A bit hoppy.

Taste : Light roasted malt with butterscotch and caramel. A bit fruity.Finish is sharp and dry. Light bitterness. Slightly mineral.

Overall : Drinkable and refreshing. Nice everyday porter.

Pours a black brown with creamy head. Aroma is chocolate, caramel, other dark malt aromas Flavor is has a nice roasted malt character with the perfect amount of balancing hops that come through surprisingly well. Creamy mouthfeel and finish

355 ml bottle @ Olutravintola Pannuhuone. Rated @ 29.8.2009.
Pours a black colour with a brown head. Roasted malts on the nose, which dominate the flavour too. Coffee and mild hop notes. Thin mouthfeel and decent carbonation. Average porter.

Bottle.  Poured a deep cola brown color with ruby highlights and a thick, dense tan head that slowly recede and left some thick spotty lacing.  Aroma of chocolate, light roast, coffee, and a soft dark fruitiness (light plum).  Smooth, sweet entry with some chocolate and a light fruitiness that leads into a moderate roastiness with more hints of sweet fruit (plum) that give way to an espresso-like coffee character that lingers into the finish where it pairs with a faint, lightly hoppy bitterness.  Low carbonation and smooth, slick mouth feel.  Overall, a very drinkable beer that does a nice job balancing flavor and weight on the palate.

Poured quick and left a nice lingering tan head. Not black but very brown with red highlights when held to the light. Nose is sweet with a caramelly backing supported by prunes, raisins, light roast, and maybe some hops but is light. Taste is balanced between some light malts, caramel and roasts. Kinda light bodied and is finishes fast and clean. Light bitterness shows. Not bad but not my favorite. easy drinker.

12oz bottle pours an opaque brown body with a bubbly tan head.  The aroma is outstanding, mostly sweet caramel and chocolate malt.  The flavor is not as sweet as the aroma would have you think, though it certainly plays its part (though, I think its mostly coming through the nose).  Theres a hoppiness in the flavor, which is very welcome, but the standout component is the coffee-like roast and bitterness.  All of these components play incredibly well together to form an amazing brew.  One of my favorites, definitely.

Pours a deep red with a lasting head. Maybe some caramel, dark malts, wants me to dive in. The beer leaves a taste with me that just makes me want more and more, perhaps Ive found a new go to session? Im tasting a bit of coffee maybe... overall delicious.
UPDATED: FEB 16, 2015 Most excellent stuff. Quite rich and flavorful. Plenty of mouth feel but lets up just the right amount. Very drinkable. Serving: Bottle

Pours  a deep dark mahogany with a long lasting tan head. Nose is roasted malts, caramel. Taste is roasted malt, sweet caramel some hints of roasted esspresso and some bitterness. Palate is full body, thick texture, with good carbonation. Finish is bitter sweet caramel malts, with some roasted esspresso. Overall a well balanced and tasty brew.
Great caramel malt sweetness, terrific body, and nice cloudy dark toffee color.  One of the best porters Ive had in a long time-wish it was more widely available.

Poured black with an extremely thick tan head that didnt dissolve, but folded in on itself.  Body is smooth and not too heavy.  Has hints of coffee and lots of roasted grain.  I cant say Ive had a better porter.

Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a pint glass.

A: Pours dark brown with a great looking 1.5" creamy, tan head. Retention was decent and lasted about a quarter of the way through. 

S: A nice balance of coffee and roasted chocolate with a hint of sweetness. 

T: Great balance of bitterness with sweetness from the dark fruit taste. Not too rich with just the right flavor for a good American porter.

M/D: It goes down nice and smooth. With plenty of complex flavors, and low ABV, I could definitely drink a few of these in one sitting.

I love this porter because its available locally here in MS where there arent many good beers to choose from due to the ABV limits. This has become my go to beer for quality and availability

Bottle.  Pours an almost-black opaque dark brown with a beige head.  Aroma is smokey dark roasted malts, some bitter coffee.  Taste is somewhat sweet to begin with smoke, roasty/burnt malts, coffee and chocolate.  Ends nicely bitter.  Great porter.

Bottled (too small bottle). It is almost  black, little and firm brown head. Roasted nose. Aroma is roasted malts with coffee hints. Flavour is malt, dark chocolate with liqourice. Finishes the same, the long lasting aftertaste makes it perfect for slow snipping. One of the best beers I ever had!

Really dark brown color with a cappuccino colored head. Rich, sweet but fresh aroma of licorice, pumpernickel, dark chocolate, coffee liqueur and even peppermint. Taste of licorice, burnt wood, herbs and a bit of tar. Quite sweet but leaves your mouth with a dry feeling after swallowing. A beer for a true sailorman.

A-pours a black liquid with brown edges, a khaki colred head that leaves a filmy lace.

S-light note of caramel and toffe, hints of chocolate and molasses, tons of malt sweetness, plums, figs, black cherries and a hint of alcohol.

T-notes of toffee, burnt coffee, black malt, dark chocolate.  these flavors are subtle up front, tons of malt sweetness, plums, figs, black cherries, lightly bitter finish.

M-this is soft on the palate with a grainy feel to it.  well carbonated with a crisp finish and slightly astringent.

D-this packs in huge flavors, lots of malt sweetness with a dark malt balance.  good feel to it, very drinkable and tasty.

Nicely enough getting to try this in Belgrade via Rare Beers in Budapest. 12oz bottle pours warm and thick, with a cream just-tan head. Nose is robust and sweet, warming and rosy. Smoke and roast are very much at the back, just whiffs, under a much warming dark malting and hoppiness. Incredibly smooth and welcoming mouthfeel that finishes a touch dry and bitter. A bit sweet in the end, Id personally prefer something a little stronger to balance, but this is a worthy of a winter mug. Very nice.

Bottle. A dark brown/black coloured pour with a medium beige head on top. Roasty, coffee aroma. Tastes quite smooth, malty, coffee, chocolate, dark fruit, roasty. A really complex porter for such a low strength.

Bottle, 12 fl oz. Black with light brown head. Slight aroma is of burnt malt. Lots of carbonation (all natural, states the bottle) initially . Slight sweet taste. Flavour of bitter chocolate and burnt malts. Dry finish. Good stuff, plenty going on for just 5.6%.

This one really shows the vast range of what you can call a "porter".  Pours a deep, deep, deep reddish brown with significant head.  Startling and bold flavours here - chocolate big time - I often use chocolate as a descriptor when things sort of taste like chocolate...but this was flat out chocolate.  And unmistakable cherry.  Almost a cherry cola taste to it.  Only 5.6% alcohol but it was present enough to give a nice warming effect.  Very low on the drinkability scale.  It makes you think, this one!
Aroma of caramel and roast. Dark brown with thin head.  Heavy caramel more than chocalate and past.  Bottle better.

Bottle from "Csakajósör"-store, Bp.
Pours a ruby dark brown with a nice, creamy and beige coloured head which collapses slowly.
Smell of fruits, coffee and toffee.
It begins malty, chocolate/liquorice flavoured, escorted by fruity notes, mouthfeels slick.
The middle part is roasty with hoppyness in the back, the finish is chocolate-bitter, light alcoholy noted and dry, which remain in a coffe/liquorice-liked aftertaste.
Very nice and complex.

$10 sixer - Ive waited too long to try this one.  Anchor Porter is the real deal.  Nice chocolate and toffee notes.  Silky smooth texture and nice to look at.  Moderate carbonation.  Good value and would buy again.

12 oz. bottle

Poured a very dark brown, almost black with a small creamy had that dissipated quickly. Distinct lacing. So dark, it looks like cola in the glass.

Smell is quite sweet surprisingly with a nice cocoa/coffee hint. Also had a hint of a red wine smell which was quite unusual.

Taste is chocolatey with a hint of wine as well. Very unique. Nice bitter finish.

Mouthfeel was quite smooth and enjoyable.

Drinkability was quite high. Nothing too filling which surprised me a bit for how dark this porter was.

Overall, this was a great porter. Anchor puts out another excellent product and I would highly recommend it.

One of the most interesting north american porters Ive ever had.  One the one hand, you get the coffee/cacao robustness you expect, along with a refreshing hit of bitterness.  The surprising and quite pleasing aspect that made this memorable was just how much flavor and texture this ale has while being so light on body and weight.  I highly recommend all of the Anchor beers, but this one is the most interesting to me.

Csak a jó sör
Olyan fekete színe van mint a mint a frissen kevert és kiöntött kátránynak. A kitöltéskor rajta keletkező hab kemény, sűrű és szép világosbarna és elég kitartó is.Illata édeskéd, égetett cukros és gyógyfüves. Ízében erősen érezni az ürmöt, szurokfüvet, fekete borsot, egy kis kávét és barna cukrot. Aztán jön a fekete csoki és egy derék adag komló. Ahogy hagyjuk melegedni és úgy kóstolgatjuk, minden kortynál jön valami kis újdonság. Kellemesen kerek teste van és pont megfelelően élénk, szénsavas. Utóíze kissé földes, száraz és a legvége olyan mintha egy minőségi belga keserű csokit ettünk volna és igen hosszan tart. Remek porter, ami nem a mindennapokra, hanem inkább különleges alkalmakra való.

Bottle, Csakajosor.hu. Poured with deep-ruby, almost black color and a beige head that reduced to a fine coating on top. Strong roasted aroma with hints of chocolate, coffee, plum, licorice, and hops. Smooth texture with enough carbonation, this beer is easy on the palate, pleasant. Sweet, sticky finish with some roasted and bitter aftertaste. Good!

Poured a 12oz bottle into a Sam Adams senosry glass.

Dark maroon/opague color. Head is a nice fluffy tan color. Lace is pretty good.

Aroma is of chocolate and roasted honey nut. Taste is of honey and roasted sweetness carmel.

Mouthfeel is very smooth and the alcohol becomes present at the end.

Overall, this is an excellent porter. Great to the style, a nice honey and carmel taste makes this a great brew!

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-27-2008 07:53:16

35.5cl bottle from Systembolaget. Best before June 2010. No batch info. It poured a pitch black colour with a huge off-white creamy head. Aroma is malty with lots of caramel and roasted nuts. Hints of roasted coffee as well. The flavour is smooth. Lots of malts, barley, caramel and roasted coffee again. Some dark berries as well. Short aftertaste.

Dark brown with a tiny bit of ruby around the edges, soft tan head that grips the glass.  Medium roastyness with a cocoa coffee edge, with a slightly noticable hop bitterness.  Med-light bodied and very smooth.  Overall a rich yet balanced, drinkable yet very tasty, even complex.

Bottled @ Draft House, Northcote Rd. SW11. Pours almost black in colour with light tan head. Roasted malt aroma. Roasted malt, coffee taste with a bitter finish. Light mouth feel with fizzy carbonation. Bitter finish. Not my favourite porter.

Bottle. Pours a very dark ruby red color, that almost looks black. The head is frothy and tan/brown with alot of big bubbles. Aroma is mostly of roasted malt, along with some grains, coffee and a slight amount of dark fruit. Flavor is of roasted malt, slight amount of coffee and chocolate, toasted bread and dark fruit. I also get some tart fruitiness along with some hops. Body is medium and slightly creamy. Overall a good porter, that reminds me a little of the Samuel Smith Taddy Porter.
Black body, tanned head. Mämmi, chocolate, sweet malt and hops clearly in aroma. Balanced bitterness, thin body.
What a beer! Im lacking any real tasting notes on this as it has been a while since Ive tried it.  I just remember thinking to myself that this was one of the best beers ive ever had on tap.
A decent offering, well worth the money and id definitely get it again. Just didnt knock my socks off. a very solid porter

355ml bottle.  Pours pitch black with a creamy/beige head.  Aroma is berries, raisin and malt.  Taste is of some chocolate and with a bitter finish.  Low carbonation and a bit oily on the palate.  Quite a good porter, but Ive had better ones.

Bottle. Very nice porter. Pours pitch black with a good beige head. Some lacing on the glass. Strong aroma with hints of coffee, some sweet notes and roasted hints. Taste was really nice with a lot of malts, some coffee, chocolate and bitter hops. Pleasant aftertaste which stays there for a while. Full, smooth bodied and a real treat.
Butterscotch, raisins, and plastic aroma. Black, thin tan head. Plastic raisin flavor. Chemical finish. Something is very odd about this beer. It tastes unnatural, artificial.

leather, dough, resin, herbs, roasty, nuts, chocolate, coffee, smoke, woody
heavy, creamy head and a note of port in the very end

Tasted: 2010 Calgary Beerfest. Thick black colour. Nose: Rather weak, some dark malt. Taste: Entrance of a caramel and toffee swirl. Oven roasted potatoes (with seasoned salt) take over. Thick coffee finish. An unusual sweet-to-salt profile.

Ahh, a fine porter. Black body with a nice, lasting tan head. Full bodied and smooth. Taste of bitter hops with strong coffee notes with a bit of vanilla and chocolate. Bitter, lasting finish. Excellent!

Sampled from a 12 ounce bottle. With a thick tan head upon pouring, has a strong roasted scent. Very very dark brown, almost black, even when held up to light. Medium body, average carbonation. Has a small undercurrent of bitter hops throughout, but becomes more evident and turns to creamy in the finish. Overall an excellent beer.

Appearance: Poured an almost pitch-black color with a fingerwide tanned, creamy head.

Aroma: Moderately dry coffeish scent with a subtle gainy feel.

Flavor: Bland roasted malty dryness with a strong coffeish nature fills the whole palate. A smooth creamy vanilla feel at the medium gently fades to a bold roasted coffee finish.

Mouthfeel/Palate: Easy to medium body with a smooth, oily palate.

Overall: Memorable, tasty, porter from Anchor B.C Not the type of brew that i crave after in a hot summer day, but still more than decent.
I am enjoying this beer a lot.  Aroma is coco and coffee.  Appearance is black with about two fingers of tan head.  Taste is coffee and roast.  Palate is very smooth and full bodied.

Pours black with a small tan head. The aroma is sweet and roasty. Chocolate, coffee, spice, and brown sugar on the nose. The flavor is similar to the nose... Chocolate, coffee, spice and brown sugar. I was wishing the whole time there was a little more mineralliness on more bitterness to offset the sweetness. Not bad, just not great.
A deep black body with a frothy head. A little bit more bitterness than I like......

12 oz brown bottle. Pours deep brown/black, head is tan and creamy, displays good lacing.  Aroma is dominated by dark fruits with subtle notes of roast chocolate and coffee.  Taste is smoke, chocolate covered cherries and malt. Finish is lightly burnt wood.  Not quite what I would like to drink all the time, but occasionally.

Drank this right out of the cellar with no fridgework. Poured out a black brew on a smooth pour giving a frothy dark brown cap with excellent retention and messy lacing. Chocolate, daaark roast, hint of milk, figs early on - those fade to a light fruit, caramel, vanilla, fainter smoke - that equals an appealing aroma! Taste wise this rules. I cannot count how many I will drink in the months to come. Chocolate, deep roast, plums, caramel, good mild and short lived bitterness found during every tasty sip, smoke, ample dark citrus stuff, vanilla. The chocolate taste isnt a face full of chocolate but there is a lasting impression as the flavours all seem to compliment eachother. Smooth and lightly carbonated make this pretty damn good drinkin. Deep roast and caramel rule the aftertaste with a smidgen of charcoal.
Nice creamy head. Aromas of coffee an burnt caramel. Taste is smooth...maybe too much. Still a nice little beer altought rather conventional.

pours a dark dark brown with a decent sized tan head that has good retention... aroma is dominated by dark fruits with subtle notes of roast choc and coffee... lively body, also too lively for my liking, some tart notes initially, minimal choc notes, but roast and coffee notes are present followed by a good deal of dark fruits... medium to almost medium thin body... much more british in nature than the new wave of american porters...

Poursa dark brown with ruby edges and a thick frothy creamy looking tan head. Aroma of dark malts, mild cocoa, cream, raisin. Taste has lots of thick roasted malt with some hop citrus and a milky creamy texture. Some citrus and dark chocolate on the finish. Medium thick body, soft carbonation.

Bottle from a Food Lion in Atlantic Beach... for some reason, we cant get this at any of the fine beer stores in Durham.  Pours rich, dark brown with lovely beige head... smooth and creamy.  Nose of chocolate and mild roastSimilar taste, but creamier and with malted milk ball and and hops showing.  Light but smooth and lively palate.  Quite good.
Now this is a very nice beer. It is roasted, but has some light but detectable, and welcome, fruity flavours as well. Smooth finish, a bit of a light body. Great and refreshing.

12oz pour.  Very dark, almost black in color with a tan colored 1.5" head.  Aroma of malts including chocolate and coffee.  Taste was a little carbonated for my liking and just not a ton of malt flavor bursting out like other porters have.   All in all a good decent porter but not one to go out of my way for.

355ml brown bottle. Pours deep brown/black, head is tan and creamy, displays good lacing. Chocolately malt nose. Flavour is also chocolately, roasty, hint of licorice in the finish with some hop notes, some lasting bitterness. Dry. Smooth body, mild carbonation, good drinkability. Been waiting quite a few years to see this here and Im glad its finally here.
caramel, coffee, roasty, banana, earthy, woody, smoke, black, cloudy, minimal head, light sweetness, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, full body, thick feel, soft carbonation,
Pours a very nice black with fingernail length tan head. Nose is bakers chocolate and lightly smoked wood. Taste is much the same. A little crisp. Rated 6/29/02
UPDATED: DEC 17, 2014 A very quality Porter .  Made a pretty fucken solkid black and tan using this and PUNK IPA yesterday .
Dark black pour from bottle.  Nose is light smoke and chocolate.  Taste is smoke, chocolate covered cherries and malt.  Finish is lightly burnt wood.  Fantastic!
Rich chocolate, roasted malt aroma. Flavors of chocolate, rum cake, roasted salted nuts, and a splash of smoke. Full, well rounded beer. A top one for sure.

Ebony color with a foamy egg shell, almost tan, head.  The head thins down after a few minutes but leaves a film on the top of the beer and laces well on the glass.  Nose is sweet caramel, burnt sugar, and charcoal.  Full bodied taste, very roasty with a subtle bitterness.  Slightly boozy.  Great palate -- very full for a porter and the roast flavor lingers long.  Really a great beer and an excellent representative for the style.
From a pint bottle,Black,white head,Chocolate and coffee taste,great porter especially for the price.

33 cl Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a nice tan head on top. Aroma is full of malt. Smelling also hints of vanilla, nuts, and fruit. Flavor is very rich. Also hints of vanilla and even toffee in the flavor of the beer. Hops are in there also to help balance the beer out, keeping it medium bodied and not sweet.

12oz bottle, purchased from Whole Foods? Pours a deep, dark brown color; significant, foamy, textured, small-bubbled light-tan head with great retention and lacing; gorgeous pour on this. Hugely charismatic malt character in the aroma, but also a minimal yeast fruitiness that suggests very low, lager-like fermentations (that seems on par for Anchor, though I dont know all that much about their brewing techniques across their entire lineup): creamy nougat, toffee, non-bitter chocolate, and caramel, with a significant melanoidin contribution, it seems, with a very light hop presence and a very clean yeast character; clean, well-developed maltiness, and a touch of dark fruits in the nose. Medium to medium-full body; average levels of carbonation; creamy, and entirely non-astringent despite the heavy contributions from darker specialty malts; very smooth in the mouth; there is a significant bittering quality here, suggestive of minerals and mint that hints at the Northern Brewer hops used in Anchor Steam: not resiny or dank, but pleasantly expressed; following the nose, the maltiness is lovely and well-grown: toffee, caramel, and a melanoidin bock-like presence, coupled to the darker chocolate (non-bitter) and very light roasted qualities; the yeast is generally clean, perhaps contributing a touch of red apple, but again I think low fermentation temps. really keep the yeast contributions in check; overall, a creamy, impressively rich porter that I greatly enjoy but doesnt (ultimately) take me to that 4.0+ range; but lovely anyway. Id love to know more about their mashing and fermentation practices. Lasting finish of caramel, non-bitter chocolate, toffee, a touch of mint.

Bottle (355ml) from Vinmonopolet, Oslo. BB Aug 2011. Two-inch beige head, leaving some lacing. Very dark brown colour with a faint red hue. Meaty licorice/chocolate roasted malt aroma with some smoke, tar and coffee. Also a bit fruity. Medium-bodied, average carbonation. The sweetness is excellently balanced by a dry hop bitterness which lingers.
355 ml bottle. Dark brown body with tan head. Flavour is roasted malt, smoke and coffee.
Nice pour - Pitch black with a light brown head. Taste is smooth and chocolatey. Aroma is of coffee and roasted cereals.

Appearance: Big light brown head, brown/black colour.
Aroma: Dark malts, hops, subtle but enjoyable
Flavour: Distinct bitterness, roasted, rich layered and well balanced
Mouthfeel: Average
Total: This is real craftsmanship.

Bottle, home.  Excellent porter, one of my favorite hometown beers.  Anchor Porter pours a very dark shade of brownish ruby, nice highlights in the light, transparent but for the color.  The head is big and creamy.  The aroma is a mix of chocolate, coffee, roast, plums, molasses, mild booze, some porter ashiness, dates, blackberries, toasted granola.  The flavor is smooth and rich.  Its intense for the abv with a lot of roast, dark fruits and brown sugar/molasses/caramel.  The hops give just enough bite to reign things in.  Its one of the best porters around, in my opinion, and its relatively cheap and well-distributed - a testament to Anchors success.

Pours a nice tar black body with a thin off-white top. Smell is cough syrup, mild licorice notes and an unidentified species of American hops I dont really like at all. Well, here goes the sip. As I imagined. Anchor uses this same kind of hop for their Christmas Ale, and for that very reason I detest this seasonal from Anchor. In this porter, it is more hidden and blended into the usual coffee and licorice, but nevertheless present enough for me to repel. Only to a certain extent, though; Anchor Porter has a decent mouthfeel and is fairly drinkable. I guess I just cant handle that particular kind of hop. Gotta find out what it is.
black pour with moderate tan head.  Pleasant aroma of nuts and sweet fruit. thick and malty with taste of dark chocolate.  Mild bitterness

A: dark with chocolate-colored edges. Pour created a large creamy, coffee-colored head which settled quickly, leaving a lasting lace.

S: sweet molasses/caramel and fruit with faint alcohol tinge.

T: Starts smooth and sweet with flavors of toffee, caramel and molasses. Malts and fruit predominate until the hops and carbonation take over. 

D: I have had this a LOT and its priced reasonably for a left coast offering,

Pours black with a great fluffy tan head. Aroma-toasted nuts, brown sugar, malty, earthy. Taste-roasted malt, dust, nutty, hints of chocolate and vanilla. Finishes medium bodied, oily, bit of alcohol. Very rich, awesome porter.
Sweet fruit malt aroma. Very very dark amber color with a small white head, Short sweet beginning with a malty bitter finish.
Tap. Rich mahogany pour. Aroma of prunes, chocolate, and alcohol. Oily mouthfeel. Tastes like it smells. Really nice beer.

On tap at the Cambria Pines Lodge during the family get away.  Nice and dark with a solid tand head that left gooey lace.  Nose roast malt and nutty.  Taste light bitter and yeast.  Malt ball chocolate peeking out.  Ive definitely tasted worse porters.

12 oz bottle pours dark brown with hints of ruby in the light.  Nice tan head that fades quickly but has beautiful lacing.  Caramel and coffee dominate the aroma.  Nice light sweetness with a mild bitter chocolate finish.  Very light carbonation with a little slick, oily mouthfeel.  Otherwise, a fantastic example of the style.
UPDATED: FEB 21, 2015 Pours black, creamy head, Drank while on the DTF California Tasting, A porter that gets the respect it deserves. Love the vanilla, coffee, and chocolate combo.

Pours a beautiful black with a generous creamy head.
The aroma is of roasted malts and coffee. I taste medium sweetness and light bitterness. 
  It has a medium body with a nice creamy texture.

To find this in a $.99  bargain bin was astounding. To reflect back that I only bought one was... I will go back Sunday to rescue all the other  Anchor beers. I regress.  Dark pour with a dark tan head. Aroma of roasted malt and sweet malt. Taste is roasted malt, low carbonation. Very tasty beer. Alcohol aroma more noticeable as it warms. Nice lacing. I really like the fact that I have less competition to buy great beers. I.E. The shop I go to still has Nemesis on the shelves.
Dark with nice crema. Aroma from chocolate, coffee, roasted, soy, smoke. Taste bittersweet chocolate, coffee. Body full, texture smooth, carb average. Finish light bitter.

Pours like a good porter, coffee black body, thick, healthy beige head.  The aroma was definitely dominated by bittersweet chocolate, though you could get some wiffs of roasted malts.  However, the taste was more on the malty side.  Some bitterness, but then the chocolate flavor somewhat balances it out for a smooth finish.  Good amount of thickness, could use a little bit more carbonation though.  Not too pricey or heavy, so great drinkability.

Pours black with small light brown head; slightly roasted aroma of brown sugar, chocolate and hints of butter, strong baked notes; medium body, quite smooth carbonation; sweetish flavor of chocolate, roastness and licorice with mild bitterness.

Had this at the Rake Bar yesterday, small bar in borough market run by the same people as the Uttobeer stand. Barman recommended this for me. Great smell, hints of nuts. Lovely creamy light brown head. Big flavours, lots of caramel and coffee notes. Loved it.
Just a little sample.  Not the great malty palate that I was expecting.  Slightly yeasty aroma and a less than spectacular flavor.  What gives?
Lovely deep black color, Wow. Thick and  creamy head and a welcoming aroma when getting the first sip. A bit sweet and rosted malty aroma that lasts long with nice hoppy touch.

Anchor Brewing Company Porter--1997 22 oz. Bottle.  5.50% ABV.  (4.5 / 5.0)  Clear dark brown red color.  Wow front explodes with cherry nut chocolate flavor built on thick rich body.  Finishes lightly spicy with hints of Christmas Ale, but nothing harsh.  Wow Again.  Sampled 3/3/1999.

Anchor Brewing Company Porter--1997 12 oz. Bottle.  5.50% ABV.  (4.0 / 5.0)  Clear dark red brown color.  Rich chocolate head leaves rich lace.  Sweet cherry toffee licorice front with light chocolate hint.  Rich malty sweet toasted cherry toffee body.  Ends rich and smooth.  Sampled 12/26/1999.

Anchor Brewing Company--Anchor Porter--2002 12 oz. Bottle.  5.70% ABV.  (4.75 / 5.0)  Clear ruby obsidian color.  Mild espresso laced head.  Malty roasted mild espresso cocoa fruit hop front.  Sweet thick crusty chalky roasted fruity smooth creamy cocoa body.  Roasted mild hop end. Sweet.  Burnt.  Sampled 1/13/2003.

Bottle at mitra kisjes, Meppel. Black with a very dense big creamy head. Aroma is espresso, mocca, caramel, sweetish.Taste is malty, coffee-like, full-bodied, some carbonation, with a long and slightly bitter finish. Very nice.
One of my personal favorites. Creamy head and rich flavor without being too overpowering.
12 ounce bottle dark brown black pour lite tan head .A dark robust,chocolate, porter with little hop

chocolate aroma.  Tan foamy head that is very light.  Black, full color that is inviting for a porter.  Smooth taste, not much bitterness and just a little sweet.  Not quite as rich as Founders porter. Overall, a very good porter

26-FEB-2010, bottle @home, from "Magasin".
Very dark brown, high light brown head.
Nicely roasted, coffee aroma and taste. Quite hoppy giving it added length. Nice, not overly complex porter.

Bottle, 355ml - Opaque black brown beer with a large head. Aroma is malty with notes of salt licorice, dried fruit, coffee and chocolate. Flavor is roasty malty with notes of chocolate milk, coffee and smoked licorice. Quite enjoyable porter.
Deep brown color with  tan head. Aroma is roasted chocolate and flavor is nutty and chocolate. Smooth creamy mouthfeel.  A solid porter.

( 12oz bottle) pours espresso brown, huge lasting dark tan head that lasts forever and has nice lacing. Nose of chocolate malt, roasted nuts, brown sugar, light cream. Taste of very run of the mill coffee, bitter chocolate, and a slight metallic taste. Nice medium body, refreshing carbonation, and a roasty/nutty finish.
Not for the faint of heart, this is a heavy duty porter.  Pours black as night and comes with a heavy, smoky flavor.  The perfect beer for a winter night.

Poured from a 12oz. bottle into a pint glass.

The color is a dark black with a nice foamy brown head and some really nice lacing being left on the glass.

The smell is malty with a slight hint of dark chocolate. A nice roasty character to this beer brings out thoughts of fudge brownies with some nuts.

The taste is again nice roasted malts with some slight coffee flavor and mixed with the dark chocolate flavor. Along with some nutty flavor that is also a little caramel flavor. Great flavor profile for a dark beer.

The feel of this beer is medium bodied. Goes down clean and is pretty easy drinking. A great beer for people into darker beers.

A classic! Love it! Could drink all night, bonus poi nts for not being over the top, not too rich, not too high alcohol, not crazy wacky name or logo...just beer......damn good beer. Anchor is fantastic brewery and this is a wonderful brew. Notes of brown sugar and caramel with a toasty nuttiness. Creamy and so well balanced on the palate. This almost has a zen like, less is more restraint that I admire. Sign me up

12oz bottle.  Caramel and chocolate aroma with an amazingly balanced taste, pretty fruity, with chocolate and a nice hopping.  Quite vinous, with intense notes of a delicious and smooth red wine and with a tartness I increasingly appreciated. Totally enjoyable, probably my favorite porter.  I only brought back one of these from Florida, damn it !?!?!  But yes, beers fly and it is a great day...

Poured from 16 oz bottle into nonic pint. 

Appearance: Strong coffee black color with a hint of clarity at the very edge. Thick, rich, caramel colored head that leaves heavy lacing on the sides of the glass.

Smell: Fragrance of rum, dates, and some yeast. However, it most strongly smells of molasses.

Taste: There is a strong backbone of what tastes like Steens Pure Cane syrup or molasses in this one. Its sweet, but there are enough hops to really make it balanced. Not cloying at all. Some roasted/smoky character slips into the background too. 

Mouthfeel: Bold, frothy carbonation that goes down without being too thick. Medium feel to it. 

Drinkability: Not overly strong or thick. Thin enough to guzzle, but thick enough to sip. Quite a tasty porter.

Pours deep dark brown with a small, thick, creamy tan head. Nose is coffee, bitter chocolate, and toffee. Taste is mellow roasted coffee at first, followed by a bitter dark chocolate, and a hint of vanilla. Lacing is minimal. Palate is smooth, medium bodied, and refreshing. Good porter.

Bottle 355ml. Opaque black color with average creamy beige head. Overall very malty and smooth. Medium to heavy body with average carbonation. Taste of roasted coffee, toffee and a hint of caramel. Pleasant aftertaste of bitter chocolate. I have to admit that porters arent my favorites usually, but this was the first I actually liked.

12 oz bottle from Princetons.  Deep brown color with a big tan crater filled head.  Aroma is roasted chocolate and flavor is nutty and chocolate.  Smooth creamy mouthfeel with a slight coffee taste in the finish.

I dont know why it took me this long to rate this..
Dark Brown/Black pour into my Rock Art Tulip.  Healthy Beige head that leaves nice lacing along the sides.  Aroma is rich molasses, Raisin, Plum with heavy breadiness and notes of chocolate, vanilla and tobacco leather.  Flavor is super bready with some chocolate, molasses, and coffee sidenotes.  Lovely silky mouthfeel.  A classic porter and the benchmark for good ones.

12oz bottle from Market Square.  Black pour with a thin tan head and some spotty stick.  Aroma of roasty malts, chocolate, coffee and dark fruits.  Sweet dark fruit, nuts and malt taste.  Slick milky drinkable light palate.  Overall an excellent roasty porter.
pretty decent drop. chocolate and toffee aroma but also an estery bubblegummy note in the background which I dont particularly care for. Roasty flavours with a nice mouthfeel. very drinkable.
Wow. Jet black with a nice tan head. Roasty scent. Smooth drink but just a tad more carbonation than I like. Very good though.

(bottle from Weber St. Liquor in Colorado Springs). Dark brown color. Large tan head, which is mostly diminishing. Sweet malt aroma. Moderate roast coffee flavor. Avg duration. Light bitter finish. Slick texture. Soft carbonation. Good lacing.
12 oz bottle.  Aroma of bitter chocolate and roasted malts.  Fantastic creamy mouthfeel with a taste of nuts, roasted malt, toffee and hops.  Nice clean finish.

Pours a very deep dark with a thick tan creamy head that leaves behind some very attractive lacing.  The aroma is very noticeable as Im pouring this into my glass.  Immediately the smells of deep cocoa arise followed by rich roasted coffee.  Sweet anice and black licorice are both very noticeable.  There is an underlying sweet character with some subtle spices as well.  The aroma carries onto the palate.  The coffee aspect seems to really carry through on this one.  The mouthfeel is pretty spot on, not near as thick and chewy as a heavy stout but still thick enough to meet what I would consider to be very good for a porter.  Overall, a very classy beer, well done, and wonderfully tasty.

Muddy brown pour, thick tan head from the 12oz. bottle:  Mocha, malts, burnt orange nose. Intricately balanced flavors of bitter hops, toffee, and chocolate. Medium bodied. Alcohol hidden fairly well. Drinkability: Pretty tasty. A nice bitter bite to it. Rebuy: Yeah. #251 on 22012010, DG.
Very dark beer, with a creamy head. Light maltiness with a balance of hops. Definite aromas of coffee. Nice amount light bitterness to the finish. Very smooth and easy to drink.
Pours a nice deep, dark brown with a creamy head that lasts. Chocolate and coffee flavors along with roasted grain and malt. Very smooth finish. This is one of the better porters Ive come across.

The pure aroma of roasted malts and dark rich complexion charactrerize this traditional porter. The huge cappucino-colored head settles like a waterfall in the glass in the tradition of a Guinness. The flavor is a pure, rich roasted malty porter as in the aroma.

Pours almost black with a nice sudsy beige head, slowly goes to lace. Aroma is dark fruit, roasted malt, notes of coffee, chocolate, caramel. Perfect carbonation. Taste is malty hops chocolate, and creamy. Not as dry of finish as some. Very smooth brew. It is not the most full bodied porter, but is not watery. It could use a bit more smoke. The bottom line is that this is a very good brew. maybe the best bottled porter available today.

I cant believe this beer got such a high rating? Pours a creamy frothy light brown mocha 3 finger head. Dark roasted coffee on the nose. The body was alot lighter then I like with a porter. Light flavors. It would make a nice early evening beer perhaps a warm up for a beer tasting.

Molto bella a vedersi, colore scurissimo, schiuma scura a sua volta, abbondante, persistente e "pannosa". Già laroma scopre il caffé e un sapore molto amaro e luppolato. In bocca lamaro è risaltato ulteriormente e insieme al caffé e, un po meno, al cioccolato sprigionano un mix piacevolissimo. Una birra che riprenderò sicuramente e magari aggiornerò questa recensione con qualche sapore che ancora devo scoprire.

bottle thanks to bhensonb.  poured dark brown with a beige head.  aroma was fudge brownies, toffee, chocolate, and coffee.  flavor was fudge, coffee, and chocolate.  body was medium-heavy with low carbonation.  good stuff.

Pours black with a lovely off-white head and excellent lacing.  Aromas of chocolate malt and a hint caramel. Rich and smooth on the palate, and tasting lightly sweet with pleasing chocolate bitter finish. This is a delightful porter. So happy to make its acquaintance.

Pours an opaque black color.  Big tan head with good retention and lacing. The aroma is soft with roasted chocolate malts and a slight bit of coffee. The taste is dark bitter chocolate with just a hint of caramel and dried fruit sweetness. Just the right amount of hops to balance the roasted malt.  Smooth, medium-full mouthfeel and lasting bittersweet chocolate and coffee finish.  Perfect example of a porter.

en san juan despues de la catastrofe en haiti y con un gran vergaso de agua. 
que barbara!  ni pensarlo que seria una birria tan buena.  dije buena?  buenisima
menos dulce que la russian stout que hicimos pero mas completa.  un alimento balanceado.  ya no necesito cenar.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2012 Bomber. Appearance is dark brown with an inch of creamy light brown foam. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee and dark chocolate. The taste begins with strong dark roast coffee and bittersweet chocolate flavors along with some toffee and licorice. The mouthfeel is smooth and creamy with a slightly dry, chocolaty finish. A classic Porter and one of Anchors finest offerings.

22oz fatboy bomber.  Pours dark brown with a 1-inch fluffy tan/eventually receding/leaving good lacing head.  Aromas of bittersweet chocolate, roast coffee, slight red wine sour/twang(?) and plum/raisins.  Flavor of semi-sweet chocolate, espresso coffee and stone fruits.  Lingering hop bitterness with fine carbonation and a very smooth, creamy mouthfeel = Great finish.  Low ABV makes this easily sessionable.  A classic that never dissapoints.

Great Porter. Beguiling aroma. Hints of sweet liquorice, toffee, and caramel but no coffee or chocolate. Great head of lasting beige foam and beer color of black with ruby sparkles. Tastes same as aroma. Sweet but not cloying with a soft syrupy palate and noticeable bittering and finishing hops.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2010 Pours dark brown with a nice tan head.  Very fresh aroma with lots of dark roasted coffee and some veggies with the strong malt smell.  Taste is on the bitter side at first but mellows out as it warms up.  Mouth feel is very smooth, lush and satisfying.  Finishes unexpectedly sweet.  A solid porter.
Pours black with a tan head that quickly dissipates. Aroma of coffee, licorice, caramel and chocolate. Flavor is quite light, dry, coffee, watery porter. Bitter dry finish.

Pours dark brown with a fluffy tan head. The aroma has some lager yeast notes with some chocolate and green banana peel. The flavor is very nice with chocolate and notes of berries and banana. A little black licorice on the palate with a mild, bitter, toasted finish. A really good porter.

dark brown with a good head that lasts. a butter malt nose with a dusty hop accent. nutmeg? flavor is a charred malt, toast, blackstrap molasses. The hop is bitter, dry and gives a strong backbone but also adds a stale sulphury quality. medium body and a nice amount of carbonation. I wanted to like this more than I did.

(br-btl, bu-lbl)

§lcnt-mhgy, thick-buubly-head, malty T1 T2, bitter T3, §Tf.
UPDATED: FEB 2, 2010 Bottle, pours a deep black with a coffee head. Light malt aroma. Flavour is a smooth malt, with a bit of sweetness. Nice beer.

Black color with a nice and thick light brown color head.  Aroma is full of barley malts, licorice, and some hops.  Taste is quite smooth and pleasant.  Flavors include malts, some slight chocolate, coffee, and (as weird as this sounds) city water.  Has a bitter aftertaste but it hits the spot.
Pour dark with a nice tan head which lasted well.  The taste had a bit of sweetness.  I finished it with  a slice of pumpkin pie which seemed to bring out a bit of cherry flavor.
On tap, San Francisco airport. Served a bit too cold. Pours jet black, thick head. Choco, sweet aroma. Roasty, chocolate, licorice. Warming sweet finish.

I cant believe I have never rated this beer, since it is one of my favorite porters. It pours opaque brown with a very nice fluffy tan head and an enticing chocolate and treacle aroma. There is a hearty roasted malt flavor some carbonation, a bit of chocolate and a lot of dark molasses. This is a real porter.
Wasnt expecting too much but this porter was creamy and tasted great.  Very smooth and relaxing beer to drink.

Bottle, Göteborg, 2006-08-10
AP: black body wee white head AR: malty, dark and sweet bread with orange peel F: malty, dark and sweet bread with orange peel, hint licqoris root
Didnt see the high praise everyone else gets with this one. Poured real dark with a thin head.Taste was malty and toasty pretty in your face taste to me. may need to try this again

Dark black pour with a thinning tan head.  Aroma is malty sweet with hints of coffee and chocolate.  Flavor is strong with malt, coffee and chocolate.  Finishes extremely smooth and soft with a lingering sweetness.  A favorite porter.

Im a total novice when it comes to porters. With that said I enjoyed this brew. Very smooth. Fantastic aroma and color. Taste is malty and toasty, very complex with a hint of hops at the end. Nice beer.

One of the best porters Ive ever had the privilege of tasting. Somewhat salty aroma, dark black appearance, and solid head. Deep taste, somewhat sweet and full bodied. Recommended to every porter lover!

33cl bottle, as shown.

Pours a pitch black with a big, creamy beige head. Impressive retention, plenty of lacing. Great-looking porter.

Sweet aroma of double chocolate, with a subdued coffee note and even a whiff of hops lurking in the background.

For a porter, this one is medium-bodied, with moderate carbonation. Smooth, creamy mouth feel. 

Initially sweet taste of caramelised malt and aniseed, but towards the middle a healthy, smoky bitterness kicks in and carries this brew towards its dry, refreshing finish. Lingering, but smooth, alcoholic after taste. 

This is a most pleasurable American porter from Anchor, a classic, I am told, of its kind. While of the porter beers I know Id slightly favour Fullers London Porter and Samuel Smiths Taddy Porter, this one comes pretty close. Extremely well-balanced soft and bitter notes, a well-rounded, smooth drink - highly sessionable.

Id describe this beer as sweet and restrained enough to be very drinkable, but with enough complexity to interesting.  Pours with a medium to large tan head which is retained well. The aroma is nicely sweet and chocolatey which some sneaky bitterness. The flavour is fairly moderate, initially some roasted coffee quickly subduing to a more gentle and sweet chocolate finish. Some smokiness lingers throughout. The body is surprisingly on the firm side for its alcohol content. Well crafted and very enjoyable.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2009 Classic, very reliable and solid porter. Lovely dark dark brown, close to black with a huge, dense chunky brown head that leaves fantastic lazing on whatever you pour it in. Aroma is nicely roasted, lightly hoppy and piney with notes of hard roasted coffe and caramell. Mouthfeel is medium, oily and very sick with a medium amount of suitable carbonation. Flavour is also "oily" if you can call a flavour that, very chewy, caramelly, piney and perfectly roasted. Awsome porter.

12oz bottle. This one is a classic. The label says that they have been brewing this one since 1974 which is truly impressive. There may be alot of great porters available today but back in the 70s this must have been truly unique. And it still holds up as being one of the better ones. Thanks Fritz!
brown/black in appearance.  chocolate and roasted notes.  easy to drink.  like a Guiness almost.  nice.

Bottle drank at the Greenwich Union pub, Greenwich. Pours black with a light brown head. Good carbonation. Aromas of roasted malts, chocolate, caramel, raisins. Flavours of dark chocolate, coffee, raisins, vanilla. Very nice mouthfeel. Finishes sweet and hoppy. One of the best American porters.

Aroma: sweet, dark malt, dried fruit (such as prunes, raisins), some flowery, grassy hops. Molasses. Very, very nice. Surprisingly not very roasted. Smells like a dark barleywine.
 
Flavour: Sweet, malty and slightly bitter. Vague smokyness. Pretty good. Rubber, liquorice and charred aftertaste.
Powerful for this gravity. 
 
Appearance: Very dark brown with greyish brown rind. Some beige irregular foam clinging bubbly to the glass and scattered thin film.
 
Palate: Really nice. Slithers down the tongue. Velvety & silken. Slightly fizzy. Really nice.

Pours inky dark brown with a medium tan head, fine lacing.  Aroma of chocolate, plum, coffee, toffee, leather and pine.  Medium body, velvety and smooth.  Dark chocolate, toast, plum, and coffee flavors, rich and malty but understated.  Citrus and a hint of earthy hops in the finish.  Very well balanced and drinkable.

An above average porter, pours nice and black with a nose of smoke and chocolate.  A nice malty start with some hop bitterness makes this a classic example of the style, just nothing very outstanding about it.

This is a truly unique porter in their combo of Northern Brewer and Cascade hops.  I however am not a fan of citrus hops in a porter nor do I really enjoy the minty/blackberry flavor from the Northern Brewer hops.  I found that the hop aroma was competing with the roast qualities.  Still though, this is a well made porter that finishes fairly dry, but there are several other porters in the Seattle area that can dance too.

Pours little but thick creamy head, and has a dark chocolate brown to black color.  Very heavy on the chocolate malt, heavy on the smoke flavor (a little too heavy for my taste.) Above average porter.
I really enjoyed this beer. Very dark, very stout with tastes of chocolate, coffee, and vanilla. Just dont drink too many of them!

Bottle at the Bloomington Beer Festival. Poured a near black with a light brown head. Aroma was full of aggressive malts with just a touch of citrus hops. Flavor was very malty as well with a bit of a coffee flavor and again, just a bit of bitter hops. It was nice and thick on the tongue.

12 fl oz bottle.  Pours pure black with a ruby tinge, huge frothy caramel head, leaving tonnes on lacing.  Aroma is pure roasted malt.  Flavour is again,sweet roasted malt, hint of raisin.  Awesome beer!  Great porter!

Bottle.Pours black with a beige head.Aroma of caramel , roast, fruit and chocolate with some nuts.Flavor is dark chocolate,roast, fruitiness with hints of smoke on a sweet and bitter finish.Ok ,but a tad sweet porter.

12 oz bottle. Pours a deep brown color, with tanned head and fair lacing. Aroma of dark fruit, juicy malt with a touch of nuts and yeast. Medium body with sweet malt, dark fruit and espresso coffee fill the mouth. Nice long dry finish. Great porter.

light bitterness,chocolate aroma, pours dark black.... soft off white foam head.
Refreshing and enjoyable.

Great porter of a fine quality very impressive.  A favorite great for a fishing trip or camping nice with marshmallows.  Pours thick and dark black like an imperial stout and puts a smile on your face.
I havent had this porter in years, but the fact that my memory of it is so fond can only speak to its drinkability, or my naivete at the time. Lets hope for the former.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2012 A very nice porter. Very smooth and satisfying. I loved every drop! Excellent!

Update here, for Oct 13, 2012. Just as good as I remember it! The coffee nose and flavors are intense. Served in a snifter at The Oakwood in Kits.

Bottle. Dessert at Blå Rock 12.oct.09. Pours a deep brown colour, with spare beige head and fair lacing. Aroma: Dark chocolate, roasted coffee beans with at touch of herbs and cookies. The chocolate and coffee is noticeable in the flavour as well, but there is also some hints of plum, hazelnuts, cherry and a touch of vanilla. The finish is slightly metallic. The aroma is a bit more appealing than the flavour. I like the texture, and that it is not as substantial as a lot of other porters, which makes it perfect with cake to.
