thick viscous pour... nearly impenetrable dark brown topped by  a tan head. its got  a luscious mouth feel. aromas of roasty malt, fresh cream, chocolate and light coffee combine with a strange fruity sweetness. aroma carries through to the flavor along with some molasses then finishes tart and lightly hoppy bitter. i tried hating on this but i cant... its pretty solid. 7/4/7/4/17=3.9

More like some of the roastier Belgian heavyweights than a porter, but who gives? This is a great beer. Oily pitch pour with a creamy beige head. Sticky, malty snout with sniffs of vanilla, molasses (probably), walnuts, raisins and espresso roastiness. Fudgy malt, xmas pudding, charred cocoa bitterness. A teaspoon of Marmite. Afternotes of licorice...and more charred malt roastiness. Really sticks around. As creamily bittersweet as I knew it would be. Worthy of the gold-rimmed Rochefort snifter.

this little Porter was alittle lighter in the mouth than I thought in would be. Its got a good dark colour , but a light head that disipates rapidly. A little to much fizz for me in a porter.The bitter nose makes it much better from the bottle than from the pint. overall agreeable with a bit of hard chesse and summer sausage

Wow.  Everything you could want in a porter: pitch black with a dark, frothy head; aroma of roasted coffee; flavor of dark chocolate, coffee, and bread crust.  Perfect ammount of carbonation that went down incredibly smooth - the single best mouthfeel Ive experienced.  Ive had a few highly-regarded porters in my day but this is the best all-around porter Ive ever tasted.

Alcohol in aroma with strong hints of rich dark chocolate.  Ligther body with a dark hue and thin fizzy head.  Starts with stong hints of chocolate, finishes slightly fruity.  A decent porter, but not my favorite considering the finish
rich chocolate and malt aroma.  Velvety light body palate.  Nice chocolate flavor with hints of coffee and a very slight sweet fruity and toffee flavored finish.  A good everyday beer.

Bottle, 355ml. A dark black colour with a good head. Aroma is malt with dark fruits. Taste is very malty with chocolate and undertones of hoppy citrus fruits. Moderate carbonation. A hoppy, malty, citrus finish. Very tasty and seems more alcoholic than it is.
Bottle.  Appearance is flat brownish black.  Nose is malts, chocolate, a bit of coffee.  Tastes more of the same with a light touch of fruit.  Good in the mouth.  Solid.

Bottle. The nice dark brown color was promising but something was just wrong with this beer. I bought a six pack and the first four tasted and smelled like sour red wine. It was almost undrinkable and I just gave away the other two.  Maybe it was a bad batch but I still havent been able to get that flavor out of my head.

12oz bottle.  No freshdate date - just a cryptic code.  Pours a very dark brown.  Little carobnation visible and very little lacing.  Faint aroma of malt.  Nice taste of roasted malts, although I dont taste much in the way of the advertised hops.  There is a decent amount of aftertaste, but it becomes slightly funky.  Decent porter.

Bottle conditioned, 355ml. Dark brown to black with beige head. Somewhat underflavoured porter with non of the fruitiness, tartness expected. There is a deep roasted malt note, chocolatey with some bitterness, reasonable palate but too sweet for a true porter. It looks overhyped in the marking to me, its really only average.

Bottle, pours dark brown with a huge light brown creamy head.  The head shrinks down a little but sticks around for the whole beer, and the lacing is pretty good.  The aroma is heavy on the malt side.  The aroma is of chocolate and coffee.  There is not much hop aroma.  There is also a hint of sourness to the aroma.  Takeing the first sip you are hit with a pretty good size malt bill, with quite a bit of coffee and chocolate.  There is also a distinct sourness to it.  There is a slight bitterness, but not much for hop flavor.  With the initial flavor it is very sweet with light bitterness.  Then the finishing flavors the sweetness falls back to the moderate level with a little bit of bitterness and that sourness.  The duration of the finish is somewhere inbetween short and average length.  The body is medium with a creamy texture and soft carbonation.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a dark ruby-cola color with a mocha hued head that is thin but leaves trace lacing.  Medium carbonation.  The aroma is faint, with only an earthy hint of chocolate and smoke.  The taste is somewhat peculiar, being slightly watery and tasteless towards the beginning, and fading into a toffee and coffee ending with a decent hops and malt balance.  The best part of this porter is the palate, which consists of a very silky mouthfeel with little astringency. After seeing the high scores this is given, I honestly wonder if I got a bad bottle/

Tis a dark beer with a brownish head, though I didnt get a really good pour. Nice roasty sweet smell of course. So the beer itself is hella of roasty, with bittersweet chocolate taste. Some caramel hints and it possesses a quite interesting finish, which is slightly different from the rest of the beer. An interesting and tasty beer to drink.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2007 Had it in a pint glass. I really loved this beer. This is the type of beer I could have a few of and still enjoy everyone just as much. The flavors are not over bearing but they are there and delicious. Also it shouldnt feel you up if you decide to have a few of them at dinner. Or breakfast... Again great beer I loved it, also smooth and it fills your palate and slams your taste buds with a delicious flavor

Bottle. 12 FL. OZ. Opaque, very dark brown color with minimal tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt with chocolate and coffee notes.  Nice medium body with soft carbonation  and a dry, bitter flavor. Good beer, not great.

Pours black with a large frothy/rocky beige head. Aroma is full of dark berry fruit, with notes of vanilla, and a slight hint of alcohol. Flavor has some nice coffee like bitterness, with an undertone of vanilla, and lightly sweet berry. Palate is full, a bit creamy, with some lingering bitterness. Definitely the best Ive had from Anchor so far.
bottle from ace bev.  aroma is roast and caramel.  medium/full body, lots of caramel and toffee.  the finish is almost clean, but just a touch sweet.  great standard porter.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2007 Great porter! It tastes more like a stout to me. I love the black color that this beer has. I like how it poured. The beer is semi-thick, and goes down very smooth! It has a very sweet caramel/dark fruit smell to it. After I had a few gulps I noticed the smell does not do the flavor justice. The beer provides coffee, chocolate, and smoke notes. I love this beer because it keeps me guessing. The ONLY reason this beer did not get a 4+ is because of the weak alcohol content. I am disappointed because I like to feel the beer take a bite of my throat while drinking it. The St. Bernardus Abt 12 has this quality. The flavors come out, but then the alcohol gives you a slight zing at the end. The bottles are cool too.
Pours dark black with a small head. Creamy feel and smooth rounded body. Malty, with flavors of chocolate and light coffee.
bottle. Deep dark pour with a nice tan head. toasty malt aroma. creamy with a chocolate bitterness in the finish. loved this beer.

Rather unique shaped 12 oz bottle with a twist off cap.The shape of the bottle allows for a perfect pour into my clear mug. Very dark and stoutlike colors. Aroma is very nice, attractive to the beer drinking nose. Chocolate root beer?  Dark tan head that is barely there except for a froth and ring.  Good strong bitter porter stout flavor impact.  Thick and almost syrupy on the tongue. Burned western pine flavors impact the uvula.  Metalic aromas slowly infringe on the olfactories. Seems to have a higher alky content if you observe by flavor. Black coffee bitterness is apparent. Barely any carbonation. Finishes with the intent that you will not forget. A stronger porter. A little more ver busto  than I expected from a gentlemans porter. Plenty good for a west coast beer. If it was not for the bitter linger, I would say this is much like a sweet stout.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Poured into a glass. This porter and I have memories. Riding into the parking lot during my first phish show with pat and sean ahern. The first I had this I thought it was a stout. So thick, creamy, and chocolately. Yet the hops are there too. Still remains my favorite Anchor product.

12oz bottle.  Pours black with a small, foamy brown head.  Aroma is dark roasted malts and sweet chocolate.  Taste is pretty chocolatey, smooth and a little creamy but on the light side.  A nice porter.
Bottle. Black colour with a light brown head. Sweet roasty aroma. Also a scent of raisins in rum. Flavour is coffee and chocolate with a nice sweetness.

Aaah a delicious porter. I love the mouthfeel of porters in relation to stouts. You get most of the flavor without the extreme thickness. Aroma of malt. Pour was a deep dark brown with a thin off white ring for a head. Taste was delicious and full....dark coffee, chocolate and a bitterness in the aftertaste. Great!
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: 12 oz. bottle. Black with tan head.  Rich aroma of malt, coffee, caramel and  toffee. Coffee, charcoal, raisins in the flavor with some citrusy hops. Creamy mouthfeel. Very rich and pleasant. Some bottles have been much hoppier than this one.

Bottle at In de Wildeman, march 07. Toasty, raisins, buttery aroma and a slight tobacco touch. Full, powerfull flavor, coal, chocolate, unsweetend coffee and charcoal ending. Medium MF with a punch of flavor. Dry feeling with a bit astringent end. Appareance is black with some ruby hues and a fine, creamy, yellow-brown head. A nice, reflexive, warming porter.

Pours black, with a massive khaki head that fills the pint glass perfectly.  Sweet malt aroma, with some alcohol evident over the hops. Sweet and light bodied, with a bit of a sourness that doesnt seem to fit, reminiscent of their steam beer.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: Big bottle here for a decent price.  Pours brown black with red highlights and a small fizzy  head.  Aroma of alcohol, sweet cherries, and brown sugar.  Sweet smooth flavors, foamy chocolate, light roast, bitterness, overly sweet.
this has to be one of their best. deep, dark color, nice creamy head. theres some chocolate and coffee flavor here, and it is balanced quite well.

Quite surprised by this one. Wasnt expecting much and it turned out to be good. Color is a choclatey brown with creamy head. Aroma is coffee with chcolate hints. Taste like a blend of choclate and coffee.

Anchor Brewing has always been a favorite of mine. Going back when I first stared with their Liberty Ale and working my way up to Old Foghorn. Itd been awhile since I cracked open an Anchor Porter so I thought Id give it a go. Pours out a rich, creamy thick tanish/brown head which stayed the course while drinking. Color of the beer is a deep chocolate brown color, with some light bubbles sticking to the sides. Flavor is dark chocolate, some roasted coffee, molasses and toffee. Flavors were more of the same with the nose but an added hop profile to keep it lively and interesting. This is an excellent example of what a porter can be. Drinkable, rich, smooth, and not overbearing in anyway. A near masterpiece from a phenomenal brewery.

Really a class act here. Poured with a nice full, textured, foamy, frothy, light tan head and lace. Very dark brown, almost opaque with highlights of dark copper red. Nice rich malty roasty coffee toffee chocolate nose. More roastiness in flavor. A bit thin body, but creamy. And the flavor is really good. Definitely a session beer. NIce balanced finish. Having this at Bodega Brew Pub downtown La Crosse. Occasionaly they have it on draft too.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2008 Not much aroma.  Beer looks beautiful--medium brown with creamy light brown head with good staying power.  Decent malt flavoring--almost stout like--burnt molasses/coffee with hints of raisin and prune.  Hops is heavy and bitter, and lasts through the finish.  Too bitter for me.
Poured into a pint glass very dark with a nice tan head. Aroma is amazing with roasted malts. Taste is chocolate-coffee, dark fruits,caramel, and slight bitterness but does not effect the body.
Bottled. Canals in NJ. Brown pour with coffee aroma. Medium body with roasted flavors. Mild hop finish. Not bad at all.

Poured into a pint , out of the nicely designed and labeled bottle , very dark and opaque black. Head is exellent , about 1 1/4 inch , tanish color similar to the main color of the label , and it sticks around as 1/4 inch the entire way through leaving slight lacing. Taken to the nose , smells of dark roasty malt , slight chocolate , and a hint of toffee or butterscotch. Very pleasant and welcoming. Taste is rich, hearty malt at first with a little bit of chocolate , then the whole hops kick in nice. Slight Bitter , dry finish of coffee and subtle toffee. ( not very sweet though) . Nicely carbonated and silky mouthfeel. Overall this is one great American Porter. I really like the taste of the liberal use of hops. Very dinkable.

bottle.  dark maple color with thick tan head.  smokey chocolate, coffee grinds, mild dark fruti, hippy.  light body.  sweet.  tastes more of a sweet stout.  easy drinking.  slight sour bitterness in finish.  enjoyable.

Bottle. Pours dark mahogany red. A thin, creamy and lasting beige head. Aroma has lots of roasted malts, some berrues and a little smoke. Nice full mouthfeel - not that creamy nor oily, just full. Flavour is quite sweet with with a clear background of roasted malts. Finishes with a well-rounded bitterness.

Bloody Lovely.
Bottle, IBS, Perth.
a Swathe of rich malty goodness, wiht a little american hop flavour around the edges. A must try.
UPDATED: MAR 31, 2007 Very dark beer, poured with big, slightly brown head. Aromas of coffee and bitter chocolate. Very smooth to drink with roasted flavours and hints of bitterness. Pretty good.

This is probably my favorite beer.  The nose is sweet.  Pours a deeeeep amber with nice smokey head which unfortunatly disappears too fast.  Ahhh the flavor is exquisit.  Nothing really stands out as being the main flavor of this brew.  No flavor really dominates, all the flavors really blend together very well, think of it as a good jambalaya or other food that is cooked together for a very long time.  No single flavor is standing out its all so very well blended.  Flavor is plenty malty but quite highly hopped for balance.  Sometimes the yeast flavor comes through as well.  Profile is really one of malty sweetness, coffee/toffee flavors, and a well balanced bitterness.  The finish lingers but in a very good way.

Anchor Porter poured nearly black, but not quite. Very dark brown with light tan head. Immediately tasted a little too much burned chocolate for my taste.  I enjoyed a lot of the flavors in the Anchor, but ultimately, the burned taste made it pretty tough for me to drink.  A little on the harsh side.

This was an awesome beer it is verry dark has a decent pour and head to it. the flavor is a mix of caramel and hopps with a hint of chocolate. But the taste is awesome it is a smooth  and goes down quick. but it was an awesome beer this is one of my favorite porters that i have ever had
Pours black, smallish head.  Aroma is nice and complex.  Flavor is nice and complex, with chocolate and coffee, but overly sweet, and a little too fizzy in my opinion.  Still, a nice porter.

Very refreshing to find a real ale at an airport. It was on tap at the SFO Anchor bar. Poured extreamly chilled. Dark brown color, tan head with a well mixed coffee and chocolate flavor, mainly roasted too burnt malts with a very smooth body and slight fruity aftertaste. Didnt have time to let it warm but would like to try it again with more time.
dark brown color when poured.  chocolaty head.  nice chocolate flavor.  tastes pretty good at room temp

draft at other room - dark pour with a nice chocolately colored head. aroma and flavors were pretty much the same. chocolate and roastiness. nicely balanced with a nice medium creamy mouthfeel. solid anytime beer.

Pours a very dark reddish brown, nearly black at first glance, with a firm tan head.  The nose is strong with roast and chocolate malt, sweet, with some relatively liberal floral hops and some creaminess.  The palate is creamy and smooth, with subdued carbonation and a tiny bit of stickiness holding it together, I like it.  The flavors are in line with the aroma, big sweet characteristically porter chocolate malt and characteristically stout roast.  Creamy and sweet, with a bit of a acidic charcoal aspect.  The finish is creamy and smooth then the charcoal acidity and the floral hops kick in.  A little bit of diacetyl noticable with the warming, though its not out of place.  I think this is much more of a stout than a porter, but its still a very nice beer and perhaps my favorite offering from Anchor for every day drinking.
Dark roasted coffee flavors and aromas with hints of chicory and tar.  A distinctive cocoa powder character to it too.  Seems a bit thin.
Pours black with a hefty beige head. Smells of black cherries and cola, some licorice.  Tastes roasted, cherries, and mildly sweet.
Lots of toasted malt flavor without being too sweet. Medium body is just what I would expect from a porter. Aroma is modest toasted malt.
one of Anchors best.  Rich and malty pours like oil.  A wonderful Porter, if youve never tried a porter this one is a great way to start.

bottle of it....This pitch back beer has a nice, creamy head. ok porter, that is initially a bit thin, but it gains terrain in the flavour and the finish is good. It has notes of coffee, a bit of licorice and a nice bitterness at the end. A decent porter, but could use a little more bite
My second try from Anchor, and goodness this is leaps and bounds better than the Steam.  A very good all around brew. Smell is very good. A drinkable porter I will continue to buy.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2007 Re-rate. Bottle. Nose is slightly acidic dark chocolate and coffee. Opaque black with a brownish head, frothy fades to bubbly. Delicious and smooth. Full bodied thickness carries dark chocolate that isnt overly sweet, well-balanced with some coffee and caramel notes in the finish. A wonderful beer. 
Original rating: 7/4/7/5/16

12 oz bottle.  Nice dark brown/oily black color, firm brown head that fades but the aroma doesnt.  That hits your nose at the glass nears the lips, and the solid flavor follows fully.  More of an astringent alcohol taste than say Sierra Nevada, but this is more full bodied.  Wish I had purchased more than one.  Great porter.
darkest porter i have ever tasted.  pours coca cola black with a thick creamy head.  tastes of coffee with hints of sweetness.  not over-carbonated by any means.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2007 Black with big, foamy espresso head / Creamy, light, roast malt nose /  Medium body with lively carbonation and good finish /  Flavors of dark roast coffee with a little sweetness / A good, solid porter with fairly simple burnt coffee flavors.
Rich! Blacker than a bicycle tire. Smells a bit smokey. Taste is hoppy and bitter. Whew. I like it.

This beer poured a deep murky black fluid the defied any light wanting to pass through it. The aroma consists of nuts and toast with a hint of  earthiness and  leaves. Alcohol and raisins laced with smoke finish the nose. This beer was easy on the palate that filled my mouth with bitter dark chacolate and sweet plums. the creamy tan head lasted almost to the end and laced the glass with and even consistency.

12Bottle. Aroma is hoppy with a molasses and nut honey hint. Black with a brown head with an opaque body.  Has a good balance of hops and malts that mixes well with the sweet chocolate and prunes. Mainly bittersweet dark chocolate or dark coffee with some light refreshing fruitiness. Easy on the palate. I love to pour this into my 30oz mug and enjoy this beer with friends.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2007 Surprisingly aromatic. Most beer seems to be light in the aroma category - not this one. Typical porter appearance. Nice balance of bitter and toasty, malt sweetness. Good mouth feel. Ill do it again - I was surprised

Bottle. Thick chocolate head over a near black, opaque body. Nutty, roasty aroma. Mainly sweetish dark malts along with some refreshing fruitiness (raisins, figs).  Taste is complex and exciting; espresso, both bitter and sweet chocolate, sweet black malts, and notes of dark dried fruits. Good body, oily mouthfeel. A lingering  acidic bitterness in the finish. Very nice!

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2007 This Porter pours deep black with a huge mocha head.It has a perfect blend of hops robust but not too bitter and balanced well with the malts.It has the flavor of dark chocolate with notes of molasses and black cherries.The nose was exceptional.What really stood out to me was the amazing flavor,a very well brewed Porter,that I will buy again.It has a Palate that will make your mouth water ,like an electric shock on the tongue.Nice effervescence adding to the palate.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2008 pours surprisingly dark for a porter with a tight light brown head.  good lacing and all that. flavor is almost sweet stouty, with a little bit of milky chocolate, moderate roast.  raisins and some kind of fruity flavor is in there somewhere and i really like it. finishes slightly dry.  unique and very tasty!  i need to try more anchor beers.
Inky black, caramel colored head.  Wonderful malty aroma, smells like dried fruit and chocolate.  Mmmm, very tasty, choclate to start, with a nice bitter hop finish.

Beautiful dark dark brown witha nice frothy tan head.  Rich and smooth flavors of chocolate and cofee.  No bitter aftertase on the palate.  An excellent drinking Porter.  I shall buy many more of these.  A great value.
Cheers!
Bottle at Boom Chicago, Amsterdam. Excellent. Very syrupy and dark. Oaky colour with luscious texture. Distinct Anchor taste of chocolate and coffee. A real pleasure.

I love this stuff. It is by far the smoothest porter Ive ever had. Not overdone on any single flavour. Coffee, molasses, chocolate, malt, and no tartness to be detected. The light brown, fine head looks amazing atop the deep brown body. Buy it if your fan of any beer.
Purple/black with a coffee roast, A little burnt roast with a small amount of sweetness and hint of chocolate with a bitter linger

Oh very nice. Pour was very frothy with a thick dark brown head. Flavor is great. Along with a smooth mouthfeel with little aftertaste. Flavor is very carmel and malty with smooth toasted hoppiness. Pour is also nice and dark.

[194-20070122] 12floz. Smells like a bit of beef was sitting in a sweet woody oak barrel deep in the thick of a forest. Dark brown black body with a big creamy medium-lasting light brown head. Lightly sweet chocolate malt flavour with an initial bitterness blending into a sweet aftertaste. Medium-full body, not too thick. Very well-blended flavour, texture and aroma, quite impressive.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2007 Pours a dark brown color with thick frothy tan head that fades quickly.  Aroma of malt,  chocolate, faint coffee and molasses.  Taste  is somewhat fruiter then any porter Ive had, almost a dark fruit flavor.  The chocolate and roasted coffee make their expected appearance but are downplayed a bit.  Some roasted grain shows up in the finish.  Carbonation is moderate.  There is a bit of an astringent or citric alcohol taste as well.  Not impressed.
Pours a redish browm with a thick foamy head. Aroma is sweet , maybe cottoncandy, fruit. Tastes licorice, kind of a unique flavor. cant put my finger on it. Very intresting brew.
UPDATED: MAY 9, 2008 12oz bottle from the Co-op in Davis, CA. Very dark in color with a hint of brown sugar and molassas. Subtle sweet taste with a slightly bitter finish.

Picked up this one today and couldnt wait to try it out.  Poured a nice black with a well structured head.  Tastes thick for an American porter which was fine with me.  Malty, with hints of molasses and a little fruit.  Nice and surprising drinkable for such a robust beer.   Finishes long yet smooth.  Should have tried this a long time ago.

Statistically speaking, I am irrelevant with this, but I was surprised that Ive never rated this old favorite.  Deep mahogany color when held up to the light with an attractive creamy beige head that left sticky lace.  Sweet malt nose with some faint roasted grain.  Light brown sugar sweetness with some sweetened coffee and some burnt grains.  Nice beer.

Almost pitch black beer, with a beige head wich disappears into a creamy film, and sticky creamy ring. Aroma of chocolate and malt. A dark unsweetend chocolate taste, malt, slight notes of black original licorice, balanced bitter finish. A damn good beer all and all, really enjoyable.

Bottled(355ml). -at the Pianeta Birra, RiminiDark brown coloured, medium sized opaque head, slightly sweet chocolate nose. Light roasted chocolate aroma with nice chocolate and licorice notes. Bitter hoppy finish. Very nice beer.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2009 Rerate. 7mo bottle as an experiment since my last 7mo bottle of this was amazing. From this bottle though, I have to give it the same score as original rating.

Cola brown body, full-sized cheesy khaki head. Bready aroma and actually comes off lightly spiced, as of gingerbread(??). Unspecified dark malts. Still very tasty. The Dr Pepper and cola flavors that were so outspoken when fresh have receded to a second-long impression and have given way to the darker roastier flavors. Which isnt to say this is at all roasty in the way that stouts are. Deft-bodied and very drinkable, which is just how I like my porters. Retronasal - whole espresso bean oils. Overall, it seems this will hold up for a long time.


Near black body, mocha tan head. Roasty nutty aroma. Well balanced flavor, a little mocha sweetness, a little roasty bitterness, a little smoky and a tiny bit acidic. A little underwhelming at first but a few bottles later and its starting to grow on me.

7 4 7 4 15

Lonely stray single bottle in the supermarket cooler crying out to me like an animal shelter dog, "please bring me home...Ill make you happy."  Poured black with a light brown bumpy head.  Dark roasted malt aromas--chocolate, espresso coffee, even a bit of licorice and dark dried fruit.  Chocolatey malt flavor with a smooth creamy full palate--a nice change from the more watery domestic porters.  Mild roasty finish.  Very pleasing.
Bottle. Black colour with an average tan head. Aroma and flavour of dried fruit, chocolate and roasted malt.

Blacker than night. Thick frothy head with nive lacing. This has a note worthy appearance. Smells similar to brandy with notes of wheat. Tastes beautiful! Fig, bannana, grape, and wonderful!. Leaves you feeling refreshed and happy to be alive.
Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours dark with a tan head. Aroma of roast, alcohol, chocolate, and slight fruit, The flavor is bitter, roast, and alcohol.

The Anchor Porter pours a dark brown color with a large, frothy light-brown head. Fair lacing trails a fully diminishing head. Murky body. Aroma is of heavy with toasted molasses notes and grape, as well as a red licorice scent. Initial taste is moderately sweet, turning to a light bitter at the finish with a long duration. Light to medium on the mouth, it has a watery texture with lively carbonation. Solid porter.

Reviewed on October 27th, 2006.
(Bottle) Pours a dark brown color with a nice beige head. Roasted malty notes with a touch of alcohol in the aftertaste. Smooth, full mouthfeel. One of the better porters I have had in my days.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a pint glass, very dark with a thick chocolate milkshake head. (Dark amber when held up to the light.) The aroma is slight, but diverse with notes of coffee, cocoa, fruit and roasted malt. There is a heavy coffee taste up front, but later notes of cocoa, burnt toast and roasted malts come through. (More cocoa than sweet chocolate.) Not much bitterness and no alcohol taste to speak of. Very nice.

Heavy hopped, heavy body, tan head. Hint of chocolate in the taste.  Very flavorful. I must admit a surprise, since I wasnt expecting a whole lot based on the steam beer by the same brewer (not a fan).
Black with tan head.  Much lacing.  Aroma of chocolate, malt and hops.  Flavour of malt, chocolate caramel and toffee.  Hoppy finish
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Pours as thick and dark as a cup of coffee. Inch think fizzy head of foamy chocolate milk color. Hints of rasin and prune on the nose. A bit bitter on the sides of the tongue and a litte watery. A little roasted coffee and chocolate on the palate as well (that "sweet bitterness"). Generally pleasant. Definitely tell theres some alcohol in it, somewhat metallic aftetaste. (Bottle Pour 2/11/2007)

Bottle. Pours midnight black with no head. Aroma of cold coffee, baking chocolate, amaretto, and Gran Mariner? Huh. Flavor of iced coffee, baking chocolate, skim milk. Aftertaste has long coffee bitterness, hazelnut, whole milk. Body is nice and thick, but is a bit sticky in the back of the throat as well. Yea, this is a bit bitter for my personal porter taste, but pretty darn good.
Very thick dark brown, tan head.  Strong aroma of roasted coffee, alcohol and raisins.  More subtle but similar flavor with some malt.  Very smooth and simple finish.
On tap @ Coles Buffalo NY. Deep black in color with tan creamy head. Notes of chocolate & roasted malts. Beautiful porter. Easy drinking & delicious
I really like this beer.  Nice deep dark color, smooth feel and great taste.  Nice overtones of chocolate taste and roasted malts.

Black. Brown head leaves some lacing on the glass but otherwise disappears quite quickly. Roasted aroma, not very strong though. Malty, sweetish, liquorice... Even less bitter than I expected. Fine brew, very enjoyable, but I still find it lacking a little something... Will require a re-taste some day.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2007 Anchor Porter is not just great, but something that brewers should take note of, a prime example of why craft brewing in America is as great as it is.

When you look at the bottle, it appears frivolously austere, serious but unorthodox. The label appears to be from a generation ago, which invites you to taste a brew from a time when craft beer was the only beer available.

The porter is rich tasting, with subtle hints of chocolate and strongly roasted malted barley flavor. It is slightly carbonated with just a dash of sweetness; pouring a creamy beige head and hints of bitterness. It is solid and noble, just as the bottle shows.

Anchor Porter is the kind of beer you see on a menu at a neighborhood restaurant and recommend to friend who is looking for something other than Guinness.
Bottel.33cl. Sweet n nice porter, the aroma is just the way i like it. coffee, brown, brown foam, medium sweetness, medium bitterness.

(Bottle BB 06/2008) Roasted malty, chocolate and dark bread-like aroma. Black (reddish) colour, average size, brownish, slightly lasting head with good lacing. Strongly roasted, chocolate, coffee, dark bread and licorice flavour. Softly carbonated, dry and medium to full-bodied palate with a hint of alcohol. 04/02/07

12 oz Bottle poured into a Pint Glass. Black with a tanish head. Roasted coffee flavors with a bit of a smokey taste. Smooth, creamy and delightful. This is the porter that has taken me to the dark side.

12oz bottle - Black with creamy beige/offwhite, longlasting, head.  Aroma of roasted malt and walnut shell.  Flavors of semi-sweet chocolate, roasted coffee, and hint of walnut, with bitter hops finish.  Solid porter.

Bottle (by kind permission of Bierkoning): Extremely dark amber coloured with a small, but stable tanned head; stronger dry roast-malty and slightly sweetish-coffeeish nose with a touch of aromatic hops; slightly sweetish flavour, but mainly  solid bitter; medium-bodied, creamy oily texture; sweetish-bitter coffeeish-roast-malty finish. Pleasant brew from a sympathical brewery.............

This pitch back beer has a nice, creamy head. Its a nice porter, that is initially a bit thin, but it gains terrain in the flavour and the finish is long. It has notes of coffee, a bit of licorice and a nice bitterness. A really nice porter, but I think it is a bit to neutral in the long run, where I would prefer more bite.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2011 Black with an off-white lasting head. Aroma of malt, molasses, a bunch of dried fruit, chocolate and a hint of licorice. Malty flavour with sweet chcolate and toffee,  a good bitter and roasted finish.

Anchor porter is a solid black with a fluffy, creamy tan head that sticks around for a while.  It smells mildly of coffee in a wooden basement with a tenor fruity note in sea air.  The flavor starts with a snap of uglyfruit, fading to citrus skin and chocolate with coffee lingering underneath.  Its big and chewy, like a porter should be.  If someone asked me, "Whats a Porter like?", Id give that person this beer.

Bottle.  Strong dark chocolate and some roast in a scrumptious nose, lots of malt.  On the browner side of barely-translucent red, dark with a creamy, rocky light brown head.  Really a superb head, spoonable and worthy of a dozen pictures.  Lots of chocolate and light roast in the mouth, medium-light body (somewhat watery) with a dry, woody, toffee-and-roast aftertaste.  Dark chocolate note is lasting and is always lurking somewhere.  Tons of malt, light bitterness with a touch of terminal hoppiness.  Rich for a porter, but not overly so.  Touch of acidity and slightly less mocha.  Balanced and smooth.  Rather robust but with concomitant complexity.  I dont feel the slightest bit of regret about slapping down a high score - this is a true classic!

Bottle thanks to HogTownHarry. Pours a beautiful pitch black with a nice amount of head. Mouthfeel is creamy, and it smells like very dark chocolate. Taste is strongly of dark chocolate, with a very dominant character of marley barley that lasts for ages. Finish is bitter with a lingering flavour reminiscient of scotch accompanied by roasted barley and toffee. This one is quite the brew. Fairly heavy amount of lacing on the glass. A fine pleasure to drink.
On tap at Old Chicago.  Pours dark brown with a light brown head.  Taste has notes of toffee and hints of coffee and chocolate.  Has a dry hop finish.

Pours a dark brown with reddish tint and a caramel head.  Smells just like hersheys dark chocolate.  Just like it! No joke!  The dark chocoalte flavor appears in the taste along with a hint of roast. It finishes smooth and dry.  Loved this one.  Go buy it......now!
Faint sweet and roasty aroma. Flavor was light and smooth, a little sweet with some chocolate. It  was more mild than I would have liked
athick tan head takes some time to dissapate, good rich flavor of malt yeast and chocolate. tasty brew
Bottle. Very sweet aroma, like a baltic porter. Cola colour. Taste very nice bitter and sweet at the same time, with some smoke.

Bottle; pours an impenetrable dark brown black with a very nice two finger dark tan head that persists; great lacing.  Mild aroma of roasted malts and a touch of molasses.  Taste follows nicely with more roasted malts, chocolate and some espresso.  Very smooth and crisp on the palate with a bit of a bitter finish.  A nice porter that keeps up with its reputation, recommended.

Excellent but unusual porter that features a fairly sweet fruitiness up front with a mildly bitter, dark roasted maltiness and a yeasty flavor taking over in the finish; The fruity sweetness also dominates the nose and is reminiscent of English style porters; Black in color and opaque; Large, frothy head is dark tan in color and has excellent retention; Lacing is stubborn at first, sliding down the glass rather than sticking, but eventually grabs hold in small amounts
Aroma is very rich almost like a nice red wine, the taste is unbelievable.  A perfect match of mild sweetness and a blast of bitter.  MMmmmm

Ive tried several poters and even brewed a few. My mainstay seems to be the Bells Porter and that is my mainstay. This one just didnt seem to stack up . Though drinkable I probably wont have this again. There are better porters to be had and was somewhat dissappointed with this offering out of a 12oz. bottle. A little on the bitter side for a porter and not as smooth as I would have liked..I dont know sorry not everyone can have a Bells porter on draft but it is great to live in the Midwest where we have access to such great beers!

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2007 (bottle)poured into a pint.  I am a huge porter fan and this one is one of the tops.  A dark porter that pours a thick frothy head( 1 inch in my pint) to the rim that sticks and does not dissipate.  Has a light creamy/nutty nose.  Very smooth on the palate, not too bitter, and a little creamy.  It has a medium finish.  This is a great porter.

Bottle poured a translucent blackwith red highlights and a large lasting amber head. Aromas of roasted malt, charcoal and a hint of chocolate. Palate was light to medium bodied, smooth yet crisp. Flavors of roasted malt, a hint of coca and charcoal with a crisp moderatly bitter finish.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2007 Bottle. 35.5 cl. Black with a thick brown head. The aroma is nicely roasted and smokey with hints of capucino and chocolate. Well carbonated creamy palate. Taste of coffe, liqurice and lightly burnt roasted malts.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2012 First rating(At Haket, Göteborg) Dark brown to black color, brown head. Acidic light roasted sweet grainy malty scent. Acidic taste with some chocolate and light burnt aftertaste. Smoth mouthfeel. Medium bitterness. Sweet chewing gum, salty.6/3/6/3/13=3.1Rerate(Bottle from Systembolaget)Sweet, raissin, roasted taste. Metallic, roasted, sweet scent. Black color, tan head. Medium to smooth mouthfeel, medium bitterness.7/4/7/3/14=3.5Rerate(Bottle from Systembolaget)Blind tasting on September 27, 2008Shady dark red to brown color, brown head. Sweet, raissin, licorice, alcohol scent. Raissin, sweet, licorice taste. Roasted aftertaste. Medium to thin mouthfeel, low bitterness.7/4/7/3/14=3.5Rerate355 ml bottle at The Golden Days, Göteborg.On February 11, 2012. BB 8/2013Clear very dark red to black color, big fluffy lasting coffee with cream light brown head. Roasted, fudge, sweet, malty, caramel, grainy scent. Malty, raissin, sweet, fudge taste. Grainy, coffee, fudge, roasted aftertaste. Medium to a bit moussy mouthfeel, medium high bitterness that lingers to the dry chalky side with some tongue bite to it.8/5/7/3/15= 3.8
dark brown/black in colour with thick creamy toffee coloured head. Disapated quickley. Plum and rasin aoma. Coffe and malt flavours but short in the palate.

Im a big fan of  this guy.  Attractive bottle (always a plus for me, and part of the reason why I dislike purchasing Rogue and Stone beers). Great rich brown color that doesnt disappoint on the palate. Doesnt linger too long in the mouth, but thats ok. Nice low level of carbonation that reminds me of English porters. Definitely a beer  Id purchase again.

Pours a very dark brown with a thin cap of tan foam. Sparse lacing. Sweet dark malt and plum in the aroma.

Tastes of robust dark roasted malt, full of bitter chocolate, with mild coffee undrtones. Drier and a bit spicy in the finish and aftertaste. Very flavorful.

Medium to full body, nicely carbonated. An excellent beer in a style that admittedly is not among my favorites.

Bottle.  Deep brown color, thicker than your average beer with a nice head, no lacing. Aroma is of hops, toasty chocolate.  Mouthfeel is pretty thick, oily, a little hops and cola in the taste and goes down smoooooth.

Bottle.  Damn, the more Anchor I have, the more I love them.  This is just a classic looking porter.  Deep mahogany with a perfect sized head and the perfect consistency.  Not too thick, not too seltzery.  Nice aroma of dark chocolate and hops.  Doesnt sound like theyd go together, but, who knew?!  Great roasty, earthy, almost gritty mouthfeel.  One sip is loaded with bakers chocolate, the next milk chocolate, but it never gets close to cloying.  Excellent porter

Big thanks to HogTownHarry for sending this to me.  Pours a deep brown body, almost black with a nice centimeter thick tan head.  Aroma of malted chocolates and sugar.  Taste is rather roasty, nice chocolate with some additional hops in the taste, light spice accents as well.  Ending is smooth yet lightly hot on the tongue.

Poured a midnight red with a standard head.  Nice little aroma, reminding me of a neighborhood coffee shop.  Flavor is magnificent coffee, toffee, and dark baked fruits.  Excellent porter.  (#2643, 1/7/07)

NIce, relatively light, aroma of chocolate and malt. Through halgen the color is brown ruby, but without it is opaque. A nice tan head that does not wholly dissipate, and actually laces a bit. Medium mouthfeel that tends to collapse quickly as the mild carbonation leaves. The start is mild chocolate, and there is no toasted character. Some hop pops up, but its not strong. Very smooth, and it finishes relatively dry. Extremely drinkable.

I think that my old age is changing my tastes. A number of years ago I had Anchor Porter quite often. It was OK but It seemed too malty for me. Now with my latest tasting, I am very pleased. It truly lives up to its reputation of being an excellent porter. Quite robust but only medium maltyness. with a bit of a chocolate flavor. Slightly sweet and possesses a nice bite. It has a nice foamy head that dissipates a little too quickly
It has an black appearance and fells great in the mouth.
This is a really nice beer.

Bottle.   Pours a dark brown color, with a medium sized tan colored head, nice lacing.   Aroma is roasted malt, some coffee, faint hops.   Flavor is sweet, roasted malt, coffee, mild chocolate.   Palate is medium, medium carbonation, bitter finish.   Solid, a benchmark porter for me.
Black colour with a nice long lasting head. Aroma of well roasted malts and hops, some sweetness. Creamy flavour with nice roastiness from the malts, chocolate, coffee and hops. Great brew!

Cola-like pour.  Two-finger tan head that is fizzy and doesnt hang around long.  The aroma is sweet initially, with the malt coming through along with some caramel.  As it opened up the aroma of soy sauce became more powerful.  The flavor was a benign mix of caramel, roasted malt and soy sauce.  The mouthfeel was thin and somewhat fizzy.  I felt like it was too sweet and didnt have the smoky, dry finish to balance it out.

12oz bottle.  Dark brown hue with a spiral off-white head.  Toasty, malty chocolate nose.  Little cocoa and spice.  Medium to full bodied.  Coffee and chocolate flavors with a sweet cola fruity malt note.  Delicious and toasty.  Sweet and cloying.  Great flavor.  Amazing!

A beauty of a porter. What a supprice. A smell, a taste.  I expected a moderate porter not complex, a beer for the crowd.  This beer you can serve at a dinner or drink it near the fire with a cigar (I dont smoke) and a cognac (I prefer beer) and a book (I have read one already).

Draught.  Pours black with a moderate brown head.  Weak aroma of sweet roasted malt and chocolate.  Stronger flavor, also of sweet roasted malt and chocolate, with bits of molasses and coffee, and finishing slightly woody.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Definitely sweet and rich for a porter.  Pretty good.

22oz bottle on christmas night... the first time that i had this beer I was in a traffic jam on my way to a phish concert with slam and sean.... yummy bitter coffee flavors dominate this excellent porter...  Ive got a speedway stout up next, and it is one of the few dark beers that can top this one for me.... this is my favorite anchor offering.

Bottled - This is a wonderful porter.. This is my 2nd Anchor beer.. and man its a great one..   Pours almost completly black with no highlights...Aroma is lots of sweet malts and ripe fruit... Taste is amazing.. lots of roasty
malt...caramel..with a balanced bitterness.. awsome beer.. and might i add  THIS PUTS ME IN THE 100 BEER CLUB... YEA BUDDY!!

Still, in my opinion the best porter available! Period!! Pours black as night with a one-finger tan head. Nose of roasted malts and hints of caramel. Deliciously malty on the tongue with a good balancing bitter that reminds one of espresso or perhaps bakers chocolate. Incredibly drinkable! Will always be one of my favorites!

Sweet malt.
appareance is bang on. 
nice full feel to it. very nice porter, one fo the better ive had in a while
very very nice.

Aroma is mostly sweet malt.  The pour is black with a thin tan head.  A nice full palate hits you with flavors of sweet coffee and some mollasses.  Hop bitterness comes through in the finish.  Quality stuff.

Roasty malts weigh heavy on the aroma from this slightly brownish black porter.  A light caramel head with large bubbles reduces quickly.  The flavor is rich, creamy, lightly roasty, and filled with a mild bittersweet caramel/coffee flavor.  Fairly complex and very tasty.  The mouthfeel is creamy smooth and has a long finish.  Overall a great porter.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2006 12oz 6AL - Tight bubbles rising through a volcanic black liquid, leaving a creamy beige head and some superior lacing.  Licorice and pine on the nose, creamy chocolate, malt, then fading to hops on the palate.  This is a party in a glass.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2007 An okay Porter. Pours pitch black with a thin off-white head. This is my my first beer from Anchor, and I will only come back to it if I need to. Not very aromatic, but has has great espresso flavor that starts our bitter but has a strong vanilla after taste. Cheers
This is a really good porter.  Very smooth and creamy, with coffee undertones and a wonderful dry finish.  Well done.

Poured a dark black; creamy beige head.  Aroma of caramel malt and chocolate; would have liked it to be stronger.  I found it a little thin/light on the palate.  Flavor was very complex, got better with each taste.  Flavors of malt and chocolate. Caramel.  Coffee and licquorice also.  Above average for me, but expected more.

This classic porter features a full body, creamy brown head, and a healthy roasted barley flavor.  This is a good one for when you want a full-bodied beer to have with dinner but for some reason do not want a stout.
Interesting beer. The aroma is nice - but it is barely there, as are the flavors - I would love to see how this beer would taste if it was more concentrated.

This was the first Anchor beer I ever had; I believe it was 1999.  And it made an impression on me then as a good beer.  That hasnt changed...this is a very good porter.

Appearance is of a dark, nearly opauque reddish brown with a dark tan head.  Also, this product comes in the unique Anchor bottle.

The aroma of Anchor Porter is of caramel and sweet alcohol (not hop) esters.  It is a pleasant smelling product.

Taste is of chocolate with a definite alcohol component which is not at all unpleasant.  There is a slightly sour malt taste which accompanies the lingering alcohol taste.

This is a pretty sticky porter.  The caramel malt seems to build on the back of my tongue.

Drinkability wise...I am happy Im drinking this beer at this particular moment, but I think when Im done with it Ill have something else.

i love this one. definately my favorite, but not to get drunk off of. this beer is to be sipped and enjoyed. its really a masterpeice. i would call it perfectly balanced. this beer is to be savored. no drop wasted. mmm... anchor porter. so good. so so good. drinking one right now.mmmm mmm...so good.
12 oz bottle. Poured dark black with small tan head. Big nose of chocolate and coffee.  Rich mouthfeel.  Flavor is rich of chocolate and burnt malts.  Very nice hoppy finish. An excellent porter.
Get some sweet malt and slight alcohol in the aroma.Pours black with very little head.Get some dark fruits in the flavor.A little thin.Well carbonated.Has a sweet finish.

Bottle. Thick motor oily black color. Head was medium and very dark creamy like. Duration of head was medium disappearing. Impressive array of flavors hits the nose at first sniff. Aroma was liquorish, slight smoke and roasted, light coffee and chocolate with some light hops catachrestic in there like floral and herbs and yeasty notes like leather, earthy. Medium to full bodied. Flavor was medium bitter, with a bitter finish.

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2007 Yes, its THAT good. Textbook porter appearance, very dark brown with a dense and longlasting tan head & good lacing. Aroma of vanilla, hazelnut, dark chocolate, espresso, dark sugar and myriad of other things. The taste is very rounded and full-bodied, roasty malty dry with lush vanilla hazelnut sweetness. Very long finish like an espresso. Mouthfeel is thick and pretty heavy on the carbonation.

This beer pours a black color, there is basically no opacity to this thing!  Lots of deep roasted coffee and chocolate flavors.  Drinks very smoothly as a porter should!  This is a well crafted beer, but then again I am a fan of the porters...  Cheers!

Pours  dark cola color with a tan frothy lasting head. Smells malty. Toasted flavor of malt and possibly a little coffee. Slightly bitter for my tastes. Its alright, not my favorite, but good. Worth a try.

Nice aroma with a good balance between chocolate and liquorice. The flavor is chocolately and also of liquorice, again nicely balanced, but towards the aftertaste there is also some fruity notes, almost banana-like. This beer looks great with its completely black colour and its nice head,
and it also feels fine with its good mouthfeel and the rather lazy carbonation.  However, when you are used to 7-8 % ABV baltic porters it can feel a little watery, but not too much, though...
Bottle. Black as night with a creamy off-white head. Wonderful roasted malt, slightly sweet flavor with just a hint of hops. Smooth as cream. This is one fine beer.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2007 pours black with a nice one finger dark tan head and medium body. light hoppy, roasty malt smell with a little alcohol and licorice. descent lacing and the flavor is roasty malt with licorice and a little hops, also has a little coffee and a very small alcohol aftertaste. very smooth and very nice porter though. i am starting to like the anchor beers a little more this being my second and liberty ale being my first which was very good as well!
very dark with a small head. roasted malt and hints of chocolate. Not the greatest porter but a good example

Very nice dark dark brown body with a dark tan head. a smell of carmel and roasted malt. Not as smooth as the other porter I have rated but very good.  It does have just a touch more bitterness at the end.

Bottle. Pours black as night with a tall frothy tan head that left thick lacing. Sweet chocolate and caramel aroma. The flavor found roasted malts and coffee. Medium body with a coffee aftertaste. One of the best porters Ive had in a while. Nicely done.
This is quite simply one of the best Porters that Ive ever tried.  The Anchor Brewery sure can kick out some fantasitc beers!

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2007 Suprising one here.  Anchors brews are above average, but this one takes it up a few notches.  Solid roasted malt flavor with respectable hops up top.  Increases intensity as swallowed.  Very nice.
deep dark brown with tan head.  Roasty malty nose with a little yeasty hoppy bitterness.  Medium palate with sweet and roasted malts.  Slight yeasty, hoppy bitter finish.  Not a bad porter.

Pours close to black with a frothy tan head.  Aroma has rich chocolate malts with some roastiness and vanilla cream.  Medium body with lots of smoothness and moderate carbonation.  Taste starts with roasted malt with vanilla notes with some chocolate as well.  Very velvety.  The finish has a bit of spice and charred malt.  Very nicely done porter.

Aroma: initially strong soy sauce & malt giving way to toffee and lightly roasty notes. Appearance: black with a great tan head that leaves patchy lacing, darker than I am used to for a porter but looks great. Flavour: gentle carbon notes, malty, nutty with a great mocha overtone. Palate: thick and rich with lingering mocha notes. I was really looking forward to this then got a bit turned off by all the soy sauce nose but am thoroughly enjoing it. Next bottle will have to look at rerating as this porter is a better stout than half the stouts I have ever tried.
UPDATED: JUL 23, 2007 Bottle.  Black, brownish pour with a tan head.  Very nice looking.  Nice roast malt flavor, fairly light body for a Porter to me.  Sweet and dry finish.

Anchor Porter
12 oz bottle
Unknown brewing (batch number 5SS), lifted 11/06
Medium pour in an English pint glass.

Poured black with clear brown highlights with an average frothy light brown mostly lasting head.

Smelt of strong chocolate, toffee, cola, licorice, creamy coffee.

Taste was upfront moderate sweet licorice candy followed by a strong mild coffee bitterness and moderate continuation of the licorice on a short to average dark chocolate finish.  Mouthfeel was light to medium bodied, softly carbonated, creamy, with light astringency.

Overall, this porter looks great, smells great, and tastes good.  Could use a nudge more strength on the taste, and a little bit more body.  An awesome summer porter nonetheless.
Super-fantastic. If you love beer, you must sample this one. Anchor is such a good brewer, they have few if any "misses" and this is one of their signature beers.
12 ounce bottle.  Pours a rich chocolate brown with a tan head.  Aromas of char, choco, and coffee.  Bitter chocolate flavors with a clean dry finish.

Near black with some mahogany highlights.  Large fluffy tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, and coffee.  Flavor is more of the same, with the chocolate becoming more noticeable.  Some hop bitterness is the finish.  Very nice.

.

poured nicely with a thick brownish head and fine beads of carbonation.  Malty, roated dark chocolate/coffee aroma.  Tastes like it smells.  Chocolate malt asserts itself without overpowering. Very nice balance of dark malts and hop bitterness.  No hop aromas to get in the way of the malt.  Good balance of dextrines.
very very nice!!!!! Had at beer bistro in T.O. very tasty lotsa chocolate notes on nose and taste , good dark choc malts with some hops, very easy drinking

This truly is an exceptional beer. Beautiful color, and an impressive head to match. Aroma is of toffee/coffee, and the flavor profile is a pleasant, heightened extension of that. Anchor Brewing can, and should, be very proud of this one.
12 oz bottle totally stolen from my Uncles house. Sable with a light brown head. Rich, chocolatey malt nose and flavor. Mochalike notes. Very lightly hopped, almost an afterthought. Nice.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a dark brown with ruby highlights.  It has a huge big-bubbled fluffy light brown head that retains well and laces the glass.

The aroma is very subdued - lactic chocolate and tar and a little coffee.

The flavor is sweet chocolate with some tangy and sour fruitiness and a bitter roasted finish.  Its kind of a mis-mash of disjoint flavors.  It smooths out as it warms (and thankfully loses much of the sour tanginess).  The mouthfeel is medium to full and pretty creamy.

Overall, its a decent porter.  Definitely better warmer.
My first porter.  Pours great, rich black with a wonderful head.  Aroma lets you know that youre in for a treat.
UPDATED: JAN 9, 2007 my first porter..enjoyable in a heavier stout kind of way. very malty and thick. A winter warmer for sure

wow. what a great beer. pours beautiful solid black with a beautiful brown head that leaves beautiful lacing. great mocha aroma with just a hint of hops. very balanced bittersweet mocha flavor. bittersweet medium dry finish. medium-full wonderfully creamy mouthfeel. carbonation so creamy its hard to notice. wonderful. clean simple solid flavors.  i love this beer.

Walking around in Bevmo today, this one caught my eye.  I said to myself, "I havent had Anchor Porter in 10 years, I bet"  So, with that, seconds later, I was in line purchasing this six pack ($7.99) and I was out the door.  Damn Bevmo in Mission Valley is a crappy store.  Nothing else worth a damn.......but, I digress.........So, this beer smells amazingly good.  The head is really quite nice.....very tan, with tons of lacing.  Surprisingly, this one tastes alot like a traditional british porter, or at the very least much more "european" than I am used to.  Not a bad thing, just a very different beer.  Overall though, its a very nice, well crafted beer.  Im glad I picked it up.
Pours opaqe with a thick tan head. smells choclatly or sweet. Dark malty taste with a fresh bitter hoppy finish. Great porter. Goes down very refreshing.

Nice tan thick head that dissipates quickly.  DARK brown, almost black color.  Beautiful aroma and even better initial taste.  The palate doesnt stay with you long, but this is a nice quality to the beer in my mind.  This is a beer I could enjoy every night of the week.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a nice tan head on top. Aroma is full of malt. Most a chocolate scent is coming from the beer. Smelling also hints of vanilla, nuts, and fruit. Flavor is very rich. A nice smooth chocolate taste dominates the flavor of the beer. I can also taste the hints of vanilla and even toffee in the flavor of the beer. Hops are in there also to help balance the beer out, keeping it medium bodied and not sweet. A very nice porter!

Pours near black with a decent brown head. Has a predominantly chocolate scent. Creamy dense body. Smooth chocolate like maltyness. Nice kilned touch, slight metallic element, with a light anise/licorice hint and a late balancing bitterness. Nice porter.
Flavorful and dark.  Taste rich and creamy...smooth is a good word.  Definatley taste the barley, which I enjoy.  Not bad for an almost commercial brew.
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text:
bottle.  nice rich flavor.  Perfect portfer flavor, no off-flavors.  Beautiful dark DARK brown color, small / no head.  Creamy, a light carbonation, great palate.  
A bit too sweet maybe?  Some citric acid would balance it.  It seems too sticky in the mouthfeel.  

Definitely one of the more enjoyable porters Ive had though.
Draught. Dark dark brown with khaki head that left some lace. Milk chocolatey aroma. Flavor is more complex with chololate, toffee, raisin, and sweet cream notes. Tasty.
Pours black with a milk chocolate head. Wow, this porter is delicious!  The flavors explode with roasted cocoa, hops, raisins, and fresh coffee beans.  I love the fact that this finishes bitter.

Roasty and very fruity.  A whole lot of raisin.  Some cherry and cinnamon as well.  Brown sugar and molasses.  Maybe a bit woody (charred wood).  Cocoa.  Wickedly smooth and creamy.  Chocolatey.  Very different for the style, but very good.  Dry, despite the fruitiness.

Thick, creamy, nearly putty brownish head, slightly irregular and leaving lacerings over ebony beer. Very chocolatey nose, as a creamy chocolate sauce for desserts; hints of tobacco, very lightly smoked and faraway C-hops. Powerful and delicate at the same time, balanced. Dry, smokey flavour with more tobacco and even ashes than the chocolate from the nose. Again just this suspicion of noble USA-hops. Gradually filling in with a discreet acidity from roasted barly and smoked grains, and the essence of unsweetened cappucino. Again wonderful balance. Not rich as a stout, but dry enough, and velvety. Again: excellent balance. Long lingering coffeeish-tobacco aftertaste. Very good porter. Americas oldest surviving craftbrewer has lost nothing of its aim for perfection.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2006 The aroma is very nice with lightly roasted coffee scent and hints of nuts and vanilla.  The color is dark blackish brown with no light showing through and a dark brown head.  The taste moves from medium sweetness through sourness and a light bitter finish with hints of coffee and vanilla and a slight citrus quality.  The carbonation was mild, creamy on the palate and a lively long finish.  Very good overall, not to strong and no hint of alcohol.  Very smooth. This is one of my favorite beers to drink on a regular basis and the price is right.
Fantastic aroma with huge head. Light body with lots of fruit, slightly sweet finish. Good porter

Botlle.Poured dark brown with smallish fine top. Quality quality nose, medium dark roast, brown sugar and nuts, dried fruits as well. Good medium bitter roasted character stretched along the way. Light hoppy top and acidic below just adds to character. Reminds me of the old school Baltic Porters just this one is smaller brother. Very nice.

Pours very dark with large bubbled light brown head. First aroma seems a bit fruity almost like a barelywine. Then some dark roasted malts, breadiness and chocolate malts intercede. The flavor starts off mild and then some malt sweetness and roasted malts build up toward midway with a hint of dark fruit. The taste ends with a nice roasty maltiness.
Nice and very drinkable.  Pours very dark with a big brown head.  Flavor was straight up malt, with a touch of chocolate and dark molassass.  Nice finish.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2008 very thick, carmel-colored head. Stings my tongue a bit.  A found it to be--like all Anchor beers--more bitter than other brands.  I drank it right after a Sierra Nevada porter and ultimately determined that the Sierra was better.  I guess I find the bitterness in Anchor beers to be overpowering; the Sierra, in contrast, allows you to experience its other flavors.

Satisfyingly rich, complex porter. Firm, creamy body with chocolate and fruit (subtle banana character) in the aroma and flavor; nice bitter hop/sweet malt balance mid-palate; mild alcohol warmth in the finish followed by a host of flavors in the aftertaste: coffee, molasses, yeasty dark bread, and a pleasant hop bitterness.

This is a great beer.  Very, very tasteful.  Might be much for the pilsner drinker!  It has a nice bite and a pleasant aftertase.  Very strong flavors!  I liked this and am now going to try the other anchor beers.
Dark black body with a small light brown head. Sweet caramel and molassas aroma. Sweet chocolate and roasted malt flavor with some fruit in the end.
Nice dark poor with red/tannish head. Hint of sweet/chocolate flavor. Clean finish with no after taste.
Bottle. Black color with a heavy tan head.  Big flavor of coffee and a hint of chocolate.  Very smooth and easy to drink.
Bottle. Nice big lasting tan head. Color is close to black. Aroma is roast malt with hints of chocolate, coffee and licorice. Taste is likewise.
12 oz. bottle, a deep brown colour with a large rocky beige head. Very different palate than most. Hop bitterness was first, then the roasted malt in the finish.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2007  Black shaded brew that shows lots of fizz, with aroma heavy on rye and pumpernickel, some chocolate.  Licorice leads, but the sweet flavors are gently swallowed by heavy, bready malts.  Thickly textured, a classic porter.
Dark amber/brawn with intens brown foamy head. Malt, rye and chocolate and hints of frsh black pepper. Bitter finish but a very pleasent porter.

Poured from the bottle, a deep brown colour with a large rocky beige head. A rich warming chocolate malt aroma with a burnish tinge. Rich and chocolately to taste with a vinuous and roasted malt finish. Left with a velvety smoothness in my mouth - yum.

Very dark brown with a dark beige head. Quite a subdued aroma, perhaps a little chocolate malt. The taste is truly delectable. Theres a delicate balance between the medium dryness and the sweet, coffee and chocolate maltiness.  Dark beer at its very best.
Dark color.  Dark copper color.  Very different palate than most.  Hop bitterness was first, then the roasted malt in the finish.  Very nice all around porter.

[Drauhgt at Tatoverede Enke]

So smooth and wellbalanced that I can drink it for hours. One of my favorite beers, which I always buy more than one of.
Just not that impressed with this.  It had a bit of a coffee aftertaste mixed with a bit of chocolate, unfortunately not a good combination for me when it comes to a great beer.

Bottle. Almost black with beautiful mostly lasting light brown "espressofoam" head. Burnt malt, coffee and bitter chocolate in the nose. Liqorice ass well in the flavor. Nice balanced, but somewhat "light" porter. A beer for the ladies!

Dont know what it is about this porter, as they are usually my favorite style, but this is one of my least favorite (which, of course, still makes it better than a lot of beers). First time I tried it I just thought it was a bad bottle, but now have had on draft and still wasnt impressed. Feel can do much better when it comes to porters.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2012 Tap at Cockney Pub. Creamy lightbrown good fully lasting head. Moderate malty light hoppy strange soapy aroma. Nice powerfull licorice flavor. Very sweet finish. Oily palate. Had better Porter.

Presentation: This beer comes in a very unique short stubby bottle. A good addition for bottle collectors.


Appearance: This beer pours motor oil back, with a slight red hue (maybe mahogany). Looks black as it sit in my beer stein. Huge 3 finger muddy brown head, very thick. Nice lacing. 


Smell: I got little out of the smell. It was not very aromatic, but after searching I did find a bit of burnt chocolate, toffee and a distinct toastedness to it.

Taste: Sweet smooth malts and maple syrup. It had a bit of red to the malts (whatever that means). The aftertaste had a bit of green floral hops that left a slight bitter taste on the tip of your tongue. Overall rather balanced. 


Mouthfeel: A bit thin; light / medium; OK for an American Porter. (I tend to prefer the English). The mouthfeel was creamy and very smooth, also a bit syrupy.


Drinkability: Not incredibly interesting but adequately tasty and quite easy to drink. That makes this a very good everyday porter but nothing super special.


Hope this is helpful.
Cheers!
Dark brown color with a firm brown head. Lots of hops, chocolate and coffe notes. Very good balance between sweetness and hops. Medium to full body with a long aftertaste.

Nicely hopped porter that looks really nice in the glass. Low carbonation gave it a really good texture as it hits the tongue. The hops are a little agressive, but make for a nice nose and a long slightly bitter finish that is almost dark chocolate like.

Bottle:  This is a nice porter.  This tan head that stayed throughout the beer.  Nice smell of malts and toffee.  Very smooth mouthfeel.  Drinking this is like eating a four course meal, it was extremely thick.

Deep Deep brown pour, so close to black.  The head is tan and foamy.  The aroma has no noticable hops, the malts seem to be light and there is a sweet coffee hint in there too.   The hops are present, althought very slight, in the nose, the malts are very smooth.  The coffee aroma, is not as present in the flavor.  There is a slight after taste after the slow finish.  There is also a tad more carbination than I like, although...that is a  personal preference.  Good porter.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2008 I absolutely love this beer.  Pours with a dark tan head with aroma of chocolate/coffee. Smooth, with the proper amount of carbonation.  A must for any porter drinker and one of my favorite porters.

Botl.  Whoa-aroma of banana peanut butter, with a liquer marshmallow.  Unusual to say the least.  Blackish mahogany beer with browner beige tight head.  The crazy thing is, it pretty much tastes like the aroma, without any artificiality, and with an added touch of porterness - the roasted beans, but with a fruit sundae on top.  Definitely a unique beer that deserves the kudos.  Palate is nice roast with a modestly alcoholic sensation in the finish.

A very dark pour that you cant see through when you hold it up to the light. An aroma of sweet roasted malt, raisins, and alcohol. I know at 5.6 it should not come through but it did. A crisp clean flavor for a porter nice maltliness. A nice smooth rich palate with a good bitter finish. A very good beer. If it were just a little sweeter it would have been great for me.

Bottled. Beer is a very dark, opaque, used motor oil-brown color with a large, light brown, frothy/creamy, mostly diminishing head. Pretty. The aroma is malty with moderate-to-heavy notes of blackstrap molasses and the palest of milk chocolate, light notes of roasted grain. Interesting that the grain note gets subducted under the sweeter tones; Hoppy with a moderate note of resin/pine; Yeasty with a light note of dank basement, yeasty sweet dough, trace of Vegemite; Lots of miscellaneous notes, including heavy notes of raw wood, burbon and raisin, light notes of top soil, underripe banana, licorice. The flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter, lightly acidic with a long, lightly bittersweet, lightly acidic finish. The body is medium-to-full, the texture is almost-velvety and the carbonation is lively. Quite interesting.

Bottle. Pours a thick black color with a nice fat frothy head. Magnificent aroma of roasted malts and coffee. Taste of dark chocolate and expresso. The alcohol is welll hidden and balanced to show the beers full flavor. This is a very good, easy to drink Porter.
This is a very fine porter.  Theres notes of caramel, dark cherry,  a very slight coffee that is really secondary to the overarching malty sweetness.   Finishes smooth and clean.

Bottle. Pours ruby black with two-finger-high brown head. The aroma is chocolate and cellar must with some caramel and banana. The flavor has a lot of banana, with some dark chocolate, hints of pine, and a sweet finish with a bit of cedar. Very smooth. The banana and chocolate notes combine very well. I like it.

Bottled. Pours an opaque blackish brown with a dense and lacy brown head. The aroma is loaded with chocolate, caramel, and smoke. The body is creamy, almost full with fine carbonation. The taste starts with some sweetness featuring coffee, chocolate, caramel, and a lingering smokey bitter finish.
Bottle. Black body. NIce brown head. Malty flavor that is smokey. Smooth, but no my favorit porter

Pours black with a smallish dark tan head, nice lacing. First smell that hit me was of alcohol. Sweet chocolate and some roastiness followed with a little coffee. Flavor starts sweet, ends with a little bit of a burnt taste.
12 oz- Pours a dark black with a nice brown head. Strong coffee and chocolate is present in aroma and flavor. Better than expected.
12 oz. Bottle.  This beer has a great porter aroma.  Deep and rich with flavor, that slowly fades off your tounge.  Dont forget the great appearance!

bottle.  pours a very dark brown, close to black, with nice deep ruby highlights in the bottom of the glass. I found chocolate, some roastiness, and sweetness in the aroma.  Taste is light chocolate, some more predominant roast, coffee, and caramel.  The finish is a nice lingering roasty and hop driven bitterness.

12 oz. bottle although I cant wait to taste it on tap! The aroma wasnt as pleasing as the taste I will have to admit.  Extraordinary tasting-- the deep malty, chocolate and coffee; smokey flavors linger on the palate for an unsurpassed after-taste.  A porter that has a great body and overall solidity.

bottle.  Aroma:  Lots of toffee and caramel.  Some burnt notes coming through as well.  Hints of chocolate and coffe, as well.  A nice rich aroma.  Appearance:  Dark brown with garnet highlights.  Big, creamy, tan head soon collapsed into a cap over the top of the beer.  A little lacing.  Flavor:  Big maltiness upfront with hints of coffee, chocolate, smoke, and a little anise.  Hopping is subtle, but well done.  Palate:  Medium bodied.  Moderate carbonation.  Good dry finish.  Slight astringency.  Overall:  A solid porter, and very enjoyable.

12-oz. Pours a dark, predominantly opaque ebony black with amber highlights at the edges. Light layer of tan head that walks away whistling directly. Roast and sweet caramel on the nose. Plenty of sweet malt to balance the roast in the palate; from start to finish this is essentially a marriage between sweet and roast with a bit of hop flourish at the end. Some fizz in the body, and it stands up well, but its somewhere between chewy and quenching and Im not sure whether I like it--sometimes yes, sometimes no. This is a very good example of what I would consider a mainstream porter.

Bottle: Brown to black color, Medium light tan head that faded quickly. Aroma chocolate and vanilla, a fruity sweetness. Flavor, dark fruits, some roasty bitterness. Dry finish, medium bodied. Pretty nice porter.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2009 This porter has an almost sour taste, less roasty and more creamy, like a much darker version of an Oktoberfest.  The hops arent that strong, but theyre there and I like them.  As you drink this beer, its neither too sweet nor too sour, which is a good thing.  Normally I dont like porters that go down this road, but I think this one is alright, although I would prefer it to be much more bitter and have a stronger roast character to the aroma.  Bottom line: a very good beer, but not a very good porter.
Bottle shared with Janis. Black, brown head. Very nice malty, burned malts, sweetness, raisins and hop.
UPDATED: JAN 21, 2007 Black body. NIce brown head. Malty flavor that is smokey. Smooth. Good porter but not great.

Bottle.  I ranked this just under GL Edmund Fitzgerald.  Very nice porter.  Dark, deep brown color with with red tints.  Creamy, mocha colored head.  Hints of coffee and sweet fruits.  A very subtle alcohol flavor peeks through every once in a while.  Like most Anchor beers - great consistency and feel in the mouth.  A very good beer. I have not had a ton of porters so dont take my word for anything, but I thought this was very solid.

(Bottle at Haket, Göteborg) Pours very dark brown with light brown head. Smells sweet soy. Dried fruits, chocolate. Vineous. Some american hop. The taste is sweet, dried fruits. Some toffee. Barley. Salt. Chocolate. Finishes with coffeebeans. A very special porter.

Bottle.  Opaque black body with a thin vanilla colored head. about 1 mm thickness.  Roast, caramel, dark fruit and coffee aroma.  Taste is roasted nuts, combined with coffee and fig.  As this warms a nice bitter hoppy finish is detected.  A solid porter, not to the level of Alpha Klaus or Boulevard Bully Porter, but close.

UPDATED: APR 23, 2008 I liked this more chilled-- it seems to grow bland if it warms or loses any carbonation. The flavour is as unique as the bottle. I enjoyed the first few sips and then the flavour started to lose its appeal. I much prefer the Liberty ale which has some of the same feel to it. I like that it is not too sweet but prefer other porters.

Bottle: Poured a pitch-black color porter with a slightly above average foamy head with good retention. Aroma of roasted malt is well blended with some flavourful coffee.  Taste is a mix between well balance roasted malt and coffee with a medium bitter finish. Body is real creamy and quite full. Probably one of the best porter I have had so far.

This had a dark brown-black color.Aroma was biting malty.Head nice long lasting with deep maly look.Tasted like a stout.I liked this better than the Island brew and the Santa Barbara brewing co. stouts I tried.Had a biting almost green olive taste to it.I didnt really like the taste ,but I know it is good.I might buy again.

Whatever complexities it has are buried in the malty, molasses-y sweetness and pungency. Vanilla and banana in the aroma, nice head that dissipates soon. Sweet vanilla and chocolate in the flavor. Its heavier than a normal porter, to the point you might think youre drinking syrup. Too overwhelming to really enjoy.

Bottle: Interesting and creative porter.  It is black with a light borwn head.  The aroma is malty with sweet scents of dark chocolate and fruit.  The taste is exceedingly rich - ripe bananas, burnt ripe cherries, cloves and a little bit of smoke.  Not much hops, but quite complex malt structure.  It is thin and creamy, pretty smooth and not as oily or watery as other porters I have tried.  Pretty good.

Excellent porter, pours a thick dark brown head with a wonderful deep nutty aroma. Taste is some expresso mixed with chocolate and strangely but wonderfully enough a hint of bacon. Trust try it and yall will see.

Pours a deep reddish brown with a medium beige head.  Aroma of hazelnuts, caramel malts, biscuity malts, some roasted coffee malts.  Taste is of hazelnut, caramel malts, typical chalky burnt coffee finish.  Light bodied, moderate carbonation.  Very good porter.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Really good....Chocolate bar flavor, with a shot of espresso.  Thick and smooth mouthfeel, with a fair amount of carbonation.

Bottle. Very nice smell, full with charcater. Very dark of course with good head that stays. The flavor is very smooth and creamy with a nice malt presence. Very good porter.
Cheers!

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2006 Black color with a medium brown head that disapates pretty quickly but leaves decent lacing.  Nice strong malty aroma, with hints of dark chocalte and coffee.  Thin mouthfeel, the hop bitterness hit your right at the beginning and at the end.  Has almost a slight citrussy aroma and taste to it, you can also smell the alochol which is odd for a porter.  A nice rich porter taste, but could be a bit more heavy, and doesnt have the nice warmth to it that a lot of porters have.

Not bad if you havent had many porters.
This was the first porter i tryed and i loved it,but when i tryed others they were much better.
It has the trade mark porter taste but its not as strong as most.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2006 A classic porter which is pretty good.  A nice dark pour.  Tastes of fruit, coffee, and chocolate with some smoke and hoppyness in the finish.  Strong flavor with a good mouthfeel.
bottle. pours black. strong coffee flavour. roased malt. thick consistency. not the best but not bad. nice pallete.
UPDATED: MAR 12, 2008 Wonderful color and head. Rich, but still smooth enough to be a session beer. Has that certain maltiness that makes you pucker a bit. Good value. Wonderful brew.

Pours coffee black w/ a medium sized, semi creamy froth. Aroma is fruity w/ rasins. Full nectar w/ ample residual effers. Flavors are fruity, kinda bubblegumy w/ roasted coffee bean and cocoa tar. Overall: Its easy and full of flavor but more like bubblgum rock & roll popculture.

Black with tan head with good retention. Thin sticky lacing. Caramel and deep roasted malt. Very prominent sharp deep malt flavor. Dark chocolate and slight hops coming through. Good full mouthfeel. A good porter that finishes strong and lingers on the palate with coffee and caramel. Enjoyable beer. Cheers!

Very nice porter. Pour was typical of a stout with a head that was maybe subpar (but nice lacing). Aroma was raisin like with some light coffee. Flavor was somewhat sweet: maple, raisins, with a touch of coffee. Burnt flavors were nearly absent and the hops were only noticeable in the aftertaste (nicely done, since I dont like strong hops in my stouts). Mouthfeel was heavy but smooth and enjoyable. Ill come back to this one again.
