Bottle.Almost black in colour,small head,alot of fruit and roasted flavours coming through,thin tasting,nothing special for me.

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2005 Bottle, at No. 5.
Earlier 3.1 for: Draught, at Rover.
Black with a taste of burnt malt and licorice. Nice bitterness. Draught, oily and flat.

Poured black with a nice frothy chocolate head and thick lacing on my Chimay glass!
Very light malty aroma, almost nonexistent
 Medium body, chocolate and coffee flavor with a nice roasty, slightly bitter finish.
Very good!

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2005 i loved this beer, very dark with some rubis reflection with a small creamy head and smell like mocha and hops. The taste is great and robust for a porter, rosted, mocha and creamy, one of the best porter i ever tasted.

Une très bonne Porter, très opaque, avec quelques reflets rubis a peine perceptible, par contre sa mousse de couleur moka est légère, mais crèmeuse.  Au goût, elle est onctueuse, bonne amertume, le grain grillé et sa saveur de moka est prédominante et elle est assez gazeuse. Je la reccomande fortement.

Poured black with a brown head. Aroma
of malt. Also tastes of malt, with notes of chocolate and coffee. Much richer and thicker than mosts porters

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2005 Slight rerate based on a 6-pack purchased months after first review... Pours dark with medium viscosity, and I could smell it even as I poured.  Big head - about 3/4".  Smells great - coffee like, bitter, malty, nutty and oats.  Great sensation when it hits the tongue - smooth, with a bitter-sweet bite.  Full bodied.  Heavy duty lacing - looks like a snow storm.  A good porter.
Black, nice brown head. Aroma from chocolate, cream, coffe and some nutty tones. Flavor brings viol, licorice, cocoa and coffee. Some bitterness in the finish.

Bottle. Very dark brown with a nice tan head. Fades to a simple ring with mild lacing. Sweet strong coffee  and chocolate aroma with a little bit of fruitiness. Flavors of bitter chocolate and coffee and dark fruits, all burnt to a mild smokiness. Incredible. A slight sweetness lingers through all the way to the finish. Moderate carbonation and a substantial mouthfeel. The flavor lingers like an espresso chewing tobacco is lodged in your gums. Can be found almost everywhere, and is better than any other porter in most stores. Dont pass it up.
Nice aroma and well rounded head give way to a complex tase of bitter chocolate, mocha. One of my favorite porters.
I had never had a porter before this....definitely liked this one.  Very dark color.  Combines my 3 favorites, chocolate, coffee, and beer.  Highly recommended

the first thing i noticed after the pour was a bit of banana in the aroma,and thats a bit strange for a porter.as far as the body and head goes they were right on point.the first tip of the pint glass to my mouth gave me flavors of sweet malts,smoke,some b.b.q.,and a dash of hops.pretty good stuff although im a bit perplexed by the aroma.

bottle. sweet candyish aroma. black body with a small mocha head that quickly dies off. very sweet flavour as opposed to the very dry Sierra Nevada. this is a very rich and robust porter. long lingering bitter finish. Great stuff.
Not bad at all. The taste is on the light side but good enough to feel the smoked taste. Some hints of chocolate and hops gives it a decent aftertaste.

Well this is my first beer review, so you should probably disregard everything I say, but man, what a beer!! I dont think  Ive had a better beer let alone a better porter. It looks beautiful, pours a deep black with a little red in the light, with a nice tan head. The tase is perfectally balenced. A little sweet (from the smell mostly), a little bitter - like french roast coffee. I think I was expecting this to taste more like Guiness, but Im supprised and pleased that its much better. Dont pass this up if its on the shelf.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2006 Very dark brown/black pour supporting a creamy tan head with excellent lacing.  Aroma of chocolate, espresso, vanilla and roasted malt.  Just the right mouthfeel for a porter - silky and just slightly syrupy.  Flavors of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, some spice with just the mellowest hoppy backbone.  Finishes with a hint of sweetness and smoke.  Another brewer calls their porter "Perfect" but this one hits that mark dead on.

Bottle - 355ml. Opaque black body topped with a thin beige foamy head. Nice malty aroma with notes of roasted coffee, brown sugar and grapes. Delicious taste with various flavors of malt, roasted coffee, fruits and chocolate. Strong and long bitter finish with a subtle warming effect. Very nice porter.

Almost pitch black body with a small dense head. Lots of roasted malts in the aroma, with some bitterness from chocolate. Nice flavor with with a light roasted taste and some chocolate. Dry bitter finish.

Oh man.  One of the best porters ever.  Very caramelly, full flavored.  Crsp.  Dry.  Nice biting finish.  Not much I can complain about here, for sure.  If you havent tried it, you have no excuses.  Fullers still beats it.  Barely.
bottle. Color; dark, dark ruby black. Nice sweet malty aroma. Very sweet chocolate-malt taste. Nice slight hopped finish. This beer wowed me, so sweet and full flavored. I would reccomend this one!!

Sampled at the Virginia Touch in Berryville, Virginia.  Pours black with a good-sized off-white head.  Roasted, slightly chocolatey aroma.  More of the same in the flavor, slightly tart.  Very nice smoky finish.  Impressive.

a solid porter, pours dark brown, almost black, less than average head. thick burnt taste of caramel. it was impossible to drink this quickly. a wide bodied hearty porter, would probably be great with food.

Bottle. Black with cream/tan head. Low carbonation which is good. Full bodied with a strong burnt caramel molasses flavour. Tastes like this beer has been boiled to caramel, fairly bitter. OK but not really to my taste I prefer the Fullers Porter.

A deep brown color with a creamy tan head and sticky lacing.  The head retention is low, but maintains a decent layer.  Smells of malt, caramel roasted grains and coffee, with is a surprising presence of fruitiness.   Flavor has a rich sweet start and a roasty hop finish. Palate is medium to full bodied, creamy and effervescent with a full lasting bite at the end.  Anchor Porter maintains characteristics of a higher gravity beer with a good balance, and more chutzpa than many others of the style without going extreme.

Chocolate and vanilla aroma with caramel and fruit. Dark, dark brown in color with a beautiful dense tan head. Appetizing flavors of malt, caramel, coffee, chocolate, cola. Super rich in body. Finishes with a unique wine like quality and nice hop bite. One of the best porters in the world.

Pours dark brown with small tan head that lasts a minute. Sweet malt chocolate aroma. Some chocolate and coffee in the flavor, but something else I cant pinpoint. Maybe brown sugar? Very crisp dry finish.

Bottle: Rich, dark brown coloring. Nose contains hints of bitter-sweet chocolate, coffee, malt and a smack of hops. Smooth going down with the same coffee and chocolate esssence in the heavily roasted malt front-end but a nice amount of hops following to keep it non-cloying thus providing a clean finish. Top shelf!

Tasted at 54 degrees. Pours black with a khaki colored head. Sweet, roasted head, not spectactular. Drinking it with the frothy head, which sticks around awhile, is much like drinking a cappacino. Bittersweet chocolate, coffee flavors. The hops come through and add a flowery, citrusy flavor. Nice mouthfeel. I dont know why, but after it has sat for a few minutes and after I have taken a few drinks, the nose is a whole lot more apparent, and somewhat different from the first one.  It smells malty and sweet, there is something else, maybe a woodsy smell? Almost what bourbon might get from the cask, vanilla and smokiness.

Pours a rich, dark brown-black...with a frothy, thick head. Smells of stout coffee topped off with chocolate. Body is full and hearty, but very creamy. Just enough sweetness to make it feel like dessert, but not enough to be overpowering. Great coffee flavors mixed with molasses...good bitterness. The is a fantastic porter from a great brewery.

Nice dark pour. The color of strong coffee, with just a slight brown red glow. Moderate amount of fine carmel brown head. Very mild coffee aroma. Hints of black licorice and dark chocolate. The body is mouthfilling and satisfying, with just a fine flourish of tanic astringency to give it a clean finish. Very smooth coffee flavors, with a pleasant building bitter roast edge. Rewards slow sipping, and the flavors continue to develope as it warms. I am a fan. This is porter spot-on. Anchor may not make the biggest beer, but they sure make some of the most well balanced.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2005 This pours dark brown, almost black, and has a foamy brown head.  It smells malty sweet with an added chocolate aroma.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Its very sweet to the taste, but not cloyingly so.  Theres plenty of roasted malts, a hint of chocolate, and a touch of licorice.  Has a mild, sweet malt finsh.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Chicago, IL<font size=-1>
Second Great Anchor beer Ive tried. Pours Dark Black. Smells foody and savory. Starts coffee laced with fruit, resolves to seasame seeds and malt. Yummy

July, 2003: Bottle. "Wholly superior in every respect." I love the way brewers enthuse about their beers. I bet he also tells his wife hes got the biggest cock in the world. Brewers, theyre a bit like lawyers - you cant trust em. 
This is a damn tasty brew - full of roasty flavours and chocolate flavours, quite smoothly done. Nice winey quality - with just a hint of soft fizz. A very pleasant and easy drinking porter - not complex or demanding, just plain old fashioned tasty. Very enjoyable.

Big sweet chocolate aroma. Light fruits too. Medium soft body/feel. Black in colour with small brown head. Tasty chocolate start with a slightly fruity mid. Light coffee and chocolate bitter finish. Nice porter!
Black colour, smooth, a great porter, more on the light side, bittersweet flavor, good delicate coffee notes, very drinkable, highly enjoyable

Black with a good size tan head. Aroma 
of roasted malts, chocolate and coffee.
Very smooth malt flavor with hints of coffee, molasses and dark chocolate.

I had some on tap at Growlers in St. Louis and it was excellent.  About a week later I bought a six pack and it was good but not as good as what I had on tap.  Great appearance.  A chocolate coffee thing going on with the taste.  Id put the tap batch I had ahead of Bully Porter but the bottle behind the Bully.
Had a great aroma and moderate head.  Dark brown color.  It had a litttle bit of a bitter coffee taste.  I was a little disappointed overall.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2005 Creamy head. Malty aroma. Fantastic brew!  Definitely goes into the regular rotation. Doesnt taste nearly as dark as it pours. Nice roasty but not smoky flavors; hope that make sense? Extremely smooth & drinkable. Some fruity flavors.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2005 Roasty flavor of coffee and chocolate, with some bitterness and a tartness. Lots of body and silky smooth.  A very good porter. Complex flavor and quality all around, but not as yummy delicious as Fullers London Porter. (4.0)  ..... 3/5/2005 ,,,,,  rerate .....  five months and close to 100 beers later I pick up a sixer to give this another go. I am much more impressed the second time.  Maybe not exactly equal to the Fullers, but dont miss by much..  Damn near perfect for a porter, and the price makes me smile..  $7.74 for a sixer.  Cheers!  (4.1)

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2009 High tannish head that fades fast. Aroma is rich dark chocolate and deep coffee. 
Flavor profile is huge for a porter, very complex. Dark roasted malts with heavy coffee and dark chocolate overtones with a slight nutty feel, combined with a decent aftertaste kick of hops and light cherry and date accents. Very drinkable and refreshing.

High tan-coloured head, but not very long-lasting. Aroma reminds of coffee, a bit of dark chocolate. The colour reminds very much of a Guiness, and the flavour is quite filling, a bit bitter but not too much. A very good porter and a very nice experience on the whole.

Very drinkable with a very dark apparance and full body.  Nice head on this beer with a non-offensive hoppiness...   Been staying away from beers west of the Miss.,  anfet tasting both Anchot and Sierra Porters, time to start re-visiting...

Bottled. Looks and pours like a Guinness, just with a slightly foamier head. Smells and tastes wonderful, like a whiff of Hershey bar hiding a more subtle sloe gin cherry. The texture is a little bit grainy, yet also mellow. Not a harsh note to be found. This is indeed one of the worlds great porters.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2005 typical porter app. w/ black body and light brown head...aroma of roasted chocolate and coffee notes...flavor is much more complex and defined with rich chocolates, coffee, toffee, nuts, cream....splendid aftertaste and coating of the mouth....tremendous effort and achievement by Anchor in regards to this phenomenal porter....

Nice dark brew- similar to the Russian Imperial Stouts Ive been drinking the past few days. Nice,  hoppy & thick black brew. Head was quick to fade. Hints of coffee, vanilla, dark chocolate in this unassuming bad-boy. A little watery, but all in all, a great one!

Fresh, sweet, milky, chocolate aroma with light hints of roasted malts. Darkest brown, opaque body with lavish, pillowy, brown head that lasts throughout the tasting. Fruitiness up front recedes to reveal the thick chocolate flavour which plays out to a restrained roastiness in the dry finish with some light smokey notes. Full-body with heavy, thick, viscous and syrupy mouthfeel. Bottle.
really nice, but really expensive, not too sure about the level of maltiness, could be a bit more of a bitter taste

Thin 0.5cm head is foamy, tan, never leaving. Body is dark brown, almost opaque. Aroma is typically porterish with direct barley flavors and a small lactic bite. Rich chocolate and anise flavors. Nice range of fruitiness reminiscent of a dates cake with lots of crust. Palate is thick, oily, sweet. Not much bitterness at all despite a gentle hop hint and apparent faint smokiness. I can understand its high rating, this is everything you want a porter to be. Classy and quaffable.

bottle...deep garnet pour with generous tan head.  The head is rich and lasting.  Sweet malt aroma, some mile chocolate noticable.  Nice chewy porter with heavy chocolate flavor.  Sweet, not bitter, which is an interesting comparison to the Benchwarmer I just had.  If I could combine both, it would be the ultimate porter.  This is very quaffable.

Poured dark with a thick dark oak head. Aromas was heavy with dark chocolate Tastes of malt, coffee, chocolate. Slightly sweet with mild amount of bitterness. Could have used a little more bitterness to offset the maltiness.Tasty, non the less a very good porter.

Pours black with quickly disappearing head.  Nose is of licorice, sweet and chocolate malt.   Flavor is chewy, smoky and bitter all at the same time.  Very drinkable porter.  Nice bitter, lingering finish.

Bottle.  Very yummy porter.  Ive had only one other beer from Anchor...needless to say I have been impressed with it and with this, the porter.  Im becoming more  of a fan of porters as time goes by, and this helps

wow,,i forgot how awesome this beer is..my grandpa was making barbeque spareribs the other day,,and i picked some of this stuff up to compliment it,..GREAT..dark color, nice tan head..aroma makes we want to stop smelling and start drinking...and drinking.get some

This is it folks...the only porter youll ever need.  (imo)
Ive only tasted about 5 different porters and I dont think I have to search any further, except for Fullers. Ill give that one a try when I have an extra 38 bucks. I cant get singles in my area so I have to splurge every once in a while. In this tasty beverage you get a hoppy choco-coffee licorice treat. Perfectly balanced flavors. A tad sweet. Definately worth 29 bucks a case. A true porter classic! Try some, youll be glad you did...cheers!

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2007 (Rerate, prev 9-4-8-4-16) Almost black colored, brown head vanished quickly. Rich and roasted porter aroma, with notes of sweetness, fruitiness, berries and chocolate. Medium bodied, dry ending with lasting bitterness. Chocolate flavor with strong roasted coffee, aftertaste is very lasting with coffee, berries and sweetness. Maybe too sweet for my taste, still excellent porter.

Draught
Dark ruby, almost opaque black. Cloudy beautiful expresso head. Roasted and berry aroma. Medium-bodied, roasted, crisp and hoppy flavor. Aftertaste has soapy and sweet hoppyness.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2008 Bottle. Black colour with light brown head. Aroma of malt, pineapple, licquorice. Quite roasted, maltyflavour with a hint of sourness. Aftertaste is a good balance between sweet and bitter. 6 4 7 4 15

Bottle, 5.6%. Sweet coffee aroma. The flavour also has sweet coffee notes. Fresh-ground coffee aftertaste. 6 3 6 3 16

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2008 [12 oz. bottle] Dark brown color with a thick and creamy tan head. Light sweet, chocolate malt aroma. Smooth and sweet aroma of chocolate, some roasted malts and a nice brown sugar middle with a slightly bitter coffee finish. Very nice porter.
Dark brown and a tan creamy head. Aroma was of chocolate malts, and slightly sweet. Flavor was smooth, and sweet, but not too sweet. This is a very nice porter.

Big foamy head. Dark brown color. Faint sweet malty aroma. Nice soft mouthfeel. Spicy and a little alcoholic up front, fading to a roasty, brown sugar taste towards the end. Well crafted, I would love to have this off cask!
BottleRich creamy off-white head. Sweed dark chocolate aroma. Bettery chewable and quite complex. Long and somewhat salty aftertaste.
Poured a dark black with a large brown head. Aromas and tates of carmamel and chocolate (stornger on the carmamel side). Very light coffee in the taste. Light bitter finish. Not bad.
Porterific.  Portastic.  Portacious.  Porterior.  Porterious. Portational.  Porterb.  Porterful and Portendous.  A great example of the style.
A Wonderful drink to have after trying their steam beer.  It was thicker, darker, crisper, less carbonated, creamier and blessed with caramel sweet and coffee bitters.  Beautiful!

Great Brew! Fairly thick creamy head, slight tofee aroma and taste. The hops give it the perfect balance, neutralizing the caramel aftertaste. I would never believe anything this creamy would have a crisp finish. It def. convinced me to try more anchor brews...good stuff.

All I can say is WOW!  Best porter I ever drank, beats yuenglings and stegmaiers by a bit.  Nice caramel and hops aroma, opaque black color, flavor rich in caramel, coffee, with a nice hint of hops, but more dominated by malt.  Amazing brew, and better than the Anchor Steam.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2005 Wow...this beer just smells of Treacle Toffee!!!! When pored its a beautiful rich,almost black beer with a georgeous bonfire,sweet toffee taste....The aftertaste is like roasted peanuts and again malted sweet flavour.... I love this beer.

Poured a great dark ruby tone with a small tan head.  The aroma was of roasted malts, very very smokey.  It is one of the most appealing aromas I have yet encountered.  The flavor was slightly sweet and very dry.  I love this beer.

Nice and dark with a wicked huge head of deep brown. Exactly how a porter should smell, but not too strong. Was hoping for a more fragrant pour. Very sweet and sticky going down. First sip tasted watered down for some reason, but this only gets better with eveyr sip. Roasted nuts, chocolate and bits of caramel hit you and stay pretty well.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2004 Draft at Enken, Copenhagen. Rich chocolate/coffee porter. Intense, long-lasting flavor that just refuses to let go. Had two pints, the first of which somehow reminded me of a divine frappucino. An outstanding porter and a personal favorite.

Pours very dark brown with a light brown head that lasts an average amount of time.  Aroma is roasty, though not necessarily distinguishable from other porters.  Initial taste is slightly sweet with hints of molasses and caramel.  The finish is dry and quite bitter.  The body feels pretty full, but I personally would enjoy a little more carbonation.  Sits rather heavy and is not as refreshing as other brews, namely Fullers London Porter.  However, definitely an above-average drink.

Pours dark in color, with hints of amber when held to the light. Slight roasty/caramel aroma. Very smooth. Not overpowering. A slight nutty/coffee flavor. A little roasty up front but finishes with a strong 
roasted flavor.

A great looking porter that defines the category and shows great restraint. Ive often complained that porters are the most abused style out there. Here we have a solid, medium bodied, malty but  dry, roasty beer with enough hops to keep it balanced and somewhat refreshing.

Very dark. No light comes through. Very thick creamy brown head and light lacing. Aroma of molasses and sweet spices. Malty body. Roasted flavour with a touch of fruit around the edges. Sweetness grows through the glass and finish. Some hop bitterness in the finish as well. Very delicious as are most of the Anchor beers.

Damn this was good. The beer is very dark reddish black letting just a hint of light through. There is a small, but persistent tan head and an aroma of roast and chocolate. The flavour is dominated by a reasonably sweet chocolate profile with hints of roast. The aftertaste lingers with a pleasant bitterness. The carbonation level and thickness are just right.
Pours very dark with brown head.  Nose is malt and cherry.  Same in the taste, along with licorice, coffee, milk chocolate.  Finishes with a roasted malty flavor.  Excellent.
Anise and coffee nose with a bit of abv.   Coffee, chocolate, dark malts, cream, a little alcohol, and a touch of bitterness.  Finishes dark and grainy.
Draft. Dark black beer with a big biege head. Roasted malt aroma. Roasty flavor with chocolate/molasses backing. Creamy mouthfeel. Nice and smooth. A very good porter.
Black color, light sweet coffee aroma and smooth taste, medium body, light sweet finish.

BottlePours a very dark brown, with a modest head that fades to nothing fairy quickly. Very light lacing as well.  Aroma is a nice dark rasted grain, some licorice and purple graps as well.   The flavor is...well...is not there. Some smokey chared taste, with a touch or molassas and malt, but it is very faint.  most of it is after a breath or two passes over the tounge.  It is smooth, creamy and a bit heavy and rich. Just lacks any real bold flavor.  A little of that smokey, char-coal aftertaste and very little hops haning around.  Good but not great.
Fairly small head poured to a very dark brown almost black color. No hop flavor yet malts are definatly present. Very strong yet smooth and finishes with a sweet wheat like flavor.

Sweet, roasted malt aromas. Very dark pour, medium tan head.  Excellent malt(s) mixed with hops.  A good blend, but more dominated by the malt.  Heavy and creamy on the palate.  Another great brew for a cool night.
Dark brown almost black...smells of coffee...tastes of burnt coffee then just bitter...finishes very smooth and softly...definately a more complex porter of your widely available porters...
Dark roasted taste. Thick coffee aroma and taste. Fairly bitter up front with malt backing it up. Excellent taste, still one of the best porters Ive had.

average viscosity for a porter, I dont find it at all thin for the style.  Too me tastes like a hopped up brown ale, a nice nutty maltiness and a not meek hop finish.  Reminds me actually of Sam Smiths lighter stouts.
UPDATED: AUG 4, 2004 Bottle (355ml). Dark colour, almost black. Nice rich flavour, coffee and dates (I think). Will have this one again.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2006 This porter was excellent. Black bodied with a rich, thick chocolate head that settled like the islands in a rootbeer float. A rounded malt chocolate presence greeted my nose as well as some alchol and hops. Nose is full of ripe fruits, dates, raisins and definitely prunes.  The flavor was a bit robust and sharp malt with chocolate and alcohol appearing again to add an imperial stout like dimension. A fine, well-balanced porter that is good to have within arms reach.
Good porter, but this is much much thinner in body than the (few) other porters Ive had, so much so that it surprised me.  Although  it was tasty I prefer something thicker and stickier like Bells.

This beer was a staple of mine back in my pre-ratebeer days. Damn I wish I would have come back sooner. The body is almost opaque black but the edges are ruby tinged. The head is a beuatiful pillow of dense mocha goodness. Glass lacing is also outstanding. The aroma is rich roasted choco-coffee malts.  Big thick roasted malt flavor that doesnt quit. The hops kick in about mid way through and help bring things to a wonderful close. Body is medium-full and very rich. Damn fine stuff!
Bottled. I did not like this one, the coffee/chocolate/burt malt got too much for me, and I couldnt finish it.

Bottle. Poured with no head at all. Dark brown/black coloured. Roasted malt, chocolate aroma. Lots of  flavours, sweet, malty, coffee, chocolate with a dry bitter finish. Moderately carbonated with nice mouthfeel. Very good.
Very black, nice beige head. chocolaty aroma. creamy roasted mocha flavor with a slightly bitter finish. Nice lacing too. Very good.
Mocha bittersweet rather than chocolate and still rich, not too toasty coffee. Just easy and smooth. Roast, anise nice at end of meal, carbonation on tongue as it sooths it
Black with a brown head.  Aroma is hoppy with a molasses and honey hint.  Bittersweet like a dark chocolate or dark coffee.  Easy on the palate.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2006 Good bottled, great on tap, so here goes: on tap just outside of Frisco.  Almost black, opaque, smallish, tan, creamy head with soft and smoothe lacing, leaving rings and net all the way down.  Aroma is strong malts with prune, chocolate and maybe coffee; smells great.  Flavor is lovely on tap, fabulous: well balanced, sweet, smoothe, prunes, chocolate.  Wee heavy body for a porter, but thats how I like it and with medium, soft and creamy carbonation--this is very drinkable.  Alcoholic flavor on this one in the finish, its light but makes its presence known in a very nice way.  Big difference between bottle and tap with tap being far superior.
UPDATED: JUN 28, 2005 FANTASTIC porter.  Great aroma of chocolate and yeast; wonderful dark look in the glass, great flavor and, well, just drink it!  Nice job on this porter...
Very enjoyable!  Tasted somewhat reminiscent of prunes or raisins but very roasty.  Carbonation is suberb.  Held a nice head the whole way down.
Very good porter. Dark brown, black color. Nice lasting  tan head.  Aroma was ok. slight coffee. Flavor was very good. Vanilla, some alcohol too. good beer.

I like this beer. It is probably one of my favourite porters. I am not often in the mood for so heavy a brew as a porter nor does the setting here in Birmingham often seem complementary to its weighty seaport-sounding heftiness and mouthfeel. I dont really know what Im talking about - the review had to be about yay long...I liked it. I liked it.

Black-brown colour. Tall brown head, lasting. Sweet fruity aroma. Muscovado sugar. Good carbonation. Complex rich flavour. A bit smoky. Roasted bread. Malty. A hint of licourice. Vanilla? Dry, slightly bitter finish. Overall very good stout.

Wow!  What a great porter.  Im not a porter man, myself, but this one is a great one.  Smells and tastes of chocolate, with an extremely filling sensation in your mouth.  Dark as oil and slick as night.  Go for it, porter man.

This was unlike any porter Ive ever had.  Reminded me of Old Peculiar.  Similar English malts producing subtle fruit flavors (plumbs, cherries, raisins).  This one is tough to rate on just one bottle, but my overall impression is outstanding.

Bottle into Duvel tulip glass; bought at World Market at Broadway and Diversey.  I must say that I like porters.  A lot.  This one was no exception.  The aroma was faint, but the whiff I caught was caramelly.  Opaque black in the glass, medium hue brown head as bubbly and very short lived, but demonstrated interesting lacing for how meager it was.  The flavor: dope.  Coffee beans with cotton-candy sweetness at first, settling into unsweetened chocolate thats smooth and perfectly balanced.  Great mouthfeel; just a hint of carbonation to go with a milky smoothness.  Not as good as Carnegie, but damn good nonetheless.
Very dark reddish brown, with thick brown head. Sweet molasses and toffee on the nose. Malty sweet, w/cherry, molasses, and soft mouthfeel as chocolate notes linger on the slightly bitter finish.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2012 Bottled.  Black beer with a nice off-white head which is fairly long lasting.  The aroma is bitter chocloate, and the taste is also domnated by chocolate, almost to be point of being overpowering.  A nice drink but needs some balancing.Score 3.7Subsequent ratings scored 3.8 and 3.7. Average unaltered

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2004 This beer has a coffee taste with a hint of chocolate. Very thick and full-bodied. Leaves a thick aftertaste in your mouth. Tastes like a cross between Dark Side Vanilla Porter and Sam Adams Double Bock.

Looks like any other porter, but the taste is far better than the average porter. Rich and creamy with almost a butterscotch taste to it. A slight chocolate flavor makes this beer good stuff. One of the best porters Ive tried.
Dark, espresso, chocolate..roasted. Distinct hit.  Dark color.  Wonderful Porter.

Nice frothy tan head which is nice and creamy on top.  Great aroma with roasted malts, molasses, chocolate and even a bit of dough.  Color is a deep, dark brown.  Flavor is soft and rich with delicious roasted malts, a touch of caramel, some dark chocolate and a hint of hops.  Finish is a littel dry but creamy and smooth.  A very good porter.
Very nice and dark, a lasting brownish head. Molasses, malt a few hops. Easy to drink, smooth mouthfeel with a nice aftertaste.

Poured a deep brown typical porter color with a small brown head.  No lacing but a very slight head remained throught the glass.  Slight roasted malt flavor.  This seems like a run of the mill typical porter.  Nothing outstanding here.
Nice roasted malty aroma over a dark dark color with the lightest brown around the edges of the glass.  Light carbonation and smooth mouthfeel with a slightly chalky roasted flavor.

I wish i could say more about this beer but it seems rather "flat" to me.    What you taste initially is what you taste in the end.  No highs or lows.  Almost perfectly PH blanced.  Im most impressed by the smokey aftertaste.  Mesquite?  BBQ?...I just keep thinking I want to throw a steak on the grill!  Soy sauce!  When this beer warms up...soy/teriaki sauce is all i can think of.  Its positive.  Pair this with a steak on the grill....perfect!
deep roasted smell, dark and appealing body, light tan head. rich taste with very outstanding flavor.
Bottled from Happy Deli NYC Poured Black with a thick tan head. Smells like roasted coffee  and malts.Great dark beer

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2004 Pours a perfect very dark brown with a great light tan head. Aroma was very toasty with a great coffee smell. Taste was nice and sweet and malty, very rich with a great coffee taste. Very smooth and creamy with a only very slightly bitter end. Excellent porter
Dark brown color with tan head.  Toasted, malty aroma and rich flavor of coffee and caramel.  Good mouthfeel and and not too thin in the finish.

This was a deep dark brown in color with a tan head.  Deep aroma, smells like roasted coffee and roasted malt.  The flavor is like roasted malt and coffees.  A hint of bakers chocolate.  Tastes a bit sour actually and I couldnt really get past that sour taste. Decent mouth feel, smooth and effervescent.  Overall:  It is indeed a complex beer and it has everything going for it, as far as color, apperance, palate and especially the aroma.  The taste is however simply not for me...the acidic sour taste doesnt do it for me.

Pours out a nice solid black, ruby is only hinted at when held directly in front of light. Big light-brown head quickly bubbles up. Nose is evident of dark fruits (plums, raisons) with  delicate chocolate and coffee tones backing it up. Definately a unique tasing porter, a lot more of dark fruity tones in the taste than the usual chocolate/coffee flavors standard to a porter. Sweet all the way through with light pangs of earthy bitterness at the edges. Aftertaste is long-lasting sweet and dense with light tones of grapeskin. Mouthfeel seems a tad light, but its tolerable. 

Deep, sweet, fruity, and robust..a complex and lovely porter.

Medium, fugaceous, light brown head. Brown color with some red hues. Sweet, malty, chocolate aroma, almost milk chocolate. Very rich chocolate/coacoa flavor with some roastiness. Slightly bitter after-taste. Powdery mouthfeel. Rich, intense, I love this beer !
The taste of this beer was a little more acidic than I expected but still very satisfying.  Think Ill have another.
I dont think this is a very good tasting beer. But that does not say a whole lot coming from me because i do not like too many porters.
UPDATED: DEC 9, 2008 This beer was the shit.  I would buy this again anyday of the week if I could find it in South Dakota.  It is very dark with a creamy head and a smooth ass taste.

Though I like this, theres something a little weird about the flavor, maybe the black licorice combined with some acidity; it has a nice chocolate nose and looks beautiful in the glass with a large, creamy head- some lacing present; it has a well balanced bitterness complementing a somewhat thick malty palate; I like it, but this is overrated, and I prefer other porters.

Bottle: Good nose, banana/maltball/milky. Great color, orangy/reddish brown clear yet not much light gets through. Bittersweet flavors, baking chocolate, little metallic, grapefruit. Creamy, lite oily, bitter, burnt/ grapefruit, finish. Very nice, little thicker than i think of typically for a porter. Very enjoyable.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: UPDATED: DEC 4, 2007 Everyone always said this was a good porter, and it is. It pours out dark black with a chocolate fruity aroma. There is little to no head to speak of. It tastes like dark chocolate mixed with a smoky fruit flavor. The finish is very smooth, not too heavy, not in the least bit watery. A great porter!
UPDATED: MAY 6, 2006 Delicious burnt chocolate appearance and taste.  Dark, rich, and worthy of a second.

Bottle. Pours dark black with dark brown highlights when held to the light.  No Head and not much lacing.  Great looking beer and the aroma is amazing.  Aroma of chocolate covered cherries, sweet dates, sweet fruit pastries, and a light hint of smokiness (just a hint).    The initial flavor is a smooth and velvety roasty malt(initial not bitter), mocha, light alcohol, and a subtle balance of dark dried fruit flavors.  The finish is slightly bitter sweet and not overpowering.  Wow Im impressed; this beer actually lives up the hype and 3.9+ rating.  Amazing!! Very drinkable and well-crafted porter. Well Done.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2005 
Man I want to spoon with this brewery. Lovely Porter. Ive only had it out of the bottle and it ALWAYS satisfies. Pours a deep dark black. Dark like space dark. Head is tan and luscious like  mamas mashed potatoes. The bouquet is incredibly satsifying. The thing that is most interesting about this beer is that most other porters and stouts characteristically and traditionally are dry, so dry that what comes through is the arid texture of the dark roasted malt. Although I am a big fan of this style, it is difficult for my tongue to get past the dry, cracked, paperlike finish of the malt. This brew however is like chewing on a big ball of burnt black WET paper. Alright kind of gross, however not as dry as other porters and thus beautiful. Roasty, yeasty and satisfying this brew is great after a hard days work.

G-rat

Almost completely black body, with a very beautiful thick tan head.
The aroma is very powerful and strong. I can smell licorice, roastiness, soy, coffee and chocolate, just beautiful.
The flavor is very burnt, coffee, licorice. Very crwamy mouthfeel and perfect amount of carbonation. This is a very nice porter... If i were on the Irish Rover, this should be the 7 million barrels of porter which they had on board! (Hint: The Pogues - Irish Rover)

One of my favorites, the beer that introduced me to good beer.  A gorgeous nearly black with a thick diminishing light brown head.  Nice aroma of milk chocolate, malted milk balls, vanilla, licorice, roast and coffee with a hint of sweet raisin.  Medium creamy body with a moderate amount of carbonation.  Great flavor of plum, raisin, roast, malted milk balls, vanilla, milk chocolate, drip coffee and roast.  Very drinkable, one of my staples.  Have I overrated it? Probably, but not by too much.

Combined impressions, tap and bottle. My Kryptonite. Beer looks good and black, with a small tan head that will remain for most of your drink (on tap) though I poured it a little aggressively from the bottle and received a good inch and a half of creamy Anchor Porter foam for my efforts. Smells delightfully roasted but not burnt in the same way a properly seared steak doesnt taste burnt. There is an elusive hint in the flavor here that I just cant put my finger on, but it happens to be my favorite note. It could be raisins, or plums or some other mildly sweet and fruity taste with a satisfying toasted aspect to it. Smooth. Not Heineken smooth, which means shallow white bread, but rather immaculately balanced with subtle complexities smooth. Touch of chocolate, touch of coffee. Alcohol is obvious but not distracting in any way--another note to be relished. Mild dryness is nice, not distracting. Mouthfeel is medium thickness, not at all watery, but not syrup by any means. It fits. I think it just might be a little bit bolder on tap, and the flavor might be oh-so-slightly subdued after a sit in the bottle, but if so, its still a pretty close call. Maybe I seem gushy, but this is a good beer that I do not forsee growing past. Goes exceptionally well with hearty food, like a burger, fajitas, chili would be nice... Be careful that you dont drink more than you planned.
I am a huge Porter fan, and while this isnt my overall favorite Porter, it deserves a lot of credit.  Coffee and chocolate flavors with a nice malty balance.  You just wont go wrong with this.

Poured a frothy tan head. Candied Apples and Hops prevail in the Aroma. A very smooth flavour of Candied Yams, Raisins, and burnt Pie Crust. Smoky overtones Define this Beverage. An Excellent Potable, one that I will seek in the future. Bon Appetit.

UPDATED: APR 28, 2004 poured a dark small head. left a sour taste i didnt find pleasing, i could only relate the finish to a weak paint thinner. my buddy who was with me disagreed completely and was shocked i didnt like this, i was too our tastes are usually the same for this type of beer. but i just didn't like this one.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2004 Pours a thick black with a medium-sized, brown, frothy head.  The head does go away after a while but is easily brought back by a little swirling.  Aroma is very unique and different from any porter I have had; it smells more creamy and chocolatey than anything I have had yet, aside from Young's Double Chocolate Stout.  There is some coffee in the nose, but it is beautifully mellow rather than overpowering as is common; also some toffee smell.  Flavor is malty up front, with lots of chocolate flavor, some light coffee, and caramel, with the perfect bitterness in the finish--great balance.  Feels really good, too; almost as silky as a nitro can but without the nitro; just a tiny bit thin.  Overall, this is a really nice, unique porter.  I like the fact that there is no smokiness, the coffee is a little more laid back than usual, and the hops balance this beer very well.  Overall, very nice stuff.

Pours a deep balck , with just a hint of reddish brown around the edges.  Thick tan head, with good retension.  Creamy feel, with a fuller body than many Porters.  The malts are very prevalent, wints flavors of cocoa, coffee, and licorice.  Very smooth and well-blended, especially in the transition to the hoppy finish.  A good Porter, I'll be trying more from this brewery.
Nice looking pour and a good smell.  Tasty beer.  There's not much better then a good stout, and this one is pretty good.

Dark black pour, with a fluffy tan head.  Strong aroma of chocolate, coffee, and roasted malts.  Taste is fantastic.  Wonderful on the palate.  Coffee is predominant, along with chocolate, but you could get lost in this one.  Some expresso, licorice, toffee, caramel, smokey malts, nice hopping.. it just goes on.  Finish is a semi-sweet, perfect bitterness.  Definitely the best port I've had yet.  Most porters lose me on the finish, but this was top notch.  Deserves its spot amongst the best ports'.

It was voted number 1 porter at our local beer shop as voted by the patrons. Smells like chocolate cheesecake from Schlotsky's deli.
Dark and rich.
Slightly alkaline yet not bitter at all. Seemingly foamy going down yet very pleasing and smooth to swallow. Goes well with many foods.
Being more food than drink, this one will fill you up.
I recommend this beer highly.
Roasty and bitter this dark black brew is very nice. Not really my favorite kind of beer but this is quality. Hoppy/bitter presense, chocolately undertone. Very nice beer.

Wow!  Poured an opaque black, with a thin tan head that left thick rings of lace on the glass.  The aroma was a rich, thick, malty, sweet scent that hinted of coffee, licorice, chocolate, and perhaps plum, and it had me salivating from the start.  Flavor was an amazing torrent of malty sweetness, providing a fruity tartness alongside an espresso bitterness, and this combination was nothing short of fantastic.  Better yet was the mouthfeel; this is one of the smoothest beers I've ever had, especially for such a thick brew.  It was exceptionally smooth and creamy, an absolutely delightful sensation.  What an amazing beer!

Jet-black color, with a tight cocoa/creamy tan head. Aroma is a roasty delight: coffee, chocolate, nuts. Deep, rich, satisfying. Terrific initial grit on the palate, a torrent of beautiful bitterness braces the tongue, but it's smooth sailing all the way down. Full body, rewarding flavor, fat malt, and just sweet enough.
Texture smooths out and the large portion of this drink is an easy-going, fully flavored ride. While I love bolder and brasher stuff, Anchor Porter just about acheives perfection, and the happiness that ensues when it's flavors flood my mouth and spread my smile out wide confirm that thought.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2004 Bottle. Almost black, small thin off white head that went away quick. Nose is exactly what you want out of a beer: crisp, clean, thick. Tastes is very sharp and crisp. Notes of licorice, roasted hops, bitter chocolate and coffee. All the fore mentioned tastes are very low key and not at all  overpowering. The beauty is that these flavors are all there but they blend together perfect. This is a very compplex well crafted beer. This is almost the most perfectly crafted beer I have ever had. It is commplex in its subtlety. I could write poetry and prose about this beer for days. If I was forced to write one negative thing about this beer it would be the slightly thick mouthfeel, but that is very, very minor.

Virtually black with a tan head. Licorice is the dominant aroma here, with other malty notes of roasted nuts and caramel. There's tons of licorice flavor too, with some chocolate flavors also entering the picture. Long finish, great stuff. Thanks Lubiere!
Pours black with little head.  Coffee and chocolate aroma.  Thick tooth coater.  Silky and smooth with bitter chocolate and espresso.

Pours almost black with a thin tan head. Sweet, malty, slight chocolate aroma. UUmmmmm, This beer is really good. Creamy, heavy malt flavor with good bittersweet aftertaste. Being a porter lover, my rating my be slightly biased, but this is a great beer.

Pours dark black, with tan head.  Aroma is of coffee, chocolate, slightly nutty, and roast malt.  Very smooth flavor and finish, with hints of chocolate, coffee, prunes, and slight almonds.  A delicious, very complex porter.

The beer pours a nice dark black with a brown head.  The aroma has hints of coffee.  The taste is awesome and hard to describe because it is very smooth yet well defined.  The malty aspect of this porter is nicely executed.  I highly recommend this Anchor product.

Love this one. Carmel, malt, and smoth creamy goodness dominate. Lots of other flavors going on though. Every bottle has revealed something new to me. I will buy this beer many many more time in the future...GUARANTEED.
This beer is a charm. It's robust, flavorful, and remarkable. I cant say enough good things about this beer!

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2004 Pours a deep dark black.  No light gets through it.  No real head or aroma.  Flavor is a musty,roasted carmel.  There is the usual chocolate and coffee flavors here which stand out quite strong.  Very good and excellent lacing.
Deep dark in color with a nice tan head. Really roasty flavor. Really good. Chocolate and coffee aromas. Smooth in flavor. Great.

The three D's: Deep, dark, and delicious! Dark brown, with a nice tan head. Big roasty aroma, with chocolate and coffee hints. flavor is big, malty, smooth, and a little to the swet end of the spectrum. Glad this is readily available, and it is a toast to this beer seeing that there are 470 ratings and it has a rating of 3.95!
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: This is a well-rounded porter...fruity, malty, roasted, slightly chocolate flavored. I highly recommend it.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a thick head; good lace. Hold to the light and some gets through.  Flowery bouquet; flavor at first a bit roasted and astringent with some strong black coffee. Dry bitter finish.  Excellent example of the style
Delightful porter. Rich backbone malt with excellent lace on tap. Hop character strong, but not overpowering. Savory at room temperature.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2004 Pours thick and black. Thick and lasting spumous tan head, strong lacing as expected, fairly strong carbonation. Nose is toasted grain, soapy carbonation and yeast. Front: sweet roasted malts, acidic, some hops. Body: mega fruit asters Anchor style, berries and apple, bitter toasted grains with some hops, lots of sweet malts. Finish: some burnt toast, good balance. Palate is creamy and thick. Excellent porter.

Much differant then the other Porters I have had thus far.  More of a dry taste, hops are much more exentuated, and coffee notes are in the background instead of the forefront like the others I have had.
Roasted hops with a hint of coffee. Full bodied and very flavorful. Head pours nice. Deep copper brown color. A great porter! Enjoy!
Dark with a thin head and good lacing. Aroma is anise and dark chocolate. Flavour is the same.
UPDATED: JUL 15, 2004 Pours deep purple/black. Not the head I expected. Faint subtle aromas of carmel, malt, licorice  and sweet coffee. Mouthfeel is medium-heavy. Very good bitter finish.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2004 One of my favorite beers with decent distribution, so you can get it almost anywhere. Love it for the carmel & roasty flavor and creamy palate. Always pours with a nice head and dark body. A much better choice than Guiness because it has more microbrew characteristics, um...that would be hops!
Great example of a porter. Nice big creamy head on a dark brown body. Loads of roastedness, and a great balance of bitterness, hops and sweetness.

(355 ml bottle). Pours with a large tan head, colour is very dark, nearly black (= very, very dark ruby when held to the light). Lovely complex aroma where coffee, dark chocolate, prunes, oak and sandalwood shine through. Flavour is initially sweet and mellow, then a distinct bitterness comes through. Coffee notes are dominant. There's something undefined strange in the aftertaste that keeps me from giving it a straight "5". Still, this is a top class porter!

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2004 This has to be my favorite porter.  Everything about this beer screams great, from the conderful chocolatey aroma to the finish which leaves you wanting more and more.  Fantastic!

Good roasted malt and chocolate aroma.  Gret looking brew.  Very dark amber color with a thick rocky tan head.  Starts kind of buttery feeling with a slightly sweet hop taste that smoothly moves into a nice mocha finish.  Very chocolatey.  Great porter.
Brownish creamy head to a very dark beer. The tast has a coffeetone wish is niece. Also a little sweet tast. My first porter but not the last!

Pours a black color and is topped by a thick, creamy, paper-grocery-bag brown colored head.  Sweet roasted malt, molasses, coffee, and chocolate aromas emanate from my glass.  A medium level of body and a fruity sweetness marry well with the other flavors that are in the beer.  Roasted notes are here but somewhat subdued, notes of chocolate, and lots of dark fruit are here as well.  A very well integrated porter that I can always count on and enjoy.  Early on this was one of the best porters out there, and it still can hold its own against todays contenders for the porter crown.

Dark color with big beige head. Malt coffee smell with solid coffee chocolate taste in the mouth. Very smooth with some roasted coffee flavors and some alcohol.Finishes bitter and very good. A nice porter.

For a porter (which I have discovered that I am NOT a fan of) this is an excellent beer. It is almost black- nice appearance- with tons of chocolate malt and coffee overtones. The alcohol is well disguised and the head looks great in the glass. This was not the beer for me as it was just a little overpowering in its' intensity of flavor, merely proving I'm not a porter fan.

Near black, bit deeply reddish.  Nice, thick, mocha head.  Lovely nose, hints of chocolate, a bit of cofee, and nice bitterness.  Some nicely deep fruitiness, bit of cherry or plum.  Very nice flavor, impressively vinous up front, bit rich and sweet, slightly port-esque.  Good roasts follow, hints of dry chocolate.  End is crisp and perfectly hoppy, enjoyable dry and acidic.  Excellent creamy flavor.  #900.

Almost black body with a good tan head that sheepishly diminishes after a big entrance. Slightly sweet chocolatey aroma. Malty with a bit of roast and rasin in the flavour profile. Very good and very flavourful for this well balanced unagressive porter.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2011 I keep meaning to get back to this beer but something always distracts me. I really need to get around to rerating this one. +++ Served in a 12oz brown bottle. Pours thick,dark black and oily with a moderate brown head that slowly dissipates. Deep black color in the glass - no light penetrates. Strong sweet scent of roasted malts and chocolate. Sweet and malty flavor with a strong suggestion of molasses, with smooth roasty flavors that linger on the palate. This is certainly one of the sweeter porters that I have had and is probably my favorite in the style.
A good malt-flavor to it. A really good beer. I'd encourage anyone to try it.
Dark and traditional with a crisp finish and not too much sweetness.  Reminds me of Yuengling but with a better mouthfeel and more attentuation.  Pretty good, but not exceptional.

Dark dark brown in color, almost black (when held in direct light, there is a hint of a ruby color), with a medium dark tan head.  Nice coffee-like aroma.  Thick, satisfying taste, crisp and malty with a mildly hoppy finish.  Good aftertaste.  My only complaint is that the head wasn't thick enough.  Besides that, wonderful porter.

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2004 Deep chestnut brown with thick tan head. Aroma is thick with raisin and prominent whisky notes. Lacing is thick. Slightly sweet with a bitterness that creeps up on you after the swallow. Rich and flavorfull in the malt department. A prince amongst paupers.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2004 deep brown, almost opaque, like a good porter should look.  very thin beige head.  aroma is fairly light, but notes of licorice and malt--some smoked cheddar even?.  body is excellent... full-bodied, with awesome roast and maltiness.  really smooth and extremely balanced.  slightly bitter, coffee aftertaste, but an excellent beer overall.

Deep dark brown color with a thick tan head.  There are very noticable roasted coffee and chocolate malts in the aroma.  There is a brief hop flavor but then the roasted goodness of this beer takes over and becomes the flavor that lingers in the mouth.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2004 Excellent but unusual porter that features a fairly sweet fruitiness up front with a mildly bitter, dark roasted maltiness and a yeasty flavor taking over in the finish; The fruity sweetness also dominates the nose and is reminiscent of English style porters; Black in color and opaque; Large, frothy head is dark tan in color and has excellent retention; Lacing is stubborn at first, sliding down the glass rather than sticking, but eventually grabs hold in small amounts

Classic deep color and a distinct shot of hop and alcohol before the roasted malt takes over! A nice edge on the finish makes this one a little different for me in the under-appreciated Porter group! I seem to be going back to this style more often lately! Very consistent!

Very dark brown. Firm,creamy,khaki,head. Nice patchy lace. Aromas of malt(tar,roasty),and some leafy hops. Oily,extremely creamy,palate. Great roasty,cocoa,burnt flavors. Bittersweet finish..roasty and sweet. Excellent porter,will buy this more often.

Bottle pours a dark red black with a tan head and good lace.  The aroma is of roasted malt and hops.  The flavor is roasty malt, fairly hopped, and just overall nice for a Porter with a rich mouthfeel.  Overall, a decent Porter, but very much like liquid dark chocolate.
How is it that I have so many beers that I have had so many times and never rated? Has anyone got the RWD yet?

Bottle:

Nice dark opaque brown with creamy tan head.  malty sweet chcoclate nose.

Taste is sweet, roaty/chocolate with a bit of an anise seed flavor behind it all.  fairly dry finish, no notable hop character.

Wonderful chocolatey aroma and beautiful appearance, but the flavor was a bit lighter than expected. More fruity than I anticipated, and the roasted notes were not as prominent as I thought they should be. Still a very nice porter, but I would choose Sierra Nevada's version over this.

Bottled (355ml). There seems to be some debate about whether this is a porter (a bit rich for that) or a stout (a bit light bodied for that?). What the hell, let's just call it an excellent beer. Black with a hint of ruby. Almost opaque. Malty with sourish hoppy notes on the nose. Pontefract cake (licorice) and bitter chocolate too, which carries through on to the palate. Quite rich, but not heavy bodied. Bitter chocolate (again) and  espresso coffee on the finish. No hint of sweetness. Spiffing stuff.

bottled and on tap at the brewery: dark as night when poured with a tan creamy loose head.  some slight hop nose with toffee, toased aroma.  taste has the choc, burnt character with a burst of hops as well. this is a top notch porter and one i think of for a good standard in the class.  i dont drink much of this but i should drink more...

Bottle from Rai Wines, Harborne, Birmingham. Little aroma, but some choc. Jet black and a nice beige head, displaying a rocky personality. Amazing, fabulous smooth coffe cream taste. This is a brilliant, rounded pint - sweet smooth, creamy, balanced. All the flavours are in there, and there is a nice hint of bitterness in the mouthfeel. Top notch.
Lightly winey aroma.  Chocolate and coffee flavor, good mouthfeel.  Rides the line between a sweet and robust porter.  Fine, but nothing exceptional.

I really liked this basically black Anchor offering. Malt and chocolate with maybe some mild coffee visited my nose before my tongue was treated to a smooth, sweet, roasted mocha, almost stout-like texture mouthful. Left with a slightly bitter but mostly understated sweet wave goodbye. A must have for porter lovers.

Deep black, with moka head. Nice vanilla chocolate aroma. Intense roasted malt with some nutty bitterness, slight lactic acid taste, creamy mouthfeel, with chocolate lingering for a long time. Splendid.
Draft:  nice roasty, chocolatey nose.  More of the same in the flavor.  Typical porter appearance.  Very nice porter!

Opaque black with a tan head, smells of chocolate, fruit and coffee. Nice creamy mouthfeel, good balance of hops against sweet fruit, chocolate and coffee. A very slight tinge of smoke (or ash) but certainly not overdone. A high quality Porter, glad I finally got around to trying it.
Black w. thick light brown head. Sweet, rye bread, liqourice, espresso, flowery hops. Very nice.

Bottle, almost entirely black with slight tan head. Fruit, dark malty and chocolate aroma. Taste is the same, medium-full body, with some coffee, very smooth, great balance of hops, classic tasting. Thouroughly enjoyable.

Paid $1.39 for a 12-oz single.

Nice and dark- just about black, with a large, brown head. Looks frothy and fluffy, and seems to last.

Deep roasted something in the nose. Slightly pasty as well. Nice.

Deep cold coffee, deep rich and flavorful wonderfulness. This is a fantastic brew- a top-notch porter! Rum raisen comes to mind as well... Wow, I'm very impressed!

A very nice beer that I will gladly snatch up next time I see it.
I definitely agree with the aroma of ashes.  But the flavor is very rich, malty, and creamy.

It smells of ashes, but there is nothing of that present in the flavor. The flavor is strongly dominated by bitter chocolate. There is not much hops, and it lacks a balancing sweetness. The head is somewhat creamy but not very lasting. 
Quite enjoyable, but I'd like my porter slightly sweeter.
nice malt smell; very dark - almost black - with very little head; smooth feel; pleasantly bitter with coffee/chocolate flavors

Pours almost black. Thick lasting tan head, nice lacing. Nose is malt/sweet, hinting chocolate and licorice. Thick mouthfeel, smooth and creamy. Roasty malt and bittersweet chocolate with a good dose of licorice. Finishes slightly bitter. Very good porter.
I find this to be the second best tasting porter. It has a great lacing, and it has a very distinctive aroma. If you like a malty bitter flavor , this is a must.

Nice black porter appearance with a moderate to thin cream head.  The first one I had didn't impress me all that much, but the flavor become much more lively as it warmed up toward room temperature.  As I've slowly worked my way through the six-pack, my opinion of this beer has positively increased.  It has a very nice mouthfeel, carbonated up front and smooth on the end.  The malt flavors linger on the finish, with a nice balance of hops for bitterness.  Very subtle notes of caramel and toffee are in there as well.  Very nice, and a good beer for rating #200.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2006 This pours a near black that is a bit red around the edges.  The head is tan and laces the glass perfectly.  The nose is light, but a bit floral, plumb-ish, and also roasty.  Oh my, this is a pretty amazing brew.  The initial taste is a light floral sweetness with perhaps a hint of bubblegum sweetness or breadiness.  Following is a dark chocolatly oiliness and fruitiness in the middle; the dark roasted hops are the kicker in the end.  This porter has a near perfect mouthfeel and palate.  It is actually a bit subtle in some ways.
Nice, bold beer, great for this -20F Vermont night.  We (should) all know and enjoy this one.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2004 Decadent flavor sets the tone: a thick, tasty brew that one could drink forever.  Solid in every respect, although the sticky mouthfeel/aftertaste might be a little much if you're trying to talk to someone.  Also, the flavor could be somewhat stronger.
Dark (almost black) ruby color. Tan, fluffy head. Nice aroma of marshmallow and liquorice. Roasty, sweet malt-flavour. Big bitterness with an espresso-dry finish but still very smooth and drinkable.

Almost black body with a nice dark beige head. Beautiful! Aroma of liquorice, dark roasted malt, and a little alcohol. Flavor has a nice balance between sweetness and bitterness. Notes of liquorice, oranges, brown sugar and roasted dark malt. A nice and dry alcohol bite to the finish. Very smooth.

Dark brown hue with a frothy tan head and good lace. Aroma hinted of caramel, nuts, movha, aromatic and floral hops, leathery yeast esters, and light citrus. The taste starts bitterweet chocolate and hazelnut. There is a slighty acidic fruity undertone. Smokey and bitter finish. The mouthfeel is dry and chalky. Solid, dependable porter. Not flashy and traditional, you know what you get from this brewery.

Very dark body, perfect tan head, a pleasure to look at. Enticing aroma and rich taste. Coffee, roasted malt and toffee flavours balanced by outsanding hops. Finish is almost dry. Delicious, and very drinkable at just 5,6% ABV.

An excellent porter.  Nice malty nose with a hint ob liquiorice and bubble gum.  Beautiful black color with a huge tan head and lacing.   Nice malty falvor  sweet initial and nicely balanced in finish with appropriate hopps.  Try this one

Not much to say that hasn't already been said well about this beer.  I think it might be the best American Porter, at least the best I've tried.  Pours a fantastic black cherry color and the amoma promptly wafts off the thick head.  Sticky sweet and smoky, perfect balance of malt and hops.  I could bathe in this stuff.  Absolutely delicious.  Local bar sells it for $2 bucks a pint all day every day.  Hooray!

Bottle.  Thanks JZ.  This one poured with a huge thick head and it stayed with us for the duration (which was not long after my first taste).  Nose was sweet, nutty, but not strong or overwhelming... this may be a good one.  Great amounts of thick lace lining the pint glass as the lumpy head falls slowly.  Deep, deep ruby black color and a taste of huge malt!  Sweet and flowing to back of tongue where a toffee/chocolate bitter rises and slowly fades.  This is the best porter that I have ever tried... bar none!  Mouthfeel is an incredibly cheery, creamy, buzzing beautiful thing.  Excellent!

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2007 (Bottled) Very dark cola-brown with a smallish, tight and somewhat lacy, beige head. The aroma is quite a bit burned-malty, but nicely chocolate-licoricey with a strong hop presence. Flavor has also chocolate and salty licorice, plus sweet-syrupy maltiness, but especially when colder also a bit too much color malt, making the flavor burned and ashy. As it warms, the sweet malt takes over, and burnedness fades accordingly. Medium to full-bodied, slicky and ashy palate with a sticky, dry and pleasantly hoppy finish. Seems like a beer with many faces: thin and ashy when cold - sweet-syrupy, thick, and Baltic Porter -like when warmer. Very nice, but not quite world-class.
(About a year old bottle, BBE 2005, was 7-4-8-4-16=3.9) Very, very dark, reddish brown color with a light brown, fading head. Quite dry, very roasty, salty and slightly red-wineous aroma with some caramel and alcohol. Initially sweetish, roasted-malty, slightly port-wineous flavor with grassy hops. Turns dry, roasted and slightly bitter towards the finish, and finally ends sweetish, bitter and sugary. Medium to full-bodied, low-carbonated and wineous, sticky palate. A tasty, high-quality, port-wineous porter - maybe a bit thin in body.
Almost black with a tan foamy head that held on well.  Aroma of chocolate and coffee.  Rich, full flavor of coffee and chocolate and a touch of anise.  A delicious drink.  Excellent.
Pours very black with a craggy head.  Sweet, malty nose with just a hint of chocolate.  Very sweet chocolate and coffee taste. Nice body

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2004 The first beer I've tried from Anchor. Pours a deep, dark brown with a nice tan head, good lacings. Aroma had some hop fragrances when first poured but ended in rich chocolate. Excellent! First taste was slightly bitter, good malt flavor, but not too rich. Better when served warm. Just a little thin. Can't wait to try the Steam Beer.
(Bottle)  Pours a dark brown color with a creamy tan head.  Has flavor of carmel and vanilla with a nice creamy finish.
one of the best porters for your money and a great benchmark for the style.  mixed it with vanilla ice cream with delicious results.  roasty, but sweet, and full bodied but smooth.  cool tan head.
Ok appearance. Too much "corn-flakes" in aroma. An ok porter, dark and a fine flavor. But not complex enough. And the corn-flakes.....bad.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2005 Dark brown body, lasting tan frothy head. 
Roasted burnt chocolate and Doritos (dark corn chip) aroma. 
Rich creamy and roasted chocolate lactic taste. Sweet charcoal.
Very good overall. Nice and balanced, thick and creamy.

A very dark porter, with a somewhat subdued roast malt (+ caramel?) nose-no hops evident.  Maybe a touch of diacetyl.  Flavor is smooth and rich, perhaps on the sweet side.  The roast notes are very mild.  Overall, a good beer, but becomes more sating as you drink it, and diacetyl more noticeable.
Not sure if this beer has changed recipies over the past 5 years or so but I don't seem to like it as much as I did (probably just me). Anyway still a WAY above average porter.

Bottle.  Poured dark, dark brown with a generous tan head that lingered well and left nice lacing.  Rich aroma, chocolate, molasses, brown sugar and floral hops.  Dark roasted malt flavors, coffee and nice bitterness from the hops giving a lingering spicy, bitter finish.  Thick body, creamy carbonation.  Very nice brew from Anchor!
Very dark coloured, generous lasting brown head, fantastic. Roasted malty aroma and flavour, a bit fruity and sweet. Bitter finish. Not as stout-like as some other porters, and i like that. Good.

Black. Creamy brown head. Excellent lace. Sweet milk chocolate aroma w/ notes of cherry, licorice, & hops. Thick, oily body. Roasted malt flavour of dark chocolate, licorice, fruit (cherry, plums), café au lait, & piny hops. Finish is lightly acidic & generously bitter. Good brew.

On tap at Summits Wayside tavern- Very nice rendition of an American Porter...Strong coffee with some mild sweet aromas...Taste was very full...lots of dark roasted flavors plenty of coffee...Nice clean finish

12 oz. brown stubbie Anchor bottle. 3YF code on back of bottle. Poured out an extremely dark chocolate brown, almost black in appearance. Thick brownish head slides back to a thin lacing on top of the beer itself. Aromas are of caramel malts, molasses, slight burnt malts, and a faint wisp of hops. Tastes very good, especially for a porter. Dry finish to the strong malty backbone, and subdued hopping. Makes a great breakfast beer, goes good with bangers & mash, or steak & eggs. Another winner from Mr. Maytag.

sort of off, coffee aroma.  a bit sweet smelling. a lil bubbly, slight head that disappears.  it ain't no carnegie or fullers, but it's a helluva lot cheaper.   smoky coffee sweetness, but not much presence in the mouth.    i enjoyed this enough.
Mild aroma of coffee and malt.  Black with a small head.  Flavors of coffee, chocolate, smoke.  Medium to full bodied.  good.

A fantastic beer!  Probably, to this point in time, my most favorite Porter.  Its coloring is a deep, rustic brown and it pours with a brown, firm, leathery head.  A sweet aroma that reminds me of toffee coated oat bran.  Upon sipping it starts out with sweet and tobacco-like and finishes off with a smooth textured coffee taste.  A complex, but thoroughly satisfying example of an American microbrewed Porter!

Pours opaque with tall brown frothy head.  Leaves nice lacing. Aroma is roasted and smoky with coffee, chocolate, cocoa. Very little carbonation. Smooth creamy mouth feel.  Quick finish, no bitter aftertaste.  Very nice. A little hops come through after the roasted flavor.  Very easy to drink.

Initial strong smell of coffee, dark chocolate, and black licorice.  Poured with no head, but it had a nice black tone to the body.  Very thin for a porter but still packs a nice punch of coffee and a strong burnt roasted flavor.  As it warms, a licorice aftertaste becomes apparent. Very Tasty.

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2004 Dark amber color, almost black, with a very nice brownish head. Aroma is cocoa. Flavor is coffee and cocoa, with some chocolate and a touch of toffee. Turns into a somewhat sour and bitter finish.

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2003 Pours with a deep, dark ruby body and a big, creamy, cappuccino head. The foamy head leaves some thick lacing as it slowly dissipates into a nice thin, appetizing layer. This is a bitter beer to say the least and should not be undertaken unless you're looking for a kick in the mouth. Strong flavors of burnt coffee, smoke, and roasted malt mix together to create one amazing gustatory experience. While I can't say that I am 100% in love I would definately enjoy a glass of Anchor Porter accompanied by a good cigar.
(Added a week later) Over the past few days I have developed a taste for this beer. I also think it makes a great Black & Tan when mixed with some light homebrew. I am impressed.
Nice dark chocolate and coffee flavor.  A very ordinary porter.  However it is good.  Nice smokey finish.
Good roasted aroma.  A lot of roasted malt in this one...finishes quite dry.  A little thin.

Bottled.
Black with some head.
Sweet, warm and fruity aroma.
Smooth and fresh palate with a smoked flavour with plums and raisins.

very dark brown with a good thick and creamy head. Deep roasted aroma with notes of coffeebeans, dark chocolate and almonds. Nice flavour and palate; dark coffee and chocolate with hints of dark dried fruit. Long, deep finish of coffee beans, smoke and hops.
Very dark with light brown head.  Nose of coffee.  Very roasted flavor with hints of smoke nice clean finsih with a bite of hops.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2005 Re-rate. Has a nice roasted aroma wih a medium yellow and tan head. Smells of maple and caramel. Tastes a little dry with a hint of sherry and brown sugar. Finishes like day old coffee that is very pleasant. This is an excellent full tasting porter.

Exceptional Porter!  Aroma taunts with coffee and caramel with expresso tracings.  Appearance is deep, dark and black.  Flavor is what this beer is all about!  Coffe, Toffee, and rich palate feel, just a joy to drink.  I highly recommend this porter!

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2004 ive liked this beer. now i finally got around to rate it. black with a tight tan head. it diminishes at a nice slow pace, becoming seemingly more rocky as it does. it finally leaves a nice frothy ring with great lacing. just a great aroma, sweet/slight chocolate and floral. same for taste, with malty roasted characteristics. has a nice slightly bitter/"hoppy" side. feels lightly cremey. good animation. excellent brew. great  and subtle aftertaste.  one rich, smooth porter. UPDATE 11/04/04 cremey and smooth, good bitter chocolate with coffee, and a nice hint of boutique with a drop of citrus fruit. downrated.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2005  Bottled.  
Dark brown with a tan head. Herbal, grassy nose, with notes of dried fruits and plum, a little vineous touch to it. Rich in flavour, notes of dried fruits, plum, light caramelly. The maltiness stands up fine against the rich hopflavour. Light maltsweet, and long, finish. Medium bodied, medium bitterness. Flavourful!
one of the better porters out ther intense red brown head witha nice hard floavour and bite smooth body and nice finsih

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2005 I rated this once before and gave it a 14. I must have been out of my mind.  This beer is outstanding.  Delicious dark chocolaty flavor, with hints of coffee,  molasses.  Just an outstanding beer.

Very deep black/red. Tan foamy head diminishing. The first smell that hit me was apples. Smells like candy, toffee, a little coffee bean perhaps, raisin. Smooth and bitter. Maybe coffee flavor, dark chocolate, with a little sourness, apple. Nice finish. Very nice for Anchor.

Dark as midnight on a moonless night with a head that looks like malted milk.  Roasted barley malt aroma with hints of caramel.  Smooth, rich,  creamy textured mouthfeel.  Some mild coffee and dark chocolate in the taste that worked well together.  Finish was way smooth.

A very nice porter. Deep dark brown, light brown/tan head. Smoky malt aroma, hints of dark chocolate and coffee. Similar flavor, coffee is more pronounced than in the aroma. Nice body, bitter finish. Good stuff
Dark brown in color with a light brown frothy head. Aroma is lightly sweet, malt, grains and chocolate. Flavor is sweet, malt,chocolate and rich. Slightly bitter finish. excellent

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2004 (draught) Rich black color with tan head. Roast aroma. Full bodied beer with hints of coffee and dark fruits. Nicely balanced between the hops and malt. Not as "smokey" as a lot of porters--I'd call this a stout.

An amazing beer, plain and simple. Tastes of roasted coffee beans, mild plums and sugar. Awesome dark tan head. Very tight carbonation giving this beer a velvety mouthfeel. Smooth as silk. Little hops. A similar sweetness comparable to an oatmeal stout shines at the finish.
Roasted, malty chocolate nose.  Pours nice and dark, good head with minimal lacing.  Malty at first, finishes with some nice hop bitterness.
A sharp odor, a dark brown color barely translucent. a sharp flavor with appreciated bitterness. A bit syrupy. The flavor is very complex with a deep palate.

Big chocolate soda like head, chocolately carmel aroma, dark chocolate first taste,creamy mouth feel at firstbut then it seemed to get a little thin, no lousy aftertaste like you get with some porters, good stuff, will buy again
Opaque, dark brown hue.  Tan, creamy head with good retention.  Caramel nose leads to nutty body with cherry notes.  Dry finish.  Outstanding beer.
UPDATED: AUG 22, 2004 Has the smell of delacate fruits that are in the taste in the front.  Finishes with a considerably burnt malt flavor.  Great beer.
The aroma is, as my roommate put it, "dark chocolate to the tenth power."  And I would have to agree about the flavor as well.  Pure black, tan head, great full-bodied taste.  A great offering.

Pours black, but not too dark, with a small creamy head.  Aroma is of black malt and a small hint of hops.  
Has a subtle chocolate malt flavor with an aftertaste of chocolate or black malt.  I guess you can say there is a strange bitterness frm the dark malts.  
There doesn't seem to be a whole lot going on in this beer and I found it seems to be very overrated IMO.  It seems like a Robust Porter that is missing something, maybe body.

A very heavy tasting porter. Not as smooth as It could be, in my mind. Nice deep malty flavor, but something is funny here. Can't quite pin it down. Smells and tastes like it's an 7% or 8% beer rather than a mere 5.6% beer. Not the best porter I've ever had...
Pours black with a tannish head and nice lacing. Nose is of roast malts and some chocolates, small fruit.  Flavor has roast malts with some coffee. Creamy finish. Nice porter.

Sweet and hoppy in almost equal parts, a strange combination. Seems too acidic on first taste and not as smooth as some other porters I've tried. Was disappointed with the mouthfeel but its still a satisfying brew and I'd definitely drink again.
Dark brown color. A lively malty aroma. Pours a rich creamy white head. Medium bodied, fairly full flavored. Very mild in the aftertaste. A very good quaffable beer.

Beer pours (in Chimay glass) a near black light has trouble penetrating with small amount of light caramel colored head that dissipates to near nothing.  Aroma is of hops, molasses sweetness.  Flavor is of medium hops that is smooth with malt that ends very dryly.  Sampled at 73 degrees Fahrenheit.

I had this a long time ago, I now I'm getting around to having it again and rating it.  Dark colored almost black, pours with a moderate head.  Aroma of chocolate and roast flavors, flavor is chocolate and malt.  Mouthfeel is creamy and thick.  Moderately sweet finish, Excellent and Classic Porter.

Bottled. Code=3FK. Pours with a thick, rocky, long lasting head, that left a lot of lacing behind.  My first sample was too cold and the aromas and taste were subdued. The warmer beer had more pronounced flavors, which I knew it would.  It had a roasted malt/coffee.  The taste was of roasted coffee with a dry hoppy finish.  I felt this beer was slightly over carbonated.  I didn't like this beer as much as other Anchor beers or as well as other porters.  It wasn't bad, but not one of the top one I've ever had.
Deep, nearly opaque ruby body and a chunky tan head.  Aroma of roasted chocolate.  Flavor of the same, also some coffee or mocha.  Creamy palate.  Why I waited so long to try this, I'll never know.
UPDATED: AUG 5, 2004 Poured an opaque brown. Nice sweet, roasted aroma. Semi-sweet and chocolatey in taste, smooth roasted aftertaste. Very good.

A very rich, sweet aroma with a full solid head. Pours a beautiful dark brown black color. Has a sweet flavor that is almost too much at times, and at a hefty price 9.99 a six-pack, will probably not be a repeat purchase. Nevertheless, it still an excellent beer.
Poured dark brown, not quite opaque, with a medium sized tan head. Aroma was chocolate with roasted malts.  Bitter dark chocolate with roasted aftertaste.  a very good porter!

This beer begins surprisingly modest, slightly roasty and a touch sweet. But as it warms the beer takes on a wonderful cedary quality that is backed by an intensely roasted espresso malt that is almost rauchbier in character. Despite these very strong flavors, the beer maintains its wonderfully well rounded nature throughout all temperature changes.
Almost black in colour.  Aroma was of sweet chocolate, slight grains and malt.  Flavour was sweet with some chocolate and a little roasty.  Finishes sweet with a clean medium bitterness.
Sweet aroma with a slight maltiness to it. Offers a robust chocolaty roasted flavor and finishes with a nice toastiness. Very delicious.

Opened the bottle and was greeted by a robust bitter chocolate and roasted malt aroma.  Poured jet black with cola colored head.  Carbonation was mild, and the mouthfeel was smooth.  Flavor was much like the aroma, bitter chocolate, toasty flavors, and hops.  Dry, bitter, but clean finish.

poured a deep rich dark brown with a nice brown head. toasted malt and chocolate aroma.  wonderful mixing of chocolate, coffee, toasted malt, sweetness, with a just a touch of hop bitterness to satisfy the taste buds. wonderful full mouthfeel, outstanding.

What a great balanced(slightly complex) porter.Reminds me of other brews(great ones)but...this one gets the crown for porters.What a great creamy head(total choco-tinted)let it sit and it almost starts to caramelize.Roasted/malt/chocolate/licorice.Nice hops profile> dry finish.A true american? classic!
