Ron once played a trick on Bob by mixing Falstaff light with molasses and putting it in an Anchor Porter bottle and recapping.  On opening it at the tasting, Bob simply noted it was sweeter than the Sierra Nevada porter we had just tasted.  Well, the real thing tastes a heck of a lot better than Falstaff light and molasses I can tell you.  Nice dark roast malt flavors and hop bitterness.  A lot more enjoyable than I would have expected given that I seldom drink dark beers.  This one I drained dry and licked the last drop from the upturned bottle.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2006 Boy is this good beer...  pours black with a brownish head.  Sweet, bitter, huge mouthfeel and a bitter finish.  A riskier combination of flavors than other notable porters, and good because of this.

A satisfyingly rich, complex porter.  Firm, creamy body with chocolate and fruit (subtle banana character) in the aroma and flavor; nice bitter hop/sweet malt balance mid-palate; mild alcohol warmth in the finish followed by a host of flavors in the aftertaste: coffee, molasses, yeasty dark bread, and a pleasant hop bitterness.  Best to let this linger and let the aftertastes develop before taking another swig.

Black licorice dominates the aroma, building anticipation for tasting.  At least three flavors run a relay-race during the swallow: an initial candy sweetness, a strong hoppy middle, and a final and enduring roasted taste.  Not to be wasted on unsophisticates.
Dark, complex, and rich (sort of like Colin Powell) this brew IS the best American-made porter, period.

This beer is black as night, with a little bit of ruby-colored tint, when held up to a strong light.  When poured, you get a large head that lasts forever.  Nose is a little malty, with chocolate, caramel, and coffee mixed in.  Flavor is outstanding - what a porter is all about.  Slightly toasted, malty, and a bit sweet.  Palate is nice and creamy smooth.  This is one of my favorites ever.

Very dark body with a scalded milk colored head. Smells of coffee/chocolate.  Very smooth feel in mouth. Taste is dark coffee and malt with chocolate and a hint of black pepper. Extremely bitter hop aftertaste for a porter. An intersting beer definately worth giving a try.
Light chocolate aroma. Plenty of roastiness, with a slight chocolate flavor. Velvety smooth. A classic porter.

Chocolate, coffee, and liquorice aroma. Almost black, trace of ultra violet, large creamy cappuccinno head. Roasted coffee, bitter chocolate, and liquorice flavours. Medium bodied, finely bitter, and dry. Terrific, very satisfying!

This brew poured a medium head of fine to medium sized light brown bubbles that were mostly lasting and left a good lacing with a opaque black brown body and no apparent carbonation.  Its aroma was mild with notes of malt and a mild alcohol smell.  Its mouthfeel is initially kind of biting, from the hops,  and finishes with a mild alcohol burn.  The flavor is mild initially and then the alcohol flavor takes over.  I can also taste some licorice in the flavor, but not much else.  I don't get the typical malt and roasted caramel or coffee flavors from this porter and it has more hops than most.  I seem to find myself bucking the trend on this one as I feel it is not the best example of the style.  On the redeeming side, I think it has a higher ABV than listed as I can feel the buzz from just a half a bottle.

First let me say that I am not a big fan of this type of brew, but I must say that this is my favourite for the style. Smoothe texture nice pour and the taste is smoothe, cold, and dark. Like I said, I am not a fan and would probably never get this again, but it was pretty good.
A dark brown color with a stable head. Some caramel/coffee comes out from the aroma. A very nice porter and one of the better beers Anchor makes.

Deep brown with bergundy glints. Fluffy tan head that left some lacing. Smells of coffee laced with molasses. Body is fairly light for a porter. The taste is a blend of coffee, chocolate and raison flavors with a hint of molasses in the slightly bitter finish . Not bad, but I was expecting a little more from this one.
Color is black with a greyish head. Taste is a chocolate and roasted malts. A very nice porter.
(Bottle) Pours a near black body with a medium, almond head. Faint aroma of malt and cocoa. Flavour of chocolate with molasses and creamy fruity finish. Nice.

I really was not enjoying this beer when it was cold, but once it warmed up, so did I. This beer appears an opaque purple/black color with a fine caramel color head. This beers taste and palate are all of the above: smooth, velvety, chocolate, smoky, & toffee like. When this beer was cold it had little flavor and little aroma; but once it became room temp all of this beers great characteristics came alive. I really did not feel that this Anchor Porter was a true representation of a porter style beer, it seems more like a stout. Overall, great beer whatever the style.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2008 A gentle pour evokes a brown-black body and khaki head. Powerful dark fruits embrace liquorice and oily coffee against a balancing almond extract twist. Short mild sweetness before an assault of plump acidity then into a drying, roasty finale. Nimble body, oily texture, restrained carbonation.

Classy combination of dried fruits and coffee on an agile base.

12 oz bottle, best before 09.2008.

Old rating was 8/4/9/5/17 = 4.3.

Rerate: Not too much to add.  Brilliantly simply chocolate, roast and mocha aromas and flavors with hints towards toasted marshmallows.  Robust and delicious and so widely available.  Bumping this up from a 3.9 to a 4.3 after downing a blissful six pack of this ebony slice of heaven.

Pours a deep burgandy almost black.  Light brown head disappears for the most part but leaves behind nice lacing.  Has a pleasant aroma of moderate malt(molasses, roasted) light hops(flowers, perfume).  Finish is more bitter than the aroma or initial flavor will lead you to believe.  Oily, medium-full body leaves behind almost a chalky feel.

Deep black color with ruby edges where the light passes through. Large head, good lacing. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, smoke, fruit and floral hops. Flavor is not overly complex, I look for more in a porter, almost a burnt carmel aftertaste. Palate was terrible, extremely acidic and musky. Bad finish and mouthfeel, almost stout like.

The color is the darkest of browns with hints of burgandy. Head is initially big and tan, but quickly diminishes. Light sweet nose with a wiff of smoke. Flavor is a balance of sweet malt start and a light, long dry bitter finish.

Color is super dark, solid black with ruby red highlights near the bottom, head is cream colored, lumpy and creamy looking about a finger high. Curtains of tight lace. Smells faintly of citrusy sharp hop with a bit of some kind of tart raisin or plum fruity darkness. Its flavor is pretty dark and smoothly menacing with a fruity punch and roasty/toastyness taste that continues with a nice mix of light chocolatey bitterness. Milds out as it warms. Feel is very medium, nearly heavy, quite smooth and a bit creamy with a really interesting light little bitterness in the mouth, tongue, and even the lips. Super good stuff.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2014 Pour a black with a tan to light brownish head which quickly dissipates.  Aroma is mild without much distinction.  Initial taste is hoppy, as it should be--nothing special, but the finish is what makes this beer.  The finish is incredibly smooth and sort of relaxing in a way.  The aftertaste is good.  The palate is a full-bodied beer.  A pretty good brew.(5/4//7/5/15)~~~~~~RE-RATE~~~~~~Yikes its beer 11 years since I last rated this beer.  The aroma on this is really nice. Of course, it has the metallic Anchor house character, but it also has a really nice chalky, sweet, chocolate maltiness present.  Its quite seductive.  Slightly transparent mahogany body with a large, foamy, rocky, tan head that takes forever to dissipate.  Starts with a light metallic flavor, before some chocolate sweetness follows.  Becomes nice and roasted in the middle, without being too harsh.  More sweetness and chocolate flavor come through late, with just a small amount of herbal hop bitterness.  This is a gorgeous brew thats incredibly well-balanced and just so damn drinkable.

Good looking porter, dark with a thick creamy head. Aroma is sweet and malty with subtle notes of coffee. Medium bodied and crisp with a slightly dry finish. Flavor is sweet roasted malt all the way. This is one of the better porters I've come across recently. Not as fine as the Fullers but a good choice just the same.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Wow, this is a great beer and one of the best porters I've had.  Aroma is good, but a little weak.  Appearance is great; very dark reddish brown and tan head that has good lacing.  Smoother than Samuel Smith's Tadcaster, but still has a decent body.  As straight lined porter as you can find, but still solid for the most part.
I love porters, and this is the best available to me -- velvety, chocolatey, malty, and gets better as it warms. Mmmmm

Very dark, with tan colored head and nice lacing. Nose of roasted malt and raisins. Slightly smokey, strong coffee and dark chocolate flavors and the finish is long, warm and balanced. This style I prefer in the wintertime. Very good.

I could just look at this beer all day and be happy.  The best thing... the head would probably still be there when I finally drank it.  Great porter taste, dry chocolate-coffee... did I mention it looks great?  Excellent beer.
My first taste of porter many years ago. Then as now I am impressed with the full body and coffee/malt finish. Good hop presence and a great dry finish
user_location: Potts Point, New South Wales, AUSTRALIA

text: this beer had a lasting head all the way to the finish.  i am a huge fan of all anchors, and this is wonderful dark beer.  very few can compare.

Not as sharp as Sierra Nevada's Porter, more mild. Beefy aroma and flavor, dry finish. Not a fan of porter but this is acceptable. Just has that dry finish that I don't care for, seems like just some roasted malt, some hops, and that's it, the show is over too fast.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2004 The quintessential porter. Great smoke and coffee notes with a nice subtle sour counter-balance and a body that is smooth as silk. A staple beer for me, particularly during the winter months. Every sip tastes better than the previous one. Lovely on tap.

A beautiful, rich porter with a creamy head, excellent roasted malt flavours and a rich fruity hoopy finish.
Superb.
Smells and looks amazing, along with tastes very good too! First couple sips and you are hooked.  Great smoked taste and wonderfully hoppy.
Really good.  Reminds me of Aventinus quite a bit.  After the first couple sips, I put it in the fridge to get it colder, and it just doesn't taste as good.

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2006 Creamy light-cocoa colored head, viscous dark body with ruby-brown highlights.  Wonderful chocolatey aromas with a little raisin, over-ripe fruit.  Smooth, sweet, roasty, and slightly bitter.  Bitterness lingers, but does little to dry out the body.
Almost black colour. Mature cheesy aroma. Some initial smokyness (bacon) in the flavour. The finish is hoppy, bitter and dry.
This beer was slightly above average.  I did not think it tasted like a stout as much as some of the other raters.  Good finish to the beer.
Reminds me more of a stout. Very candy like and sweet. Smooth with a bitter finish, hoppy bitter nose. Excellent...above par.

dark black color, hoppy aroma; nice head with everlasting lacing; taste of dates with creamy texture.  Very nice.  Shared a warm six pack with an ecletic few in the wee hours of the first spring morning after a slight rain fall. we all agreed: very nice, very nice indeed.
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: First porter.  Looks and smells like stout.  Taste is like stout but a little milder.  Very good overall.

Big, tight, dirty brown head with a lotto sticky brown laceing.Dark ass porter, opaque.Malty sweet nose.Med/full body.Slick mouthfeel. Sweet malty flavors some grassiness? and roasted malt flavors show themselves in the finish. A little more hop, please.

Bottled. Very dark brown, possibly black. Low on the gas with lovely roasted malt and deep burnt caramel aromas. Juicy feel to it with sweet porter finish. Yummm. My only complaint is the bottles size, its far to small.
Almost black. Very nice aroma with chocolate and perhaps plums? Flavour is initially slightly sweet with roasted malts. Finish is long and nicely bitter. A great porter!

I realized, after tasting another Anchor Porter tonight, that this beer reminds me quite a bit of Mackeson XXX Stout.  Its smooth, relatively thin body is dominated by complex malts.  If you like sweet porters, you will like Anchor (I also recommend Arcadia London Porter).  This is one of my favorite porters, a beer to be reckoned with (for all who dare challenge its rank).
Dark roasted coffee porter. Destinctly bitter flavor. flavors nicely blended and compliment each other well.  Thumbs up!

Very nice aroma; sweet with strong roasted malt and some berries. Opaque body with a large, tan, creamy, rocky head. Roasted malt flavor; not too strong but smooth. Very good but not exceptional like the Liberty.

Wow, this is a very well done beer. It had everything that I would look for in a Porter. Smooth roastiness, bitter, burnt , malty, carmel, and a tad fruity. It is a delicious beer. I didn't want to get to the end of the glass. I will say that this beer demonstrates what's right with Anchor.

Has a very dark brown color with moderate carbonation and a creamy roasted malt smell.  Taste, when you get throught the thick head, is very roasted and finishes with just the right amount of bitterness.  Overall a very good porter from my favorite city...

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2003 Deep brown - almost black - with a small chocolate milk head. Roasty aroma that smells like a chocolate malted with a shot of espresso. Nice mouthfeel, not as thin as many porters, but not as chewy as a stout. Well balanced flavour of sweet malt and bitter hops, with a dry licorice finish. A really fine porter.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2004 This is a very good porter.  Unlike most porters, this one does not make me yearn for a stout.  This one has enough to it.  Very creamy.  Flavor are very rounded.  Very nice roasted flavors.  Rerate 090904:  I just wanted to add that I smell a lot of cherry in it this time.  I bumped it up one point on the aroma.

Very nice porter!  It was less hoppy and fizzy than most porters you will find.  The aroma reminded me of Samuel Smith's Oatmeal Stout.   
The heavy malts are not too strong, making this one very smooth porter.

Nice bottle! Pours almost black. Thick lasting head, nice lacing. Nose is malt/sweet, hinting chocolate and licorice. Thick mouthfeel, smooth and creamy. Roasty malt and bittersweet chocolate with a good dose of licorice. Finishes slightly bitter. VERY nice porter. Good job guys!
A rich black color with a small tan head. Smells fruity like banana. Has a medium to full body. Not much flavor and light on the palate.

A deep black body with a frothy head. Aromas of malt, bananas...I find that aroma in porters quite a bit. A coffee and malt flavor. Some sweetness followed by a bitter finish. A nice medium to full body. The best porter is Black Butte by Deschutes. This doesn't even compare in my opinion. I don't really know how it is ranked so high, but it is totally enjoyable. Maybe Black Butte is harder to find and not rated as often.

Pours black with a creamy, although small, tan head. Nice cascading lace. Moderate aroma of coffee and molasses. Starts lightly sweet, creamy texture. The kind of beer you don't want to swallow. Finishes with a well balanced bitterness. Excellent porter.
Nicely done.  Not too rich with heavy roasted malts.  Hints of chocolate throughout.  Yummm

Perfect deep garnet color. Thick, creamy light brownish head. Rich palate, creamy and delicious. Sheets of lace. Roasty aroma. Light but smooth flavor. Roasted malts, cofee with cream, bitter finish. A positively beautiful porter.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2003 This should be the measuring stick for the porter style. Balances the malt and hops out nicely. Good rich chocolate/coffee taste and full bodied. This is just amazing. This has to be a top 5 porter for anyone who enjoys the style!
Dark black-brown with a creamy tan head. Fruity, burnt raisin aroma. Rich and decadent with roasted malt flavors and some sweetness to keep this in balance. Smooth from beginning to end.

A black beer with a light brown head. The aroma is slightly smokey - but not enough for a porter. And the flavor is dominated by a sweet smoked taste - not my preference of a porter because of too little smoked malt - but a nice beer.

A wonderful porter.  This beer has a dark brown color with a pleasing, potent aroma.  Anchor Porter is smooth with a creamy, rich, almost 'chocolaty' flavor.  This is an excellent choice to sit back and relax with.

- deep, dark brown color with a light red toffee colored hue, light head, aroma is of bitter, roasted malt mixed with hops, light coffee/mocha aromas as well; rich roasted malt flavor, nice texture, a mix of sweetness  chocolate, and bitter roasted malt and hops
This is a good porter! Dark brown/ruby. No carbonation. Sweet malt aroma. Flavor is roasted and sweet with hints of coffee. It's very creamy and smooth. Really good stuff!

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2004 Big nose of sweet coffee & chocolate.  Small, med-brown head, gone fairly quick.  At first taste there is not much at all, but after about 5 seconds, a soothing milky coffee coating washed over my mouth.  This porter manages to do something very few other can: be smooth on the tongue while still grainy.  The aftertaste is long and rich.
This is a nice, strong brew. It has a very heavy aroma and has good flavor. I must say though that it is a bit too sweet for my taste. A very thick, creamy head and strng flavor. It is a nice beer.
A solid beer, I think this is a good example of an american porter. Not too bitter and mabye a little sweet.

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2007 Dark color, almost black. Quickly dissappearing head, brown lacing. Aroma of heavy malts, bacon, salami. Barley malt taste, typical non-belgian, licorice, coffee. Very weak porter. This is soooooo overrated...
A nice porter. No complaints about this one. Good effort...not to mention that this is one of the more widely available porters in the US.

Malty toasted nose.  Deep black hue with a small fast diminishing light brown head.  Has a slightly earthy hoppy taste with a chocolate and coffee after taste.  This is a great full bodied and complex beer that is simply superb.

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2003 2003-05-15, 5-5-5-3-11Dark color. Some malt aroma; phenol. Malt mouthfeel, some roasted malt, caramel, phenol again! (maybe too warm).2003-02-08, 7-5-8-5-16Black color, brownish persistent head, nice perlage. Pleasant nose of malt, roasted malt; light medicine. Excellent mouth feeling, wrapping, roasted malt, light coffee, light liquorice, roasted nuts, malt, some sweetness. Powerful final, long, a lot bitter and with a bold liquorice character.
strong malty aroma, dark and opaque hue, no head or lacing, little carbonation, malts, hops present in a complex flavour, full bodied, hints of coffee in aftertaste
This was a very good porter!  Nice rich black color with creamy head, deep somewhat coffee flavor, and a little hoppy.  I enjoyed this porter very much.

Dark brown/ruby body. Thin tan head. No lacing.
Heavy clove in the aroma mixed with roasted coffee aromas.
Thin, papery body with a very unpleasent bitter bite. Chocolate is there too but thin. I have 'lots of Saaz' in my notes. I'm assuming this beer was very stressed before it got to my hands.
Very chalky mouthfeel but it hits the mark for carbonation.
Definite re-rate due to old beer.
Good color, good amount of head.  Awsome taste.  Very tastey.  Creamy and smooth.  Perfect amount of sweetness.
Very creamy and malty porter, defintly on the list as one of my favs.

1/28/03:  bottle.  nice, thick, creamy tan head accompanied by a deep dark brown colored body.  good amount of lacing.  sweet malt nose.  roasted, hoppy and some sweetness at the end.  some coffee hints also noted.  nice smooth finish.
Just as good as Anchor Steam!  The taste was kind of like those malt balls you get at the movie theatre.  Very creamy and frothy.  Very yummy!

Dark brown to near black color with a tall tan head that leaves rings as you partake. Mildly sweet mocha and grainy aroma.  Creamy feel with a light carbonation tingle.  Light bittersweet flavors.  Mild malt acidity in the finish. A porter that you could chew on all night, I might!

For all the reputation of being a steamed beer this was extremely bland for a porter. I could not smell or taste any of the chocolate/coffee/roasted flavors that are to be expected of a porter.  This was essentially a dark water.  The west coast bias is influencing the rating of this beer.
Smell and taste are sweet but not too sweet.  Rich, creamy, and delicious beer.
A real hearty beer, one of the heaviest i have ever had. lots of malty character that finishes of with a sweet after taste.
Just finished my sample and ready for another one of these brilliant porters.
This is a very heavy porter. It"s got a nice head while having a nice balanced complex flavor.
Its just damn good.
This is some good stuff.Coffee,chocolate, and overall enjoyment. Black & brown fills the glass with flavor,this beer ought to be available instead of Guinness at restaurants.
Same old porter, different company...aley taste, not too burnt and carameley...but thats about it from the taste!
Very good. Strong coffee notes in the aroma, nice head. Rather bitter, but sweet at the same time. Very full-bodied amd powerful in spite of the rather weak alcohol content.

Nice dark brown to black color, light can only be seen through it at the very edges of the glass. the head is brown and very lacy, and lasts through the whole pint.  coffee and a hint of chocolate in the aroma.  the taste features the same things the aroma does but also includes a touch of hop flavor but more bittering.  the bitterness balances well with what would otherwise be a sweet brew as there seems to be a hint of caramell hiding along side of the hops.  great clean finish leaves the mouth ready for another sip.
Very dark with a thick, long lasting head. Coffeeish smell, and taste. A bit of chocolate taste as well. Slightly acidic.

Dark brown, tan foamy head.  Fresh fruit and light roast in the nose.  Body is roasty with hints of light chocolate.  Finishes hoppy and long.  Not really my type of porter, not well balanced and lacking in complexity.  Not bad, but not a stellar example.
Black with brown head. Chocolate malt nose. Rich malt flavor with mild alcohol heat

Very nice porter.  This was much better on tap than in the bottle.  Nice beige head.  This beer had more carbonation than most porters which was great by my accounts.  Excellent flavor....sweetness, fruits.  Went down smooth without a wince. RERATE: A New Years 03 treat!  This beer reminds me of talking to that hooker in Vegas for some reason.  Anyways, I cant get over how great this beer pours....the way the thick head rushes to the top while the dark liquid cascades down through the head like water through a rocky stream. This run had notes of whiskey in the nose which I didnt catch last time.  A very full and creamy brew which will always be welcome in my fridge.

Quite a warm, full, tasty 
porter.  Really good with 
food in winter.

Medium, creamy, tan head.  First taste is malty and mildy sweet with a slightly bitter stout-like finish.  Tastes of wood, chocolate, nuts, and fruit...  Surprisingly, it also finishes with the strangest smoked beef jerky taste that seemed a bit out of place.  Very satisfying low-profile hop finish that wasnt too strong;  something that most American brewers could learn a lesson for when brewing similar beers.  Overall, I was pretty impressed, but I didnt care mch for the smoked taste, but it gives it character.  Anchor continues to impress me.  They have some fanastic brewers.

This porter was dripping with roasted barley, with malty, coffee and chocolate undertones in the aroma. The pour was a glacial black, with my reflection still evident even in light..a true jet black porter with a creamy beige colored head that lasted throughout...a nice touch for a porter. The taste begins with an all out malt assault on the front and sides of the tongue, followed with a carbonated tickling of the middle of your tongue, and then the bittering dryness of those thinly spread hops and the real attack of those roasted barleys hitting the roof of your mouth, the back of your throat and the back of your tongue. A nice creamy head adds to this enjoyment. My only knock on this is the intense ending bitterness is probably a bit too much here, and the aroma is not anything i would call unique in any respects. Overall however a good staple for around the house and another must try again for the list.

This was the one I was waiting for. It was the one I kept drinking while we talked about wyat a great tour they run and how much fun the place is. It took a while to warm to its best temperatures but it was nice and dark and has great nose (warm) and taste.

Slowly diminishing, frothy, tan head.  Subtle chocolatey-malty aroma.  Very nice.  Very dark mahogoney color.  Smooth chocolate-malt taste transitioning into a delicate coffee finish.  Anchor does it right, once again.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2003 2J1 bottle code (October 2002 tasting). Withstood one of the hottest summers on record in non-climate controlled warehouse. Enormous rocky oily head. Huge flavor profile; alternating hops, chocolate and traces of coffee. Long, dry finish.
2G? bottle code (December 2002 tasting). Huge rocky head; intense, molasses-like, then choclate, then subtle coffee, wow, when fresh, the definative example of the style!

This is a fine example from what we expect from the folks at Anchor.  Great initial flavour, smooth palate, pleasant aroma and the presence of hops (perhaps understated for me).  I will agree that the viscosity is a bit thin, however the does not detriment the overall impression too severely.
At first, a sweet sting, giving way to a understated bitterness that continues. Very nice indeed.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2007 Ive had this beer many times over the past few years, but never rated it. This is the defining beer for many a young person, I think.  First off, I think it is very true to style; a bit thin, fair to great carbonation with a thin lasting head, quite dark (rubyish with intense light) in the glass. Chocolate malt sweet/nut aroma and flavor, dark malt roasted coffee and bitterness, some (although not a lot) hop bitternes in the close. All in all, an exceptional package. The only beer I know  so closely that I waited this long to rate. And, this will be one of several beers of honor at my birthday party the 28th; the hostess  (a professor colleague) loves it, weve got this years seniors travelling back into town to celebrate, and students of mine over the past two years will be coming from far flung places such as Boston and Providence. Im a lucky man.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Coffee flavour and aroma is prominent with this lightly hopped beer.  Overwhelmingly smooth palate on the palate.  A brilliant beer.

Nose is very, very malty; I was expecting more hops from a west coast brewer. Initial taste is a tiny bit sour, and then youre pummeled with an explosion of deep, dark, roasted mocha-chocolate malts. Not so much a bitter chocolate, but a sweet and creamy chocolate flavor. Very low carbonation, which I like; this is what brings the malt flavors out instead of just ending up with fizzy hopwater, which seems to be popular among west coast breweries. However, there are hops here, and they are well done. They lend a floral aroma to the beer and a mildly bitter finish. Different from other porters Ive had, but very, very nice.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2003 Initially rated on 21Nov2002 One of my favorite Porters; probably closer to a 'stout', whatever that means.
Color: Dark ruby.  Head: thin, quick to recede, and not too fine, but persistent enough to keep an appropriate level of effervescence throughout the drinking.
Aroma: Fairly subdued, but with noticeable vanilla, and a hint of caramel.
Body: Full, but surprisingly clean-finishing.  Commensurate with the level
of hopping and alcohol content.  Hops: Lots of bittering, little to no
aromatics.  Flavor: Very roasty, slightly astringent, quite bitter, with a 
nice hint of cherries.

just about black, foamy tan head.  sweet raisiny, chocolatey aroma.  good mouthfeel.  nice and roasty.  sweet/tart dried fruit flavours.  a tasty and well balanced porter with everything in its place.

The taste of alcohol is definatly present in the flavor.  For a porter, its pretty light, but dont take that the wrong way.  Over all, I am very impressed with this beer.  As far as Im concerned this is right up there with Bells porter.
One of the best american porters, if not the best.  Medium body, with a big roasty sweetness.  Hops carry through the front.  If you want to get into the porter style, heres the one to try.
dark and heavy...lots fo good different flavor but kind of weak on the alcohol

jet black body with a nice chocolatey brown head.  Nose is full of ripe fruits, dates, raisins and definitely prunes.  Chocolate in there too!  Roastedness comes through well as I got closer to the bottom.  I think It would be perfect if there were more pronounced hop flavors especially on the finish.
Great porter with wonderfull chocolate flavors.  I think I might like this better than the Bells porter/

How much do I love this Beer ??  Example: Head to head I picked Fullers London SLIGHTLY.  However, vs. great Stout (Victory Storm King), Anchor shows MUCH BETTER than Fullers.  Maybe just the bottle sample. Anyway, Anchor Porter is just one of my VERY favorite beers... in Top 10 easily.  Main reason: great nose, complex, fruity... not the heavy tar of many Porters ( i like that too).
Yum. Best porter Ive tried. Really great roasty taste, full body, and LONG palate. Should almost be considered a stout. Oh..also thick and creamy.
Good porter, but I could taste the alcohol in it.  I was surprised by that since its not that strong.  Ill try to gect another bottle and re-rate.  Nice brown head, very thick.

Better than average porter.  Very one-dimensional.  It tastes and smells like chocolate, and thats pretty much it.  Some nice subtle hoppiness.  It looks great in the glass and smells delicious.  Its nothing special though.

This porter was excellent, yet failed to reach expectations. Black bodied with a rich too thick chocolate head that settled like the islands in a rootbeer float.  A rounded malt chocolate presence greeted my nose as well as some alchol and hops. The flavor was a bit robust and sharp malt with chocolate and alcohol appearing again to add an imperial stout like dimension. A fine, well-balanced porter that is good to have within arms reach.
Wow. A sumptuous porter that simply knocked me out.
Very excellent porter, almost black in color, nice tan to beige head, lots of roasted & burnt flavors, rich aftertaste, great porter

This beer took a while for me to appreciate, and Im not sure why.  The aroma is kind of weird--really sweet in an odd sort of way.  The flavors are nice, chocolate, coffee, a touch roasted.  The flavors are mild and pleasant, if the nose was nicer it would rank much higher with me.
eh. its a completely acceptable porter, but theres not much special about it.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2004 aroma was sweet chocolate and coffee...HUGE tan head, dark brown color,. roasted coffee flavor with a malty coffeeish finish and lots of bitterness..very nice porter although i found it too bitter for the style.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2007 This is seriously just about the best beer Ive had.  It is certainly the best porter Ive had.  You will definitely not regret gettting some of this.

(Couple weeks later) Ive come to the conclusion that this is currently my favorite beer.  The balance of flavor is just awesome.  There isnt really any one aspect of the beer that overpowers, its just wonderfully smooth and even.  Definitely worth the premium price. Delicious roasted malt aroma, with some chocolate and coffee notes. The flavor follows the nose, with chocolate being the strongest flavor, along with coffee, malt and a nice, restrained hoppiness.

Thick black and viscous.  There are tons of coffee and chocolate notes in the aroma.  Very robust, yet smooth with a general roasted coffee flavor throughout.  Plenty of sweet malt upon first sip and a nice balance of bittering hops.  The finish is slighty dry and flavorful leaving you thirsting for more.

Close to being great, but slight lack of head keeps it down in rating.
Alittle heavier body would help, but great roasted malt hits you at first taste.  Slight raisin aroma at first pour.  Very drinkable on cool fall evening.

Re-Rate 11/13/02: The beer pours a deep brown, with garnet hues; the head is Herculean, spumous, light chocolate in color, and the lace in large clumps. Nose is malt, caramel, light toasted grains, somewhat sweet.  Start is malt and ambrosial, the top skimpy, the finish has a germane hop presence, pointfully acidic with a dry malt aftertaste. Quite the decent porter, not overpowering, or under whelming, just plain Good. Ranks #272 on my current 1000 beer master list.
oh yah heres a porter with some character nice flavor and balance with a slight but distinct choclate over tone well made.

Wow.  I can remember actually disliking this beer--what a fool.  This is a tremendous porter.  Dark fruit and chocolate in abundance in the nose.  Flavor of chocolate and dark fruit, trading dominance again and again throughout the swallow framed nicely by dark malt dryness and hops.  Truly wonderful.

Very nice colour. Almost black, with a light brown creamy head. Aroma of coffee and alcahol and hints of chocolate and spices. The flavour is roasted and have notes of coffee, chocolate, burned almonds and spices. Complex and challenging. Has an excellent aftertaste of bitter chocolate, and in the dying stages i have some apple notes. This is a great porter.
One terrific Porter!  Beautiful color and terrific head.  Nice hops addition to the coffee flavoring.  The first sip was nice and the last was even better.  Very tasty.
UPDATED: MAY 24, 2004  A cherry aroma, a thick, creamy head, Great flavor, a classic Porter.
Daddy likes.

The best porter I have had yet. WOW, a head that you could float Delta Burke on!  Very dark in color, like a good porter it allows no light to pass through it when held to a light.  Aroma of chocolate malt and perhaps cinnimon.  Not overly sweet.  This is crisp and not flat tasting like most porters I have had.
Creamy and smooth.  A really top notch, mild porter.
This is one to keep in the fridge. Perfect blend off coffee and chocolate. This is one of my favorite porters.

Very good porter.  Deep rich black color, with a chocolaty-floral aroma.  Nice creamy feel on the palate.  Flavor is a great combination between dark chocolate and floral tones.  A great bitterness nicely rounds off the sweetness.  Nice.

Near black, nice creamy light brown head, slightly lace. Creamy, taffy?, soft and a bit rousted malty nose. Silk soft and balanced, pretty full body, rousted malty, a bit bit bitter. Aftertaste is rousted malty and long, maybe a bit of coffee-like.
Overall pleasant soft and creamy porter.

Bittersweet chocolate, anisette aroma.  Thick tan head.  Deep ruby-black hue.  Oh what a palate.  Vinous fruit, chocolate, coffee, toffee, caramel accents, burnt grain, licorice, brown sugar.  Theres so much going on here, molasses as it warms.  Medium bodied, and the finish is oh so delicious.  Long and sweet, turning to a hint of bitter hops.  I love this prter, one of my favorites, a masterpiece, always available, and always excellent.

This beer has a light tan head that doesnt stick around for too long, and a very drak red-brown color.  As for taste, think of dehydrated fruit covered w/ dark chocolate.  I cant say much for an aroma, Im not picking much up even w/ the beer warmed up a bit.
Deep, dark mahogany color. Large creamy head. Big chocolate aroma with some hops in the background. Light bitterness. Full malt flavor. Chocolate flavor dominates. Creamy. Nice!

Black with ruby tones shining through. Excellent espresso smell, i think I smell anise. Head is rolling back to a thin slick of bubbles. Coffee and bitter chocolate flavors. Heavy bodied coffee feel on the palate. Smokey hint on the tongue. Long bitter chocolate finish. Yum! This could be great for breakfast.
Very strong, crisp coffee flavor.  Quite good!

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2008 Original Rating Oct 23, 2002:  Mmmmmm... Anchor Porter.  Cold espresso with some roasted malt added.  Very fine.  9/5/8/5/18  Re-rate Aug 9, 2008:  Ah early ratings... It’s about time I got back to this one.  Dark brown color with a large, long lasting head.  Sweet malt and lightly toasted aroma.  Bitter roasted malt taste, almost astringent.  A little bit of coffee and chocolate.  Still a staple Porter, but nowhere near "the shit" that I originally thought this was.  But who could blame me?  It was one of my first real beers!

Black with a fiery ruby core.Thick tan head fades quickly.Nose of roasted malt,some coffee and bitter chocolate.Nice full palate with a velvety texture. This is the one I would offer to someone as a representative of the style. Cant go wrong with this.
Good tasting porter. Has a nice dark color and a good coffee/chocolate flavor.
Very very smooth with an interesting mix of hops/burnt hops and malt.  Definite coffee and chocolate flavors in there too.  Great porter.

No head. The nose is dominated by licorice and black coffee. The palate is rich, but medium in body. The hops are there, but not overwhelming. Much of the bitterness seems to come from dark malts. The finish is long and full of bittersweet chocolate. A good bottom fermented porter.

A dark brown to black beer is topped with a thick head. The coffee like malt aroma is laced with hints of chocolate and licorice.   the flavor is slightly smokey with coffee and licorice and the finish is dry and full of coffee flavor.

Deep black color, large thick creamy head. Roasted malt aroma. Deep rich roasted malts and flavor.  Coffee and chocolate flavor. Slightly sweet. Good hop to malt balance. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is smooth and slightly hoppy. Aftertaste is slightly bitter, with a very slight metallic tinge. Nice tasting porter, smooth and very drinkable.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2008 Chocolate and roasted malts, sweet with bit of vanilla though slight metallic nose. Dark brown-black with big, lacing frothy light brown head. Medium-light oily body with low-med carb. Mellow roastiness with mild coffee-like bitterness. Sweet to start followed by smooth sweet nutty after.  A very nice porter. Updated on 2008-02-02: Either the recipe has changed a bit or Im just not as impressed as before; Downgraded my numbers to 3.8 from 4.2. Still a nice porter, but not as "wow" as I thought in the earlier days.
Lovely balance of port and mocha-like flavors.  Warm and rich, lovely color, too, although a slightly thin body.  Very much won my approval. (on tap, Flying Saucer, Addison, TX)

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2003 pours black with a billowing tan head (not sure how that happened) aroma is a light coffee, and roasted malt. flavor is kind of sweet, with a licorice flavor.  not as robust as I remember it being the last time I had it. my tastes may have changed since then, but this is still a wonderful porter.
Mark me down as big fan.  This porter pours with a thick, although quick dissolving head.  Color is more of a deep, deep  dark mahogony than a true black.  Very roasted flavor.

Chestnut to near black in appearance. Earth toned color head with a steady stream of bubbles marching to the surface single file. Aromas of liquorice, bread, chocolate and toffee. Roasted flavors of espresso without the cloying bitterness. Hops are quite restrained but with you every step of the way. Body could be beefed up a bit but all in all a deliciously complex porter.

The most chocolatey porter I have experienced to date.  This one isnt abundant in coffee flavor like a lot of porters Ive had recently.  Not too thick or thin and mildly carbonated, goes down nicely.

The creaminess and subtle sweetness reminds me more of the better oatmeal stouts (ie. Samuel Smith).  This is probably one of the smoothest porters Ive had.  Im a big fan of anchor beer, and this is, by far, my favorite.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2003 This one pours a very dark brown, almost black, color with a small tan head that lingers. The aroma is malty with touches of roasted coffee and a slight sweetness. Full bodied, the flavor is malty, with roasted flavors of espresso and molasses coming through. The finish is full of roasted malts and has a lingering sweetness with just a hint of hops. This is a fantastic porter, ranking up there with Fuller's, Rogue's, and Sierra Nevada's as one of the best.

Very dark brown body, very little light gets through. Head is tall and tan, but fades pretty quickly. Laced the mug nicely. Smells a little sweet, a little alcoholish. Taste is great. Good balance of malt and hops. A little coffee, a little less chocoloate. Burnt and tasty all the way through. Another great beer from a great brewery.

Beer is quite dark, the head fades away quickly. Chocolate aroma.
Malty taste, then more bitter and a little burned coffee aftertaste (in a positive way).
Roasted flavor with a weak nose and a bit thin.  Very dark with a quickly diminishing head.  Slight malt hints.
Im not quite sure what a porter is supposed to taste like, but this sure is an excellent beer.  All kinds of flavors going on here, great feel and finish.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: Burnt wood nose, dry and roasty malts ruled the taste. Almost winish at the end, very solid. dark and creamy.

This beer rocks.
The nose is of burnt malt, molasses and dark chocolate. The color is dark red/crimson when held up to the light. The frothy, light brown head is mostly lasting with good lacing. I really love the flavors in this beer. Very complex. Lightly bitter and acidic. Also just a touch sour and salty on the back end. The mouthfeel is full and creamy with soft carbonation. The beer finishes very dry on the palate. Excellent porter.

beautiful lookin beer - almost black but in fact very dark braun i reckon. nice 2 culla foam tan with cappuccino splotches although that couldave been the previous beer. like a really bitter chocolate milk. lots of smokiness and bitterness and coffee stuff - no fruit which is the way i like it. hooray for america. no not really but hooray for this beer anyway.
Im gonna score this one well mainly because it had a great close.  Very smooth and flavorful.  Overall, a very good porter.
very dark brown. Slight tastes of chocolate & coffee. A nice roasted tasting finish

A staple porter with ambiguous hints of bitter hops.  Smooth and silky. Excellent close that last forever! Color is deep dark brown.  Edges when held in light have a deep dark amber red hue.  Tremendous porter.
iced coffee appearance and flavour. some bitter chocolate and banana. theres a lot going on there and it could be slightly stronger
One of the worlds great beers.  Looks and smells so nice, and the taste follows up to it.  One of the top three porters on the planet, along with Fullers and Sam Smiths.
UPDATED: NOV 20, 2003 Dark frothy head, very dark color, and good amount of carbonation.  An excellent porter with a long roasted, burnt aftertaste. Drinking one of these is almost as fun as DANCING!
A very nice beer with a smooth Malted flavor and a nice roasted aftertaste.
Roasty. Deep. Another great beer from Anchor, equally good at room temperature and chilled, just excellent in general.
great porter; wonderful malt flavor and the slight hoppiness that isnt overpowering is exquisite. i love this brewer
Near black. Nice chocolate aroma. Slightly sweet in the nose. Richly malty. Hints of licorice. Balanced bitterish finish. Very good!
GOod stuff.  Man, what righteous shit this is.

Malty aroma, with just a hint of hop, a dark brown/ruby color, with a tan head.  Fairly smooth front to back, with just a slightly watery feel detracting from the score.  Still, its a good porter, and worth a try.
deep garnet color, dense tan head. aroma of dark chocolate.  reminiscent of chocolate covered espresso beans.  very nice finish
UPDATED: NOV 18, 2004 Great porter. Dark brown body with a fluffy brown head. Chocolate and coffee notes throughout. Not as rich as I would have liked, but still Anchors best beer.
Creamy.

Dark brown to black color with a tan, creamy head that lasts throughout.  Excellent aroma of molasses, butterscotch and prune, with a hint of alcohol.  Flavor matches the aroma, with an initial sweetness followed by a lingering bitter aftertaste.  Mouthfeel was a little disappointing, a little watery.  Overall, a pretty good porter.
Im not big into porters, but this is pretty good stuff.  Beautiful color, nice head, and very crisp, long finish.  Aftertaste is excellent.  A very very good beer from a very very good brewery.
This is the first beer I tried from the Anchor line and was very impressed.  Unlike many of the English porters there was a true after taste that made you want more.
good.. not much of a porter fan.  Still love the Anchor line though

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2004 Before I rate, Id just like to thank 'krisbierjaeger' for some of the most truly provocative, intense, mind boggling and entertaining reviews I have ever laid eyes upon.
That said.. this beer is excellent. Full bodied, smooth, brimming with flavor (almost a sweet coffee taste). Best anchor Ive had, and easily one of the best porters I'll ever have.
HUZZAH, what a troglodyte!

TAP- Deep dark black; Fantastic head that was dense and lingered; Wonderful aroma that requires poetry I cant pull off. Oiliness that swirls in the mouth. A sweetness that is exquisite. Dare I say, better then the Fullers- Yes, I will shout it from the mountaintop.
A terrific porter, as porters go.  A touch sweet.  Roasted malt is present, as it should be.  Hint of bitterness in the aftertaste.  Cute bottle.

deep and dark, huge tan head to start but it dissapates fast. Aroma of strong grains and hops with a hint of coffee. Taste is warm with a medium mouth feel starting with a light malty chocolate and moving to a slightly bitter coffee the taste lingers long after the last drink.

One of the best porters Ive had.  Nice deep dark brown body with a lightish brown head.  Great aroma of coffee and dark caramel malts with some hops in the background.  Great smooth taste which leaves me wanting another one.
Good dark color and well balanced.  Would have enjoyed more head retention, yet the flavor was somewhat carbonated.  Smooth sweet and fruity.
Very good porter.  Slight coffee taste, but it tastes more like a beer than something from Starbucks, unlike some porters.  Every tme I have it, it gets better and better.

this troglodyte foamed up to greet me when i popped the top. the head is like a crusted manhole cover capping a cavernous abyss of sooty darkness.  heavy malts rumble from subterranean depths like faraway subway trains, theres an echoing drip of coffee and molasses, a plaintive drone of yeasty pipes.  hops wailing like hissing steam and station whistles-- but soothed and muted by the dark distance.  warm alcohol vapors and the fresh silky palatte alternate like shifting air currents. a sweet, reposeful submersion.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2005 A wonderful classic Porter. Dark, well balanced. I cant wait to get back to SF for a visit and try this on tap!
Re-rate: 3/20/05 Its been two and a half years from my last sip of this wonderful Porter. Time hasnt changed my mind, its still a great beer. Rich molasses, a touch of soy sauce and traces of smoke with a floral hoppy bitterness all combine to make a wonderful thick chewey beer. I do like this very much!
A very nice porter indeed. Nice rich brown appearance and slightly alcoholic in taste it also boasts coffee and malt.  Although the head died faster than a whippet buzz, it was quite delicious.

I dont know - I just love this beer ... West Coast homer perhaps? Have had it many times - from bottle, from tap - its my goto beer and always on hand at my home. $6.99 a sixer is a great price, IMHO, at Bevmo.

Dark, deep appearance. Creamy, tan head. Medium to thick mothfeel. Complex taste of coffee, syrup and chocolate. Goes dowm smooth - nice aftertaste with hints of burnt coffee. Love it - good stuff!!

Very hoppy on the nose especially for a porter, with some nice roasty malt in the aroma aswell. Slight sweet start, and then leeds in to a roasty malty middle and hoppy finish. I liked it OK, but i thought the hops didnt quite blend with the malt and the texture didnt quite click either (almost milky with a hoppy, malty bite) IMHO.

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2003 had the bottle. So sour and bitter. Like an extra dark roast coffee.  I like it alot, takes some getting used to, but not many complaints about it. very very strong and dark beer.
For me, its a tough choice between Anchor and Sierra Nevada for my favorite...you wont go wrong with either.  Beautiful color, and great head.
Glory in the form of licorice and chocolate…Stunning deflagration of herbal coffee, anise and roasted malt…Sweet fireworks of fresh hops for an unstoppable Porter celebration…

Bottle.  A solid black color with a slightly frothy head that quickly turns to lace.  Almost a creamy flavor with a kind of grainy burnt coffee grind aftertaste.  The bitter chocolate tart flavors rest in the back of the mouth long after the sip is complete.

This is a very good beer, but Im not quite sure its a porter! Its appearance, aroma, and flavor are all more suggestive of something between a doppelbock and a schwarzbier. Its body, also, is a bit light for a porter, more like that of a dark lager. Because of all this, I cant really say its a good porter, though it is quite good on its own terms.
One of the nicest porters ive had. Dark with medium tan head. Great mouthfeel. smooth and extremly drinkable.

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2003 I may have gotten a bad bottle. There was absolutely no head. I smelled smokey molasses. The taste was a combination of chocolate, coffee and cough syrup! Overall I liked it. I was just disappointed in the lack of head. 
Re-Rate:
I definitely got a bad bottle last time. This one poured an almost opaque dark brown color (ruby highlights when held up to a light) with a large creamy beige head. The aroma had a distinctive sour milk character, some nice chocolate, roasted, slightly smokey. The flavor was sweet...caramel, roasty toasty, burnt chocolate, hops bitterness, prunes, slightly sour. Perfect amount of carbonation...crisp, yet smooth. This beer is the most "old-fashioned" beer I've ever tasted.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2003 Pours dark brown almost black with a small tan head, fruity chocoloate aromas. Sweet chocolate and burnt coffee flavors, medium body and a nice mild hop bite, but very smooth, a great porter and fairly easy to find.
Mild nose, strong sweetish coffee and chocolate flavors, rich mouthfeel. Looks good in the glass, too.
Great dark color and rich chocolaty aroma that I loved. Good strong flavor nothing too complex though. A little more bitter than I would prefer, but overall quite good.

Almost completly black, head was short lived which suprised me. Nice chocolate malt nose, maybe a hint of coffee. Taste is pretty much the same. Starts off with smooth black and chocolate malt, full bodied. Finishes with some hop bitterness and some roasty notes. Damn smooth all the way through...the best porter I have tried.
A superb porter.  Wonderful chocolate taste (and aftertaste).  Goes down so smooth I could drink this all night.
Malty beer with hints of coffebeans and caramel! Kicks on the roof of the tongue and nice aftertaste, that lasts very long! Just mmmmmmmhhhhh!

This beer poured out a very dark color. Formed a nice dark tan head with little lace(may have to adjust my frigs temp). Nice aroma of malt and coffee to it. The taste of it was quite interesting. Had not only the elements of coffee to it, but the flavor associated with it, toffee. It gives it an interesting finish. Well worth checking out for fans of dark beers.

I first had this while camping in Lake Tahoe.  For a beer purchased at a Safeway I was pleasantly pleased.  Fairly complex roasted malt flavor with slightly burnt or coffee after taste. Nicely carbonated and holds up well in the bottle.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2003  Rerate  - Well, this was my very first rating about 18 months ago - still tastes just as great - notice a bit more smooth chocolate flavor and the appearance is deep, dark black. Nice roasty aroma - goes down oh so smooth. No gritty aftertaste  Original 4.0  Excellent for a 'mainstream' Porter.  Great coffee aftertaste.

A strong, sweet aroma of liquorice. Sweet taste with an abundance of liquorice, some hopbitterness and a touch of roasted malt. Bit of tartness in the finish. Nice, easy to drink porter, but I expected more complexity and assertiveness.

id hoped for a little more out of this from the things i read. and dont get me wrong, as it is certainly a solid porter, but i picked up a strange aroma of super glue (im serious). on the bright side, this was a gorgeous beer...dark with a nice creamy head.
always a great buy nice an flavorful a little expensive on the east coast here but well worth it
A good porter.  Best I have had with exception of Bells.
A porter with a beautiful appearance and a taste that nearly equals its looks.  Great brew for the price.
lovely pure chocolat aromas, deep dark colour, nice foam, and a lovely taste, a little bitter aftertaste.

Didnt much care for this porter.  A little to sweet (liquorice) and way too watery.  Plus it seperates if left open and becomes incredibly flat and tasteless.  I puked this stuff up once in college and have never been able to get past it.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2003 A solid porter with no overpowering components.  Deep coffee color with a mocha colored head consisting of large bubbles. The nose is extremely subtle with dark chocolate, roasted malt, earthy hops, mild dark fruits (WTF??) and light-bodied coffee.  Roasted malt flavor is just right - not overpowering.  Same with the chocolaty flavors and the assertive, yet perfectly balanced, hops on the finish.  A full mouthfeel, very balanced and abundant range of flavors and subtle and supurb aromatics make this a very fine porter that leans toward being a stout.
Nice roasted malt finish with a decent coffee malt flavor as well.  Very distinctive, but the roast flavor is a bit much for me sometimes.
This stuff is alright.  Much better than Anchor Liberty Ale will ever be.  The charred coffee/chocolate flavor is pretty distinctive, but the burnt finish is a little too much for my tastes.
Very good...strong coffee, almost a smoky flavor.
Rich,sweet, with coffee and chocolate notes.I buy it when I see it.
I really loved this porter.  Slightly sweet, with loads of coffee and chocolate.  Id recommend this to anybody as I couldnt ever imagine anybody not liking it.  I loved it!
wonderful coffee/carmel aroma (fades rather quickly), deep rich dark color, with a smooth creamy head. reminded me of mac-n-jack.
Deep brown color, beige head.  Roasty coffee nose.  Roasty coffee flavors in the start also.  thin middle.  dry slightly bitter finish.  Average Porter.  I am not impressed with Anchor so far.
Fairly rich for a porter.  Tasted more coffee than chocolate. Had a funky taste that I just cant pinpoint.  The same taste is prevelant in their Steam and Liberty beers.  Strange.
Rich and satisfying.  Sweetish black coffee is what springs to my mind.  Very nice.
Red-black-brown beer with good head. Chocolate and blue cheese in the aroma. Molasses and honey in the mouth and then some bitterness. One of the best porters out there
This is a great porter. Good beer with meals. Nice coffee taste. Good head.
This will probably sound crazy - but I swear I taste the slightest hint of banana in this beer!  it has a really great taste and beautiful color.

This is a good Porter and is one of the best that you can get readily and at a good price. I like Great Lakes Edmund Fitzgerald Porter more but not much. Great coffee flavor and dry roasted chocolate bean impression. I will definitely get this again.
Very good porter.
UPDATED: AUG 1, 2004 Big dark head with lots of lacing. Aroma of chocolate, licorice and dark fruits. Very rich and sweet. Flavor of roast, chocolate, raisons and figs.

Re Rate: 4/13/02. A six for aroma. What was I thinking? This beer has an incredible aroma. Maybe my favorite beer from a stellar brewery. Nice deep rich color. Not a whole lot of head. Huge malty chocolate taste that is nicely balanced with a bit of hop bitterness. A fine porter.
Best American/World Porter
A sweeter interpretation of the porter style. Very full, rich mouthfeel. Excellent flavor.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2004 World class porter all the way!  I just found out that one of my local bars has this.  Dark, think palate, burnt/coffee aroma, slightly burnt chocolate flavor-nice think palate, probably the thickest porter out there.-a great porter!!!

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2007 Yet another note added, 3/30/02: I keep going back and forth on this one.  I have to include as part of my ranking my memory of drinking this afterward.  What I remember too much is that dull, woody feel in my gut afterward.  I wanna like this one a little more than how I rate it, but I just find it hard to come back to.  (Sigh...)

Update 3/29/02: Disregard my earlier, idiotic review.  What was I thinking?  Oh well.  This one I had just after having the world-famous Celebrator, and how this one seemed to remind me of it!  Appearance is first-rate.  Black, opaque, lots of initial head, that oh-so-creamy little bit of retention that purrs, suck me off the surface if you can.  Okay, this is getting a little pretentious, so sue me if I like it. :-P!  What bite?  Why was I such an idiot?  This is sweet, smooth, chocolatey, delicious.  Steely Dan playing in the background.  (And the water will change to cherry wine... Perfection and grace, its the smile upon my face.)  I have to bump my rating up a little.  How bout that aftertaste.  Hmmm?  Smoky, woody notes?  (What is a note anyway?)  Burnt feel?  Chocolate?  Part of this nutritious breakfast?  Am I wrong?  Am I wrong?

Drink the damn stuff, okay?

My earlier, idiotic, philistinic review:

When I first tried this, I loved it, though it has worn on me somewhat since.  Certainly has a bite to it as I assume any robust/sharp porter should.  But I suppose Im among those who could do without such a bite.  Hard for me now to down a full bottle.

This was more or less a standard porter.  It had a good, dark color and was just good.  If you want more description, read a couple other reviews, especially cathcacrs.  im in no state to be as eloquent (big word!) in my review.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2003 Ohhhhhhhh.  Doesn"t get much better than this. Possibly even better than Fullers Porter. I need to taste each side by side to decide.  Perfect combination of bitterness (very little) and sweetness (plenty, but not too much).  Licorice, toffee, coffee, maple syrup.  Many flavors.  Pours with thick, quickly diminishing light brown head.  Black in appearance. Silky smooth with medium body (Fullers may be a bit heavier and silkier??).
This is one great beer for dark beer lovers. It has a very nice texture and the finish is excellent.

This is a very drinkable beer.  I was very impressed with the variety of flavors, and the deep, dark opaque look.  The tastes ranged from roasted raisuns/plums to coffee and maple syrup.  I was most impressed by the overall smoothness and silky texture.  I would reccomend this one to any dark beer lover.

Wow  this is one helluva brew.  Beautiful rich ruby black hue  almost opaque.  Aroma  heavy roasted chocolate malts, caramel invitation.  Taste  smooth as silk  nice head - it is thick and creamy, amazing for a bottled beer!  Aftertaste  -reminiscent of coffee, although not overdone or long lasting.  Excellent beer  places number one porter on my list (only b/c SS Taddy is impossible to get fresh)!  Cheers! Had again this week -- top 5 all time beer -- smooth, creamy and drinkable. Chocolate delight! A must have!
user_location: Palm Beach Gardens, FL, Florida, USA

text: This is the first robust/sharp porter that Ive tried and its really quite tasty.  Much better than the sierra nevada porter which is a little to pale for a porter.  This has a unique finish which I am unaccustomed with.  Quite a surprise.
A fine porter, but the thing that really got me was the finish.  Nice roasted malt and strong hoppy bitterness.  Delightful.

another nice beer from anchor.  However, I found the palate to be somewhat light.  However the flavor all but makes up for the lightness.  Im sensing flavors of coffee, and malt. A very malty finish.  Very good dark beer.
My first Porter and it definitely encouraged me to try more.

Big roasty malt nose and a near-black color. Tastes of chocolate and carmel mixed with espresso undertones. The flavor profile on the brew lasts forever - seemed like it stayed in my mouth for a minute!. Started with a warm and full mouth feel that rose to the roof of my mouth. Went out with a gritty, bitter finish. Great stuff. Not good for making stout or porter pancakes, though. Anchor is just a damn good brewery. I like to drink heavy beers like this with light foods, like a salad, but this doesnt need any help - its a meal of its own.
A not-so-well-balanced porter, with a slight roasty malt body, but a pretty big, bitter hop kick.

Might have to do a side by side with Sierra Nevada Porter to pick a favorite. Total class, total quality from Anchor. Very roasty, nice bitter finish. A damn fine porter. Blows Yuengling and the supermarket porters out of the water.
Another good selection from the second oldest brewery. All of Anchors products have been very good selections

UPDATED: APR 1, 2014 Little to no head, very dark, alcohol and chocolate? in the nose, very nice. A lot thicker than most of the porters I have had. Nice and chewy but there is something I dont care for. Nice beer, but nothing spectacular. Orig rate 3/5/02...3.5. Very malty aroma. Huge malt flavor, almost barley wine esk. Hop bitterness is moderate, but malt is just plain huge. Mostly dry, sticky and syrupy. Overly malty sweet, cloying.
Great porter.  Black as midnight.  Notes of slightly burnt coffee very evident.  Fluffy tan head.  A bit robust for my palate at the start but got smoother as it warmed a bit.
Excellent beer.  Nice split between heavy stouts and those American water beers.  Could use a better head.
I was very surprised by this beer. It has a fantastic and complex flavour. Nose is rather soft, with hints of chocolate and wood. Very nice beer.
Has a little bit of a creamy, chocolatey taste, with a slightly bitter aftertaste. Very little head. I havent drunk many porters so I cant say much more.
Best porter that I have had yet. Thick and full flavored, very rich, although i like the other anchor steams better. If you like porters, definitely give this one a try.

Quite delicious.  Very 
dark.  Nice chocolate malty flavor.
Excellent brew.
Masterpiece.  This is a truly enjoyabe porter.  Wonderful chocolate notes and not too bitter.  Definately a taste experience if drank along with Mary Jane ;)
Roasted chocolate/coffee aroma. Black, large light brown creamy head, perfect lacing. Sweet, coffee, malt flavors. Finish is roasted, bitter and long. I love this beer!
UPDATED: JAN 19, 2003 Delicious porter -- aroma is inviting chocolate roasted malt.  Taste is of that, together with mild hops.  For a porter, this beer is quite rich.

nice chocolate sweetness and coffee bite. nice thick taste.  not sure if i could sip more than a couple of these at one sitting without a break for another style.  definitely in my top 10 porters, though.

Normally Im a big porter/stout fan but I was a bit disappointed with this stuff.  Not very smooth, the bite was more of an acidic nature than of a strong beer type.  Chocolate flavoring wasnt bad, nor was the maltiness.
Chocolaty sweet, wonderful aroma. One of the best porters Ive ever drank. Its no belgain strong ale, but alot easier to find and damn good!
I liked this beer. I had it for the first time at the Fog City Diner at the Scottsdale Fashion Square Mall. It is a good porter. I enjoyed it.
Very good. Slightly sweet.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2006 Head is initially average sized, frothy, light brown, mostly lasting. Body is dark brown to black. Aroma is lightly malty (chocolate, roasted grain), lightly hoppy (pine), with a note of fennel/anise seed. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.  Is it just me or has this gotten more sour and simple of late?
Coffee chocolate and roast barley aromas, head didnt last long but looked good while it was there. Tasted like an alcoholic Dandelion & Burdock with a dry finish.

A very aromatic beer at first and even more so as it warms.  There is a thick dark amber heads that fades to a slight rim of foam.  Alcoholic notes, moderately hoppy; earthy, malty aftertase, very dry at the finish.  Beer earns the style title sharp with quite a bite.  As it warms coffeish aroma and taste.  Warms the stomach, complex ale.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2007 My first experience with porters, and hopefully not my last.  Sharp smell of coffee and dark malt, some molasses upon opening the bottle.  The taste reminds me vaguely of the horehound candy I had as a child, but that is a GOOD thing.  The slight head disappears quickly, but I like that about this one.  Its balanced and smooth, almost syrupy in body.  Overall, a good experience.
One of the best American porters. I liked the balance and the smoothness. Unlike Sierras not too strong with the hop finish. I would recomend this as a fine example of the style.
After viewing the rest of labattboys ratings, I realized why he rated this so low - he doesnt know good beer.  This beer is delicious, robust, and malty....pure goodness.
Hated it.  I cant believe people actually like the taste of crap like this.
Excellent porter! A worthy working mans brew . . . and a fine looking bottle to boot!

nice opaque color, with tannish head that quickly fades.  theres a suprisingly weak aroma for an american porter, mainly coffee with an alcoholic tinge.  moderately hoppy, lending a pleasantly dry finish.  the malt flavors are nice and earthy.  this one improves significantly as it warms.  great for after you come out of the cold.

Nice roasty malt taste, slightly nutty with lingering pleasant palate. The alcohol tint offsets nicely the slight sweetness in the body, creating in the whole a well-crafted porter that is good enough to be enjoyed on its own.
Alcoholic nose. As a result, starts with sharp tint of alcohol. Medium-bodied with a nice dark chocolate mid. Finishes clean with a mild aftertaste.
This is roasty and nutty.  A well crafted porter.
Excellent

A good sitting around the house and want a good beer, beer, but not a special occasion beer by far.  Nice head, decent flavor, little light on the color, nice adverage portner, but nothing special here.
Roasty patent malt bitter flavor, not too sweet.  Perfect appearance, grainy tan head.  Palate could be a little thicker.  This is an almost ideal beer with chili dogs & chips, BTW.

This is the beer that woke me up to what real beer is, and I can not thank it enough.  Chocolate dominates the black malt, but both are moderate and balanced for this often overdone style.  A classy execution of a gruff style.
Assertive but not overpowering, this porter is a truly classy brew. It has a crispness that is uncommon in the style. Definitely recommended.
This is a great porter, indeed.
This is a wonderful porter.  I even enjoy it more than Fullers London Porter.  The experience on the palate is unforgettable.  The initial taste is hoppy but it is quickly displaced by sweet malts.
A damn good beer, especially on those cold, cold, wisconsin nights.
can i have another?
What more can be said about this classic?  It begins very smooth, almost like a (chocolate?) ale, and ends with a nice roasty bite.  Session is on!

Pours with a huge cream/tan colored, long-lasting head.  Wonderful sweet chocolate aroma with hints of roasted malt.  Medium bodied, smooth mouthfeel.  Chocolate flavour to start with bitter roasted flavors to finish.  A classic American porter.
mysteriously black.  good stuff.
A great porter - rich and creamy, even though it has a slightly oily mouthfeel.  You want coffee?  You got it - tons of it.  Lots of depth of flavor.  Did I mention I really like this porter?
Beautiful black color and a creamy head. Nice sweet/bitter balance. Drink on the slightly warmer side.
Once again the anchor brewing company has crafted another fine brew. I do not usually enjoy porters, but this was a pure pleasure to drink.

Normally, the description printed on a beers label isnt worth the ink that was used to print it. Well, Anchor has delivered:  The deep black color, the thick creamy head and the intensely rich flavor...have earned this delicious and unique brew a worldwide reputation for outstanding quality.  They hit the nail on the head.  Opaque with a thick, creamy, tan head and delicious malt and chocolate flavor.  Heavy and smooth like a stout, with a bitter, rich chocolate aftertaste hinting at yeast, which reminds me this is a porter and not a stout. Excellent.
Really good once it warmed up a bit. Had lots of nice malty chocolatey flavors. Dried my mouth out a bit too much though which i didnt care for.
At first this was terribly bitter, but then it warmed up alittle and all was well in the world. Enjoyable malty taste with slight hops foundation. Medium mouthfeel and a full, sharp taste.
A nice robust porter- one of Anchors better  brews.
I like to test porters by drinking them warm - just a quirk of mine, I guess - and this one holds up spectacularly.  Creamy, spicy, a fine roasted feel.
a bit sweet for my taste

Is there a theme going on here? Maybe the best porter made in the USA, but them more research is required. Reminds me very much of Sams Imperial with its port flavors. Great coffee dryness, teasing chocolate aroma. Anchor Steam made this brewery famous, but this beer is better.

Fine cola colored foam, a very deep copper color Theres not much in the nose which is a tremendous flaw for the style. Some chocolate in the mouth and excellent balance with full hop flavors balanced by a tanninesque finish. Very clean. Besides the aromatics, well done.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2005 July 2001:  Did a Porter session and sampled this after McNeills.  Not disappointed with this great brew, probably 5 years since Ive last had it.  Wonderful smoky/sweet/popcorn (yeah, thats what I get) aroma followed by incredibly well-balanced robust/sweet flavor.  Probably the best American porter Ive had.  Now, if only I could get the barley wine around here....8/5/10/5/19 4.7

June 2005:  yet another beer I rated incredibly high in my first year on RB that I will proceed to trash now...no, just kidding.  The beer pours an incredibly well-laced, thick dark-headed coal black, just beautiful...lovely cocoa nose with small hints of buttery caramel and popcorn, hmm was I spot on 4 years ago?...vanilla and a tiny hint of orange as well...flavor is outstanding, the velvety moutfeel supporting creamy vanilla-chocolate, sort of "3 Musketeers" bar nougat goodness, but with some acerbic, lightly sour cherries and dark roast coffee giving some bite...compulsively drinkable, exquisitely balanced, still one of the very best porters ever and worth the extremely high grade I gave it when young and impressionable.
My favorite porter.
I think this porter is dissapointing and could be a lot better.  Never had it on tap, which may account for that.
I love anything by Anchor Steam, and this Porter is no exception.  I would have to say that this is my favorite all around porter; not as sweet as other porters, which I dont care for.  Yummy.
UPDATED: MAR 5, 2003    A very nice porter, but something hangs around in mouth for too long afterwards.
Full, rich. What else can you say.  A very good porter.  The best.
Excellent porter.  Roasty up front, a little bitter in the back.  One of the best porters out there.
A great porter.
Best porter I have had.  Hands down.  Rich and roasted, without being too sweet. Excellent fullness in mouth.  Perfect finish.  Another great product from the best brewery in North America.
Very full flavored.  A great all around beer.
Great flavor.  Nice aroma.  This is one of my favorites.
Cant say anything to add to the many good things that have already been said about Anchor Porter.  Suffice it to say that I agree with most of the other comments.  Great stuff.
One of the best porters on the market.
A good porter, but I actually like Sierra Nevada Porter better.
Yeech, fools you with the rich, malty smell and gives you a nasty bitterness.

sorry to scew the ratings, but i dont know what you guys are talkin about.  ill admit im not a porter or stout guy, but i know what tastes good... not this.  Overly bitter throughout, not a pleasant experience.  Sorry, but this one wasnt for me.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2004 Deep brown-black color, nice dark tan foamy, lasting head.  Such a unique and full-bodied porter.  Chocolate  flavors with an incredible bittersweet, roasted malt finish and lingering hops.  Thick and creamy.  Quite satisfying.

Im also a big fan of Porters. To me this is one of the best domestic Porters made. Its overall presentation is is fairly aggressive and well balanced with a rich chocolate malt nose and flavor. Creamy mouthfeel with thick long-lasting head. Has somewhat of a port wine taste in the background similar to Sam Smiths Taddy Porter. Good stuff!
decent
Really really good.  As a self proclaimed porter man, this one definately makes my approved list.
Very good porter, not too sweet, just a little bitterness toward the end. A good beer for after dinner with a cigar.

Forgive me if I wasnt as impressed with this as Id hoped.   Creamy, yes - well balanced bitterness, yes, but for some reason, the aftertaste did not agree with me.  And I love porters, too.  Perhaps Ill give this one another shot given all the hype...
Very nice porter, but so far nothing compares to my beloved Mocha Porter.
One of the best porters in existence.  Its a tough call between this and Rogue Mocha Porter.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2003 dark black colour with a thin and compact head, nice lacing, aroma of dark chocolate, licorice and alcohol, oily, thick, dry malty chocolate finish with a long lasting but somehow rough bitterness

I have to agree with everyone else here:
this is one of the great porters.  It has just
a hint of chocolate, plus a great roasted malt flavor
and is not overly sweet - it actually has a nice mild bitterness
that seems to result from both hops and the burnt flavors (roasted
malts).

Roasted, toasted, rich, bitter, & chewy, with just the right hint of chocolate aroma. Strong mouthfeel. I love the burnt flavor! Abstractly intricate Brussels Lace patterns form on the inside of the glass. Not too overly sweet like many porters. What a great beer!
UPDATED: SEP 26, 2012 Consumed via bottle.  This is a very nice porter.  It is rich with a nice burnt molasses taste.
